column2: Member of Mother Church Passed Away
column3: My mother- a member of the Mother Church- recently passed away, and one of her directives to me was that I contact the Mother Church and inform them that she has passed away.  I know she loved Mary Baker Eddy and Christian Science, and I am grateful for all it has done for Mom over the last 65 years.  She did not give me here membership number, so if you need that information, then please let me know, and I will look for it.  My mother's name is Evelyn Cline from Carefree, Arizona, and was formerly of Tucson, AZ.  She was a member of First Church-Tucson since the 1950's and I would guess a member of the Mother Church since the 1950's or the 1960's.  --  Regards,  Steve Cline "What you choose to think about, to concentrate on with all your mental power, will, indeed, become a reality. So choose carefully." Thomas D Willhite

column3: Good Morning Clerk:  Re:  Margaret J. Trotter - Member No. 6758833  This is to inform you that sadly, our 98 year-old mother Margaret passed away on Wednesday July 31, 2019. Kind Regards,  Pam Pichanick-Graham (daughter)

column2: Contribution for 2019
column3: Hello Folks in the Office of the Treasurer, My member number is: 149009086 I just received an email confirmation for my contribution to TMC for the month of August. In late January/early February of 2019 I sent in (or submitted online) my 2019 Per Capita Tax Contribution form authorizing a MONTHLY contribution of $275 starting in Feb. 2019. This was to be charged to my American Express card. I allocated my contribution per month as follows:Per Cap Tax General Fund = $150.00TMC Endowment Fund       = $50.00CS Monitor Operating Fund = $75.00Total per month = $275.00 Your recent email confirmation alerted me to check if other monthly contributions had been charged to my AMEX card.There were no other charges from FCCS for 2019.   I had hoped to make my yearly contribution to TMC for 2019 to be eleven months @ $275 for a total of $3025.00. I don't know how this mistake regarding my contribution happened or why my AMEX card was only charged for the first time in August.  I want to honor my initial intention of contributing $3025 for 2019.  Please let me know how I can reach my total contribution goal for 2019 without having to make a lump sum payment. Thanks in advance for your help with this. Marilyn Dietrich

column2: Re: Payment Question  (KMM117554521V35197L0KM)
column3: *******************  Forwarding, please respond to customer. Thanks, Sarah  ********************  Thank you for contacting The Christian Science Publishing Society.      If we can be of further assistance, please let us know.  To ensure your future concerns are handled in a timely fashion, please include all previous e-mail correspondence.    Thank you,  Sarah  The Christian Science Publishing Society Customer Service  ebiblelessoncustserv@cdsfulfillment.com   Gift the Monitor Daily! 6-month Gift or 12-month Gift  For all your subscription service needs, visit https://w1.buysub.com/servlet/CSGateway?cds_mag_code=CAV the quick, easy and safe way to manage your magazine account and answer any questions you may have in one convenient place.     Customer's email address: ericwalling@astound.net  Case id: 40899484  Subject line: Re: Payment Question  (KMM117531259V54328L0KM)  Received Date: 8/9/19          Original Message Follows: ------------------------     The problem is that "Change Payment Details" is not listed on the screen, so I cannot access it.     From: eBibleLesson Sent: Friday, August 09, 2019 5:41 AM To: ericwalling@astound.net Subject: Re: Payment Question (KMM117531259V54328L0KM)   Thank you for contacting The Christian Science Publishing Society.       You can change your billing information for your eBibleLesson subscription by following these directions step-by-step:    1) Login at www.ebiblelesson.com    2) Put your cursor over "Welcome" in the top right corner and choose  "My Account" from the drop down menu.    3) Login again with your full email address and password.    4) If your billing address has changed, click on the link in the right side of the screen to "Change Payment Address." On the next screen you can change your address information and when finished, click the ""UPDATE your information" button at the bottom of the screen.  5) If you only need to update your credit card details, click on the link on the right side of the screen to "Change Payment Details." On the next screen you can change the credit card type, number and expiration and when finished, click the "UPDATE your information" button at the bottom of the screen.    If you are using a mobile device, such as a tablet or smartphone, the display on the screen will be different. Once you are logged in to your subscription, you will see "Welcome" in the upper right of the screen with "My account" and "Log out" underneath it.  Tap on "My Account". You will be asked to log in again. Once on your account page, you will find the option to "Change Payment Details" and "Change Payment Address" by scrolling down to the bottom of the webpage.    We hope this helps and you continue to enjoy eBibleLesson!      If we can be of further assistance, please let us know. To ensure your future concerns are handled in a timely fashion, please include all previous e-mail correspondence.   Thank you, Sarah The Christian Science Publishing Society Customer Service ebiblelessoncustserv@cdsfulfillment.com   Gift the Monitor Daily! 6-month Gift or 12-month Gift   For all your subscription service needs, visit https://w1.buysub.com/servlet/CSGateway?cds_mag_code=CAV the quick, easy and safe way to manage your magazine account and answer any questions you may have in one convenient place. column2: Missing pages in German Fulltext Edition August 2019 - Your messages 8/2/2019
column3: Dear friends, hear is a more  detailed explanation of the mistakes in the August edition of the German Full Text. There were no errors in the text of the lesson about which the printer would have to be consulted. The error was in the assembling of the (correctly) printed pages. In several issues, the pages 5 to 12 were contained twice (subject: Love), and the pages 13 to 20 were missing. Correspondingly, the connected pages 61 to 68 (subject: Mind) appeared twice, while the pages 53 to 60 were missing. -- We will offer copies of the missing pages taken from correct issues and deliver them to our customers who received the faulty issues, so we do not need extra copies. So this is just to inform you about what exactly happened, and hopeful to avoid a future repetition of the mistake. Thank you for your help, and all the best wishes for your precious work! Kind greetings from Southern Germany  (with help of our writing secretary in English) Yours Gudrun Fanz (Reading Room-Team)

column2: Editorial comments and corrections
column3: The following information was collected:  Name: Mary Jo Beebe  Email: Mjbeebe@tx.rr.com  Subscriber: Yes  Subject: Type weight  Product: Monitor Digital Edition  Message: I recognize that this comment is not about your reporting, but to me it is equally important. It is about being able to SEE your reports. The world has gone to gray type. Black and readable is no longer fashionable. I know about design having written marketing materials for years, but now as a senior I struggle with the type.  Could you please start making the type more readable for all your editions? Pitch the paragraphs of Italics, also.  They are so difficult, so it is tempting to skip them.  Thank you!  I love the Monitor.

column2: Editorial comments and corrections
column3: The following information was collected:  Name: Emily Pfister  Email: epfister315@gmail.com  Subscriber: No  Subject: Letter to Editor Re: May 27th Isue  Product: Monitor Print Edition  Message: Dear Christian Science Monitor,  I am writing to let yow know that I have liked reading this issue.  But, I do not feel that your article on vaccines was in line with the Spirit of your magazine.  Basically, Christian Scientists would not be taking vaccines and would not feel that a paper published by the church, which is supposed to be fair, would publish an article in which the dominant position was that people that don't take vaccines are all mistrustful or anti-government or big Pharma.  Basically, I think in an article lke that, it would be helpful to clearly express the position of the church and then fairly epresent both sides of the issue.  In the article, you did not quote one person that has refused to give vaccines to their child for religious or other reasons.  You only quote people who are totally supportive of vaccines or who are supportive enough to have given their child vaccines.  I find this sloppy journalism and it represents sloppy thinking.  Something that the Monitor is not known for at all and something that is not reflected in the rest of the issue.  Thank you fr taking my comment!  Emily Pfister Arlington, VA

column2: Re: Question re Membership Files
column3: ORM has the final say on this. column2: Fwd: Question re Membership Files
column3: Data Protection and/or ORM,  Would you be able to answer Debbie's question from 1st Church, St. Petersburg, FL and cc me at tmcbranch@csps.com?  Thank you!  Laurel Sheehan Churhc Activities  ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: First Church of Christ, Scientist <fccsstpete@gmail.com> Date: Wed, Aug 14, 2019 at 2:00 PM Subject: Question re Membership Files To: <tmcbranch@csps.com>   The Board has asked that I write to you and ask the following question in response to the recent "Church Activities Department" notice on Data Protection.  First Church of Christ, Scientist, St Petersburg Florida is a consolidation of First, Second and Third Churches.  First Church has also been in existence since 1888.   We have many, many membership files (but probably not all of them dating back to 1888).  I was told when I took on the position of Clerk, that "Boston, requires us to maintain  all of the membership files."  We are asking, if "Boston" *still *requires that we maintain *all *of the membership files?   If yes, then we will need to obtain a special, locked file cabinet due to the Data Protection compliance.  Thank you for your help.  Debbie Steen Clerk/Board Member Cell 727-601-8523  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to dataprotection+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: RUPTURE
column3: PIEBOP Dieudonné Cel : 237677771708  Douala –Cameroun                    Toute la famille PIEBOP duCameroun  Toute la famille TENGAA  du Cameroun  Toute la famille NGUELIATOU  du Cameroun  Toute la famille NAADJOC  du Cameroun  Tout le clan  MBEEPEH du  Cameroun Toute la tribue BAMILEKE  du Cameroun      Objet        RUPTURE DE TOUTE ALIANCE ; RUPTURE DE  TOUT ENGAGEMENT ; RUPTUREDE TOUT PACTE DE  TOUTE NATURE ;RUPTURE  DE TOUTE RELATION ;  RUPTURE DE TOUT CONTRAT, entre vous et  notre fille, épouse et mère, la nommée KAMENI NGELIATOU ROSINE.                       Monsieur le responsable del’EGLISE  MERE DE LA SCIENCE CRETIENNE,                       Nous avons l’honneur devous informer que :   NGUELIATOU ROSINE  est mariée et mère de cinq enfants.  La rentréescolaire au Cameroun aura lieu le 02 septembre 2019.  La sus –nomméeest actuellement endettée  et doithonorer ses engagements.  Son foyer estrégulièrement  perturbé depuis qu’ellecollabore avec vous.  Ses enfants etson époux ne peuvent plus jouir de sa disponibilité du fait de nombreux documents  et autres contraintes de votre église.  Ses affaires ontsombré  et elle est l’objet de plusieursperturbations psychiques depuis sa prise de contact avec votre église.                          Nous avonsconstaté  que de manière subtile, vousl’avez enrôlé comme membre de votreéglise, à l’insu de son époux, de ses enfants et de toute safamille.                             Nous avons constaté  que de manière subtile, vous entretenezrégulièrement une correspondance  confidentielle avec elle, aumépris de nos us et coutumes  et aumépris de la législation camerounaise.                          Nous avonsconstaté  que de manière subtile, vousl’avez obligé à assister à unecérémonie initiatique  àKINSHASA  en  RDC  àla veille de la rentrée  scolaire, méprisant ainsi l’éducation de sesenfants , pour mieux les contrôler, les aliéner et compromettre leur avenir.                           Nous avonsconstaté  que de manière subtile, vousl’obligez  régulièrement  à vous verser des contributions financières et vous l’obligez à acheter vos livres, ce qui vous a permit de laruiner et de mieux la contrôler, de l’aliéner.                             Vu  ce qui précède, nous vous demandons  d’annuler immédiatement  la participation de notre fille, épouse etmère KAMENI NGUELIATOU ROSINE à votre cérémonie initiatique de Kinshasa. Nousdemandons la rupture immédiate de tout contrat, toute alliance, tout pacte ,toute collaboration entre l’EGLISE DE LA SCIENCE CHRETIENNE   et KAMENI NGUELIATOU ROSINE.

column2: Recommended books
column3: I am writing in regard to the book recommended in the CSMonitor of AUGUST 5th,2019 on page 40.  Big Sky by Kate Atkinson sounded so good that I immediately bought it.   I was terribly disappointed to find out that it was mostly about pedophiles.  I kept hoping it would improve and kept reading, but gave up after page 111.  I have been a CSM reader all my life, since the days of “Snubs Our Dog” and appreciate it more than ever now as I am in a CS Nursing Home here in Southern California and have more time to read.  I do not think a book like this deserves to be in our excellent newspaper.  Thank you for your attention.  Elizabeth Jensen Broadview nursing home  Sent from my iPad  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Share your comments with the Sentinel Editors [#5298]
column3: Title * Testimonies of healing in CSS & TCSJ Author By Zack Web Address (URL) of page https:/sentinel.christianscience.com/shared/view/5dm2njajxy?s=cs Name *    Donna-Eric Johnson Email Address *   marspirit@centurylink.net Share your Comments: * For several years I have noticed that many times the country of the testifier is "US".   Remarkably I still think to myself " Who or what is "US" ? Then, in a few seconds, "Of course, it is the United States." But this is not precise, and can be misleading. Our country is the "United States of America":  U.S.A. Comment Publication *  Please do not publish my comment.  User Agent Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_11_6) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.1.2 Safari/605.1.15

column2: Re: Bible Lens online: Deepen your study of the weekly Bible Lesson
column3: Makes no sense to click on the button for Soul in the Bible Lens section and have it link to everything but...  Frustrating! column2: JSH links to Christian Science Perspective articles [JSH-Online #31136]
column3: Subject * JSH links to Christian Science Perspective articles Message *  Hi, I am a long time JSH subscriber, but have not yet subscription to the online Monitor.  I understand your desire to charge for Monitor articles online, and I appreciate that a previous bug was fixed which had caused the same article to count as multiple articles if I opened it from my email, then tried to read it in a browser.  And, it’s nice that you include links to the CS Perspective articles from JSH.  However there is nothing to indicate that opening those links will cause an article to be charged to the now three a month allowed as a guest.  Please add a warning with the links on the JSH page that lets people know these articles count towards the three free a month.  Failing to do so implies the articles are free with a JSH subscription, as are all the other articles that have links in JSH.  Conversely, if these articles aren’t supposed to accrue towards the three allowed, it isn’t working.  Thanks for your help!  Sincerely, Ellen Biemer  Email *   solarbear@biemer.com Category * General Comments/Feedback Name    Ellen Biemer User Agent Mozilla/5.0 (iPad; CPU OS 12_3_1 like Mac OS X) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/12.1.1 Mobile/15E148 Safari/604.1

column2: Share your comments with the Sentinel Editors [#5286]
column3: Title * RADICAL RELIANCE IMPLIES UNRESERVED OBEDIENCE Author LESTER G. BESOLD Web Address (URL) of page https:/sentinel.christianscience.com/shared/view/31w062fveg Name *    Cheryl Petersen Email Address *   scienceandhealth.revised@gmail.com Share your Comments: * This article implies that radical reliance on Truth means radical reliance on prayer. Truth is not prayer.  Moreover, the word radical has taken on a different definition since Eddy's time when it meant, the root.  A better wording could be, "Only by advancing from the root of Truth can scientific healing power be realized." Comment Publication *  I give permission to publish my comment. column2: Glamping Cover Story -- disappointing
column3: On the heels of the UN Climate report last week, it was very disappointing to receive the most recent Monitor with a cover story about "Glamping".  A cover story about the efforts of the Trump Administration to dismantle longstanding environmental safeguards (the Endangered Species Act, for example) would have been far more relevant and edifying to Monitor readers.  Why prominently perpetuate the myth that humans can easily insulate themselves from the natural world and that doing so is a good thing?  The Monitor needs to be far more direct about its climate reporting.  This global threat needs immediate and decisive action and prayer.  Widespread complacency needs to be disrupted -- the facts need to be widely broadcast.  The Monitor -- with its base of engaged readers -- is in a perfect position to do this.  To tread lightly on the subject of climate change because here in the U.S. powerful corporate and political interests have created the *fiction *that there is some uncertainty about whether climate change is real only serves to validate those who are committed to perpetuating ignorance about this issue.  Why not feature a cover story about Greta Thunberg and *devote an entire issue* to climate change this fall, in advance of the Global Climate Strike on September 20th?  See https://globalclimatestrike.net/ and https://www.brightest.io/cause/fridays-for-future/activity/global-climate-strike-september-20/  *Sharon C. Lincoln* Boston, MA

column2: Editorial comments and corrections
column3: The following information was collected:  Name: Emily Pfister  Email: epfister315@gmail.com  Subscriber: No  Subject: Letter to Editor Re: May 27th Isue  Product: Monitor Print Edition  Message: Dear Christian Science Monitor,  I am writing to let yow know that I have liked reading this issue.  But, I do not feel that your article on vaccines was in line with the Spirit of your magazine.  Basically, Christian Scientists would not be taking vaccines and would not feel that a paper published by the church, which is supposed to be fair, would publish an article in which the dominant position was that people that don't take vaccines are all mistrustful or anti-government or big Pharma.  Basically, I think in an article lke that, it would be helpful to clearly express the position of the church and then fairly epresent both sides of the issue.  In the article, you did not quote one person that has refused to give vaccines to their child for religious or other reasons.  You only quote people who are totally supportive of vaccines or who are supportive enough to have given their child vaccines.  I find this sloppy journalism and it represents sloppy thinking.  Something that the Monitor is not known for at all and something that is not reflected in the rest of the issue.  Thank you fr taking my comment!  Emily Pfister Arlington, VA

column2: Re: Why Iowa’s brand of politics may matter more than ever
column3: David, interesting stats you summarized below.  Please check on the annual cost of 7% of the food stamp and Medicaid programs.  I know the full 7% doesn’t go to illegal aliens, but think about what a portion of this amount could do to support our legal citizens if it was directed to those that need these benefit programs.  But that perception is not based on the facts. Let’s take food stamps: 93% of all food stamp payments go to native-born U.S. citizens<https://www.csmonitor.com/Photo-Galleries/Infographics/10-Immigration-myths-debunked/(photo)/739915>. What about Medicaid? The Associated Press puts that number at 93%.  Keep up the good reporting. I love the Monitor. Scott Maxwell  On Aug 13, 2019, at 3:19 PM, Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com<mailto:daily@csmonitor.com>> wrote:  [The Christian Science Monitor Daily]  Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress.  August 13  <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email> Full Version [headphones icon] Listen <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=full-audio-block>  In today’s edition, our five handpicked stories explore democracy<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?src=email#1094061> (Why Iowa?), leadership <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?src=email#1094063> (Hindu nationalism), hope<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?src=email#1093944> (in eastern Ukraine), generosity<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?src=email#1094062> (in Maine), and endless creativity<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?src=email#1094065> (Leonardo da Vinci).  But first, even legal immigrants are freeloaders.  That’s a perception underscoring Monday’s move by the Trump administration to make it tougher for legal immigrants to become U.S. citizens<https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Politics/2019/0813/Why-Trump-administration-tightens-access-to-green-cards> if they’ve relied on food stamps or Medicaid or housing vouchers. Officials framed the decision as a principled push toward self-reliance.  True compassion isn’t giving someone a fish; it’s teaching them how to fish. In other words, tighter green card rules help people become self-sufficient, administration officials suggest. Of course, tackling the problem of “freeloading” immigrants plays well with voters as we head into the 2020 election.  But that perception is not based on the facts. Let’s take food stamps: 93% of all food stamp payments go to native-born U.S. citizens<https://www.csmonitor.com/Photo-Galleries/Infographics/10-Immigration-myths-debunked/(photo)/739915>. What about Medicaid? The Associated Press puts that number at 93%.  In fact, if you’re a capitalist, you want legal immigrants. They create new jobs. Immigrants are almost twice as likely to become entrepreneurs as native-born U.S. citizens<https://hbr.org/2016/10/why-are-immigrants-more-entrepreneurial>, reports Harvard Business Review. Immigrants make up just 13% of the population but account for nearly 28% of America’s entrepreneurs. To become a U.S. citizen, immigrants need to be resourceful, persistent, and determined in overcoming obstacles – the same qualities that make good entrepreneurs.  Just ask South African immigrant Elon Musk (Tesla), Russian immigrant Sergey Brin (Google), or Taiwanese immigrant Jerry Yang (Yahoo).  ~ [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2017/06/1029905_4_illustration-Dave_Scott_standard.png?alias=square_400x400] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d2d1c2ec284feb553a652ef254ff6c401ac232f2631c32fb5faa8e7dffd409ee2f8d1b36e66d63b50503b5913555f75aba2595511e1806754>  David Clark Scott  Audience Engagement Editor  [twitter] @davidclarkscott <https://twitter.com/davidclarkscott?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email>  [Daily facebook share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140dcfa2ebbe33b2d4e483240d8e29a4734ec12538238f3e4348aeaf160a7af1f3f28f596d721f8c2869d31552aa2e0a0416f43ee661cdec8a90> [Daily twitter share]  <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d1bc63129acabb9050545c209c7593f8d4d57a4e9323b94f34606e5801bd639fb981e84e16baf5c3a74fff4f524d9fd224cbc98daf43c559a> [Daily email share]  <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Are%20immigrants%20really%20freeloaders?+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/Are-immigrants-really-freeloaders?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> 1. Why Iowa’s brand of politics may matter more than ever [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/08/0813-STATEFAIR.jpg?alias=standard_600x400] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1094061> Scott Morgan/Reuters  Why Iowa? Our reporter looks at the big role this small, rural state plays in America’s democracy, and in choosing the nation’s next leader.  – David  The 30 Sec. Read  Over the course of 10 days this month, more than a million people will come to the Iowa State Fair to sample pork chops on a stick, ride the Ferris wheel, and gawk at the famous “butter cow.” Many will also encounter various Democratic presidential candidates, making their pitch from a soapbox.  “You have a big burden on your shoulders,” Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar tells the crowd.  For nearly 50 years, Iowa has played an outsize role in the presidential nomination process, with its first-in-the-nation caucuses. And while the state has a mixed track record when it comes to selecting presidents, it plays a pivotal role in winnowing the field. On the Democratic side, seven of the past nine winners in Iowa have gone on to secure their party’s nomination.  Iowa’s voters are known for taking their role seriously. But it is one of the whitest states in the nation, which has led to questions about its influence. Those may only grow this cycle, when with less than a year to go until the national Democratic convention, there are still some two dozen candidates in the running.  “The bigger the field, the more important the caucus is,” says Dennis Goldford, a political scientist at Drake University in Des Moines.  By Christa Case Bryant  [twitter]@christacbryant<https://twitter.com/christacbryant?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email>  Read 8 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1094061>  ( 1709 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140dac7a39cf0831be6de33fc81e480c4e179f819faa6bfca6fc04226f302e6bac50fe43e31ddb27179bbf0e45ca5d938d217009bf51b8379fb2> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d048be11f753b1bdc4f6618030bd6edbd44df3eaa5b312e25564dec58f2b49db9d4b4ae32193738e32a62a3a5f6a981f2168a7a21388441e1>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Why%20Iowa’s%20brand%20of%20politics%20may%20matter%20more%20than%20ever+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/Why-Iowa-s-brand-of-politics-may-matter-more-than-ever?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> 2. More like Modi: Hindu nationalists nurture the next generation [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/08/0813-NATIONALISTS.jpg?alias=standard_600x400] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1094063> Ann Hermes/Staff  To understand the crisis in Kashmir, some point to India’s emboldened Hindu nationalists. Our reporter looks at an effort to foster leadership qualities to combat secular intellectualism and corruption.  – David  The 30 Sec. Read  India’s Hindu nationalist movement is taking the next steps in building a new generation of leaders – especially among educated, urban youth.  In creating new higher education programs, it’s drawing upon the popularity of India’s first Hindu nationalist prime minister, Narendra Modi. He surprised almost everyone with a convincing reelection victory in national elections in June. At the same time, his ruling party reinforced its hold on parliament. It’s that kind of political dominance that emboldened Mr. Modi this month to revoke the Indian Constitution’s article granting special autonomous status to majority-Muslim Kashmir.  Mr. Modi has not only boosted the image of the nationalist movement but has also been central to the movement’s growth among a key segment of the population. “You could map the growing interest of educated youngsters, doctors and entrepreneurs and professionals, in entering politics and improving governance to the rise of Narendra Modi,” says Ravindra Sathe, dean of the recently established Indian Institute of Democratic Leadership.  By Howard LaFranchi  Read 5 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1094063>  ( 1232 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d607aa61e68ffbe28d2de9c41db984fd6899862f12b6f3b68dddec711a39c04dec526fdb3cf9f7bc0743c34b0c041d6e527670032d90c1ed7> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d9dd4e5c3a7d9b3fd9e0672ab1ed38f7d626d5f4ab01f49ba67fd70610cb18d02b28ae478e3d4be9528385a54c0398b918ab907f46fd58ea7>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+More%20like%20Modi:%20Hindu%20nationalists%20nurture%20the%20next%20generation+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/More-like-Modi-Hindu-nationalists-nurture-the-next-generation?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> 3. Isolated by Ukraine’s war, this city looks for a peaceful future [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/08/1088010_1_0813-mariupol_standard.png?alias=square_400x400] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1093944>  Mariupol sits on the edge of a simmering war zone in Ukraine. But our reporter found it is also a place of burgeoning hope, where at least some innovative people are treating the crisis as an opportunity.  – David  The 30 Sec. Read  With the front lines now just about seven miles from the city limits, the ongoing war in eastern Ukraine is seldom far from the subject of any conversation in the port city of Mariupol. But recently, the battleground has become ideological too. More than half of voters in the Ukrainian-controlled Donetsk region cast their ballots for two pro-Russian parties who blame Kiev, not next-door Russia, for their troubles. These divisions are a huge challenge for new President Volodymyr Zelenskiy, whose party came in second in July elections around here.  The challenges facing the city are on full display at Mariupol’s Azov Sea port, which a decade ago shipped more than 15 million tons annually of products to every corner of the world. But the establishment of two separatist republics took much of the port’s hinterland away. The loss of the nearby Russian market amid an ongoing sanctions war between Ukraine and Russia inflicted more damage.  “We all hope that with the new leadership at the top of the country, this war will end,” says Yuri Balan, deputy director of the port. “Peace is the main thing that everyone here in the Donbass wants.”  [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/08/1087989_3_0813-mariupol_map_large.jpg?alias=original] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1093944> Karen Norris/Staff  By Fred Weir  Read 6 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1093944>  ( 1251 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d44eee0be4fc7141fdbc3db167da950a5a6985e9568fefa20298f5b0ae9c6b19241b9fb173335a51e4b814c1aec050262b146e13168705f94> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d859bcb9e877062d2879ac8a86579752c68386fdf9018dc838f512cdf7c70c7eab0ad2fade82a198497764db05360ead87591823e1501442a>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Isolated%20by%20Ukraine’s%20war,%20this%20city%20looks%20for%20a%20peaceful%20future+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/Isolated-by-Ukraine-s-war-this-city-looks-for-a-peaceful-future?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> 4. Among those helping Maine’s new arrivals: other immigrants [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/08/1088006_2_0813-portland_standard.png?alias=square_400x400] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1094062>  It’s an age-old fear: There’s not enough good to go around. But scores of Mainers are rejecting a scarcity mindset as their city welcomes hundreds of asylum-seekers.  – David  The 30 Sec. Read  On a recent afternoon, volunteers cooked 600 meals to be served at a local sports arena. Lined with cots instead of bleachers, the Portland Expo Center became an emergency shelter in June with the sudden arrival of Central African asylum-seekers. Several meal prep volunteers are asylum-seekers themselves. They slip in and out of French, Portuguese, and Lingala with the ease of changing aprons. Some have already found temporary housing. Yet day after day, they keep turning up to cook for fellow newcomers.  “My people,” a volunteer named Nathalie calls them. “As they eat and feel fed, I also feel better.”  Portland has gained at least 437 asylum-seekers in less than two months. Their arrival cued another surge: an outpouring of donations and volunteerism. Immigrant community leaders, who once sought fresh starts here themselves, have bridged resource gaps between the newcomers and the public’s generosity.  Maine resident Jeff Diggins has hosted three families in the past. A fiscal conservative from Texas, he acknowledges the complexity of the U.S. immigration system and values that asylum-seekers are in the country legally.  “I don’t think kindness is a limited resource,” says Mr. Diggins.  By Sarah Matusek  Read 6 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1094062>  ( 1445 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d4f2050be689961dff40f4e28240dfa7253b015becb8abf8824bbb6ffe2962fffd304ae540c5802c8271b07719fc27a25a58152eb49335e92> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140de40f93aabef0f50fc33033d3687d50b8b19f94a2dec6df1b6b8c15b27defca333fd996fefb7b9176f28dfda9061b66e54d4fb4ef86f345e4>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Among%20those%20helping%20Maine’s%20new%20arrivals:%20other%20immigrants+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/Among-those-helping-Maine-s-new-arrivals-other-immigrants?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> 5. Da Vinci at 500: The master who never stopped experimenting [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/07/0805-LEONARDO.jpg?alias=standard_600x400] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1094065> Bibliotheque de L'Institut de France, Paris  What drives people to continuously learn? Five hundred years after Leonardo da Vinci’s death, we examine the paths he took to endless creativity.  – David  The 30 Sec. Read  Two things consistently fascinated Leonardo da Vinci: the mechanics of flight and the movement of water. His mind was like both, swiftly flowing but occasionally pooling to encompass depths beneath the surface.  At the 500th anniversary of his death, scholars, art lovers, and the public are taking a far-reaching look at his career. Exhibitions in Italy and England, as well as the largest-ever survey of his work, which opens at the Louvre Museum in Paris this fall, are celebrating the master’s achievements not only in art but also in science.  One of those exhibitions, of Leonardo’s drawings, is attracting multitudes to the Queen’s Gallery at Buckingham Palace in London. “Leonardo da Vinci: A Life in Drawing” displays the full range of Leonardo’s elastic mind at work. It conveys a life in process, a man and mind on a continuous learning curve, endlessly observing, studying, thinking, reflecting. The drawings – more than the finished paintings – show him improvising and experimenting, much more than just recording reality.  By Carol Strickland  Read 3 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1094065>  ( 583 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d76d8918c4c8615bf169deb8357a820c13b1cb3b798232127db8146fcfcbab5d8016d98b5ca000f7da086cbd2e9f3f909b8a032175f4fba5f> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d40d7426d24dc062855c4bbb9e9071fd5f5df3348aa609460417be2ab4d30e3cdc1af56912b77883f7529a1e9f485a56faa7a3b06ceeaf53b>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Da%20Vinci%20at%20500:%20The%20master%20who%20never%20stopped%20experimenting+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/Da-Vinci-at-500-The-master-who-never-stopped-experimenting?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> The Monitor's View Why the sudden challenge to autocracies? The 30 Sec. Read  Since 2006, the world has witnessed a decline in political rights and civil liberties. Yet 13 years on, this troubling trend could be in reverse. From Algeria to Slovakia, young people have taken to the streets to push for a range of democratic ideals. The most unexpected protests have been in Russia and in China’s semiautonomous territory of Hong Kong.  In particular, the protests in those two giants of autocracy indicate there is a limit to how much people will tolerate a loss of basic freedoms and the right to self-governance. They also show a strong memory of what happened 30 years ago when Beijing brutally ended pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square and the popular uprisings in Eastern Europe led to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the collapse of the Soviet empire.  China may yet crush the Hong Kong protests, while in Russia, President Vladimir Putin wields a strong stick. But at least the signal has been sent that democracy’s decline is not inevitable. Once a foundation for freedom has been laid around the world, it is hard to break. Protesters will find a way to stand on it.  By the Monitor's Editorial Board  Read 2 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1093829>  ( 451 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d408c9dd9598e891a351417011ddd26542be8f733665f4ef78c1b5d352238743c3e919c3f86ff10a0572d07b057f82ebf713072c706bb5eed> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d30cf6a7eb445d4692fb9b5438bf86027d4e6efe3c8ea92bc5660a35a83010f5269f23fac188ebadc17ab17e57b9066736fac9144a9e9a347>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Why%20the%20sudden%20challenge%20to%20autocracies?+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/Why-the-sudden-challenge-to-autocracies?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> A Christian Science Perspective ( About this feature<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140df54ae6c7e2d163de8c9c68d9103b07922175b071330c345e5114763445b7a05d5d1aa3eb451f2326439dbfb704ff418c> ) The path to meaningful employment  After moving to another country and struggling to find work, one woman experienced how turning to God for guidance brings inspiration that lights the way forward.  By Andrea McCormick  Read 3 min.<https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email&id=1093830>  ( 674 words )  [Daily facebook share]<https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d1b22e54dc4ba36ca71035c4be7f2fce032ab8bc25d36854dd24690c2685106b5ca9b2ae9500be4a25aa17768a1e6055c59aa1fd6f3f4f247> [Daily twitter share] <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=9a53d677a603140d2d2b3e457192366ae71a516ea996e31bd885da0c31123ae1817ae62410133c035e400d666260d9cb9f24d9dd25e3614c545c5ad6875d892e>  [Daily email share] <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+The%20path%20to%20meaningful%20employment+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813/The-path-to-meaningful-employment?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Viewfinder Starlight [https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2019/08/0813-Viewfinder.jpg?alias=standard_600x400] <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190813?cmpid=ema:bundle:20190813&src=email#1093831> Stars streak across the sky in a long exposure image taken near the town of Mitzpe Ramon in southern Israel, Aug.13, 2019. column2: Mary Baker Eddy our Leader
column3: It was so encouraging to see Anne Melville’s article (what a powerful article it is!) in this month’s (August) Journal referring to Mrs. Eddy not only as our Leader, but also as our “beloved Leader”. Those terms have been sorely missing in our periodicals in recent years. In Article XXII, Section 1 in our Church Manual, Mrs. Eddy speaks of calling her “Leader” and says that Leader is “already used in our periodicals”, but it is not being used in our periodicals of late. She is often referred to as “Discoverer” and/or “Founder”, but seldom “Leader”. It is important that she be recognized and acknowledged as our Leader. She is our forever Leader and that should be made clear in our periodicals. Many of the testimonies in the chapter Fruitage in Science and Health refer to our “revered Leader”, our “beloved Leader”, our “dear Leader”, our “faithful Leader" and this is done even more than once in a single testimony on occasion. Why is it that the expression of our gratitude for our Leader, for her Leadership, is so lost? Please, bring it back!  With deep gratitude for your commitment and dedication to the periodicals, Carol

column2: Editorial comments and corrections
column3: The following information was collected:  Name: Grace Braley  Email: gbraley55@gmail.com  Subscriber: Yes  Subject: US immigration  Product: Monitor Print Edition  Message: I appreciate your coverage of many pertinent topics.  I am particularly interested in US policy regarding foreigners arrival, and our policy failure in relation to this.  It is curious that a note about spending $2.5 billion for a border wall to prohibit foreigners from the South, follows a story about trying to recover information on when we imported millions of slaves from Africa, and that, following an article on how the US is financially interfering with the operations of a democratic nation, Venezuela, in South America.  None of these behaviours shows respectable values.  How can we bring forward a leadership which promotes human dignity and responsible governance -- that theme we espouse:  democracy with justice?

column2: Re: Why El Paso is determined not to roll up the welcome mat
column3: Dear Mark,     Earlier this week I came across the following quotation by Maria Nemeth, in her 1999 book The Energy of Money: "We all exist in an interdependent system.  No matter how we feel about it, we're linked socially, economically, and biologically, like the cells of a giant organism.  We are healthiest when all parts of our bodies and society are functioning together." -p. 271 Five sentences later, at the end of the next paragraph, Nemeth concludes: "Given that interdependence, it quickly becomes clear that our greatest success comes when all of us succeed together." -p. 271     It is clear, both that former president Obama understood this concept, and also that current president Trump does not.  This concept is also the correct answer to white nationalists here in the U.S.A. and also to the nationalist movement in the U.K.     One of the headlines in today's news is that five countries outside the U.S.A. are "teetering on the brink of recession:"  China, German, Italy, U.K., and Japan.  It is clear from Nemeth's words that if China goes into recession, then every country in the world will be adversely affected--including the U.S.A.     I would like to request that you use the Christian Science Monitor as a "bully pulpit," so to speak, to publicize Nemeth's words.  Because we the people need to disassemble the current trade wars as soon as possible, or a lot of people are going to suffer badly if we don't. Sincerely, Jerry Jacoby1307 Sara Way SERio Rancho, NM 87124-0999(530) 263-6099     On Wednesday, August 7, 2019, 04:17:02 PM MDT, Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com> wrote:       08/07/2019 Perspectives matter. _filtered ; _filtered ;#yiv1157442311 h1, #yiv1157442311 h2, #yiv1157442311 h3, #yiv1157442311 h4 {margin:0;padding:0;}#yiv1157442311 p {margin:0;padding:0;}#yiv1157442311 a {text-decoration:none;color:#000;}#yiv1157442311 a:hover {text-decoration:underline;}#yiv1157442311 ul {padding:0 0.5em 0 0.75em;margin-top:0;}#yiv1157442311 li {padding-bottom:0.5em;}#yiv1157442311 blockquote {margin-top:0;}#yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311mini p, #yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311intro-text p {padding-bottom:20px;}#yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311viewfinder a {color:#fff;}#yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311viewfinder .yiv1157442311mini p {padding:0;}#yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311button:hover, #yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311twitter a:hover, #yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311whatIsThis a:hover, #yiv1157442311 a:hover {text-decoration:none;}#yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311intro.yiv1157442311editor-intro .yiv1157442311intro-text a, #yiv1157442311  .yiv1157442311outro.yiv1157442311editor-intro .yiv1157442311intro-text a {border-bottom:1px solid #424242;padding-bottom:1px;}#yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311separator-design{text-align:center;}@media screen and (){#yiv1157442311 #yiv1157442311main-content, #yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311content-container, #yiv1157442311 .yiv1157442311announcement {max-width:100% !important;}}  |    | |   Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress.   |    |    |   |      |   August 07    | |    Full Version      Listen    |       |   Welcome to the Daily. Today, our five handpicked stories start with an extraordinarily beautiful portrait of the grace of El Paso. We also pull back the curtain on the U.S.-China economic battle, look at how President Donald Trump’s approach to foreign policy is changing the Middle East, examine why independent bookstores endure, and tell the story of one family’s amazing dedication to save a rare horse breed.  But first a look at why the world should be watching Hong Kong.  These days, it would seem, authoritarianism is on the march. From Russia to the Philippines to Saudi Arabia, strongmen seem to be calling the shots. Elsewhere, strains of populism have some worried that democratic norms are under threat or already in tatters.  But in Hong Kong, protesters have put the strongest of strongmen – Chinese President Xi Jinping – in a bind. The demonstrators are increasingly worried that the Hong Kong they love is vanishing. The rights and liberties that have made the city a unique and flourishing hub of culture and global trade seem to be hanging in the balance. So The Wall Street Journal notes that protesters are becoming more desperate and radical in their determination to fight for their way of life.  It is a reminder that freedoms, once spread, are hard to take away. To be sure, mainland China holds the upper hand. But Hong Kong – and Taiwan – show that freedom and justice put down tenacious roots. For decades after World War II, the world took flawed but unprecedented steps to spread and protect freedoms across the globe. Hong Kong shows that such seeds can be transformative.  ~   |      |      | |   Mark Sappenfield    Editor      @sappenfieldm     |      |            |       |   |  |  |   |    |       |    1. Why El Paso is determined not to roll up the welcome mat    |     |       Callaghan O'Hare/Reuters    |       |    El Paso is an old city with a big heart, residents told our reporter. Its embrace of all isn’t going anywhere, they say, despite a terrorist attack aimed at its diversity.    |      |   – Mark    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    As the sun set over El Paso, Texas, dozens of people gather outside the Immaculate Baptist Church for a vigil for the 22 people who died in an attack at a Walmart. Pastor J.C. Rico leads prayers in both English and Spanish.  “I refuse to let that change the way we live, change the way we are,” says Rosie Rico, the pastor’s wife.  The alleged gunman had no ties to this 400-year-old city on the banks of the Rio Grande. He drove more than 600 miles from a Dallas suburb to commit the attack, which law enforcement are treating as domestic terrorism. El Paso has been, for years now, statistically one of the safest cities in the country – but now some residents are questioning whether they are safe from the rest of America.  “It’s like we’re the antithesis of how a lot of people in the heartland, where I grew up, view us,” says Bill Clark, co-owner of the bookstore Literarity. “It’s probably the most welcoming city one could want to live in.”  Daniel Aguilar, who attended the vigil, says, “It sounds like [the gunman] was not getting love. He would have got love from us. We would have given him love.”    | |   By Henry Gass    | |    @henrygass    | |  Read 7 min.  | |   ( 1648 words )    | |       |       |    2. Currency manipulator? What latest twist in trade war means.    |     |       Chinatopix/AP    |       |    The recent stock market jolt underlines the complex consequences of trade wars and currency manipulation. This story explains the thinking behind the deeper chess battle between the U.S. and China.    |      |   – Mark    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Fears of a currency war have piled atop anxiety about rising tariffs and their toll on the global economy.  Stock markets around the world swooned after Beijing allowed its currency to fall below a key level against the U.S. dollar. The United States declared China a currency manipulator. Meanwhile, the U.S. and other nations have shifted toward lowering interest rates – a move that can often result in weakening currencies.  But is this a currency war, a modern version of what happened during the Great Depression when nations devalued their currency in a vain attempt to boost their exports at the expense of others?  Many economists are skeptical. The big risk to global economic growth, they say, isn’t currency but tariffs – with the U.S. threats escalating against China last week. And the interest rate cuts can be explained as addressing that risk to overall growth, not as currency manipulation.  Pushing currency values lower can also blunt the impact of tariffs. Battles over currency “are not that bad,” says Olivier Jeanne, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in Washington. But as a tool in a rising trade war, it’s worrying.    | |   By Laurent Belsie    | |    @lbelsie    | |  Read 5 min.  | |   ( 1069 words )    | |       |       |    3. Checkbook diplomacy? How Qatar’s renewed US ties reshape the Gulf.    |     |      |       |    Shared values? Or shared interests? The principle guiding President Trump’s “transactional” diplomacy has been more the latter. Among Gulf Arabs, that’s created competition for good U.S. relations.    |      |   – Mark    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    President Donald Trump’s about-face on Qatar – receiving the emir, Sheikh Tamim al-Thani, at the White House in July as an “old friend” two years after condemning the Gulf Arab state as a “funder of terrorism” – was telling.  It potentially shifted the balance of power in the Gulf, opening a door to a resurgence of multilateralism in the region. And, say observers and officials there, it exposed the limits of influence achieved by Qatar’s rivals, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, in a transactional White House.  Just as Mr. Trump touted Saudi Arabia’s billions in arms deals during a March 2018 visit by the crown prince, in the recent visit by the emir, Qatar inked tens of billions of dollars in deals with Raytheon, Boeing, and Chevron. It was a case of Qatar beating Saudi Arabia and the UAE at their own game.  Says Andreas Krieg, a lecturer in security studies at King’s College London: “The Qataris understood that Trump is very much a transactional president – as much as the Saudis and the UAE understand – you need to pour money into the country in order to win his favor.”    | |   By Taylor Luck    | |  Read 5 min.  | |   ( 1195 words )    | |       |       |  Point of Progress  What's going right   | |    4. Comeback story: A new chapter for indie bookstores    |     |      |       |    While their numbers aren’t what they once were, independent bookstores are reclaiming their place in society. Behind their surprise resurgence is renewed emphasis on fostering community.     |      |   – Mark    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    In the past decade, the number of independent bookstores in the United States has grown by more than 50%, from 1,651 stores to more than 2,500, according to Dan Cullen, senior strategy officer of the American Booksellers Association.   Observers say a special blend of local flavor, dedication to physical books, accessibility to authors, and a business model that includes other revenue streams has fueled the resurgence. The formula has proved so successful chains are working to bring a small-venue feel to their big-box stores.   “One of the key ingredients to the independent bookseller is this notion of community,” says Ryan Raffaelli, an assistant professor at Harvard Business School. Owners often sit on city boards and are active in public schools, he says.   Patricia Fowler, owner of Village Square Booksellers in Bellows Falls, Vermont, serves as treasurer for two local community groups and participated in a program to support high schoolers as they plan for the future.   “Some of our customers that started out reading picture books are now into the teen and young adult books,” says Ms. Fowler. “We grow with our customers.”    | |   By Thomas Shults    | |  Read 3 min.  | |   ( 649 words )    | |       |       |  Difference-maker  Drivers of change   | |    5. To save rare ponies, one couple gives up almost everything    |     |       Becky Holladay    |       |    What does it look like to sacrifice almost everything for a cause? For one couple, it means they haven’t had the time or money to leave their locale for two years. But it also means a deep connection to animals in need.    |      |   – Mark    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    With its wild ’80s-rock-star mane, muscular body, and charismatic nature, the Skyrian horse has become a sort of cultural icon for the Greek island of Skíros. But today, there are fewer than 300 of these horses left worldwide, maybe 200 if counting only purebreds.  Stathis Katsarelias was drawn to the breed and its cultural significance. “I felt this duty because I’m from Skíros,” he says. “As a Skyrian, we should care about them.”  “They will grab your soul and your heart,” says his partner, Amanda Simpson.  In 2005, Ms. Simpson and Mr. Katsarelias started Skyros Island Horse Trust. From the beginning, its mission was twofold: take care of the existing population on Skíros and selectively breed the horse to create a more robust breed. When they started the project, they took in horses from locals who could no longer care for them, as well as some starving horses wandering on the mountainside. They started with four horses. Today, there are 35.  “When I see them here, and I understand that they feel safe, and that they feel secure, and that they are relaxed, this gives me the strength to go on,” says Mr. Katsarelias.    | |   By Becky Holladay    | |  Read 5 min.  | |   ( 1155 words )    | |       |       |  The Monitor's View     | |    In Dayton and El Paso, the potential power of forgiveness    |     |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Police are still trying to pin down the exact motives for last weekend’s killings in two American cities. But one motive fits both. Each dehumanized their victims out of rage. Yet not surprisingly, a few of the victims’ families as well as community leaders have refused to reciprocate the rage. They have offered forgiveness.  Acts of forgiveness after a massacre are rare. Yet they can be powerful. In a reminder of what is possible, a documentary came out this spring that details the forgiveness given to Dylan Roof by families of victims killed in 2015 at a black church in Charleston, South Carolina. In the new film “Emanuel,” Chris Singleton, the son of one victim in the church, says his forgiveness was not a choice to “move on.” It took strength to forgive. And it allowed him to be free of anger, to spread love and unity, and to work to prevent similar tragedies.  The impersonal hate of the shooters in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, deserves a response at many levels – justice in the courts, reforms in legislatures, and denunciation of their motives. Yet none may be as powerful to prevent more shootings than forgiveness.    | |   By the Monitor's Editorial Board    | |  Read 3 min.  | |   ( 603 words )    | |       |       |  A Christian Science Perspective  ( About this feature )   | |    Listening for the voice of Love, not hate    |     |    It’s not always easy to let love lead us forward instead of hate, especially in the wake of tragic events. But each of us has a God-given ability to do so.    | |   By Rosalie E. Dunbar    | |  Read 3 min.  | |   ( 706 words )    | |       |       |  Viewfinder     | |    Hasty departure    |     |       Indian migrant laborers carry luggage at a railway station in Jammu, India, on Aug. 7, 2019, as they prepare to leave Kashmir. Jammu and Kashmir, India’s only Muslim-majority state, borders Pakistan and has long been disputed. On Tuesday, India’s parliament approved a proposal from the Hindu nationalist-led government to revoke Kashmir's special status, stripping its limited autonomy and raising fears of greater conflict. Channi Anand/AP    |      |     |       |   ( The illustrations in today's Monitor Daily are by Jacob Turcotte and Karen Norris. )   |       |  A LOOK AHEAD   | |    Thank you of joining us today. Please come back tomorrow, when we look at how the national conversation on gun violence in America is playing out in Washington.    |      |      | |    Mark Sappenfield    Editor      @sappenfieldm    |      |    |            The Christian Science Monitor is a trademark of The Christian Science Publishing Society,   registered in the United States and in other countries. column2: Girls step up to the plate
column3: I read your article in the August 12, 2019 issue and thought I would send along a photo of my daughter, Molly Gordon Tysinger, who was disappointed to learn there weren't enough high school students to field a varsity softball team during her Junior year.  Not to be daunted, she switched her allegiance to the boy's baseball team and soon claimed the starting catcher's position with an occasional appearance at first base. Her skills were even put to use when she scored a catcher's position on a men's team in Vilsek Germany where she lived with her military husband.  Now 24 years old, a wife and a mother of 2, she says these were some of the best times she ever had.  Girls rule!

column3: The following information was collected:  Name: Barbara Williams  Email: bgwilliams.cpa@live.com  Subscriber: Yes  Subject: Glamping  Product: Monitor Print Edition  Message: I so enjoyed Michael Hopkins' feature on glamping.  As a lifelong Monitor reader, I have followed and admired the work of Melanie Stetson Freeman, so the peek into her glamping trip with her husband was a treat.  Monitor writers always feel like family to long time readers.  Michael's writing style was a delight; I look forward to more articles by him.  Not sure if glamping is for me, but it was a pleasure to learn about this style of travel.  Happy s'mores!

column2: Angels
column3: Attn: Tony Lobl  I missed the podcast on angels but will find it!  This isn’t for publication as it probably wouldn’t be suitable. But I have to share my experience with you.  I’m a lifetime Christian Scientist, having been raised in an active Christian Science home where it was practiced on a daily basis. I was always taught from the Bible and Science and Health, by Mary Baker Eddy that angels were God talking to us through our own thoughts. Not winged creatures with halos, etc.  I’ve come many years from those lessons but never stopped trusting in them.       A month ago my husband and I were looking for our passports to renew them.  We live on the third level, garage/basement to main floor and the bedrooms.  Searching for 3 consecutive days in every conceivable place; file cabinets, desks, computer cabinets, bedroom closets and drawers, car and van, without success. We were at a total loss as to their location.  I threw up my hands and said, “I’m turning this over to God, He knows everything! I should have done this 3 days ago!”  Day 4 I was folding laundry in the upstairs bedroom, when loudly, firmly a voice said “Go to the Van”!  I dropped everything, went down the 4 levels of stairs, opened the door to the garage, opened the van door, passenger side, got in, opened the cabinet between the seats, reached in, removed 2 passports, without the blink of an eye!  I sat there totally amazed, raised my head to praise God and said out loud....”Dear angel if you had a name I would say Thank You to you and God!”      I would swear I heard “Hazel”. I smiled, said “thank you Hazel, angel messenger of God!”   I ran upstairs, shared the “lost that was found” with my astonished husband, and called a dear Christian Science friend.  Half an hour later she called back saying she checked her Hebrew Dictionary to see if Hazel might be listed.  It was and was defined as “GOD SEES”!  Since then I can attest for sure that God’s messages are strong, to be listened to and obeyed. No matter a name or not!     I so enjoy your Sentinel Watch and wanted to share this with you Tony! Sincerely, Ellen C Allen  Celebrate What’s Right With The  World??

column2: Re: How ‘safety first’ ethos is destabilizing US society
column3: Excellent piece on safety.   Thank you for being so clear on  how the definition of "safety" had shifted.   Kathleen Osborn Redlands, Ca.  Sent from my iPhone  > On Aug 14, 2019, at 3:18 PM, Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com> wrote: >  >  >        > Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress. > August 14 >  > Full Version                  Listen                                 > In today’s edition, our five handpicked stories explore the downside to a “safety first” culture, a dispatch from inside Kashmir’s lockdown, a potential trade deal between Britain and the U.S., a debate over what it means to be wild, and 10 great reads. >  > Moscow has been seeing its largest protests in years as thousands have come out weekly against the decision to bar opposition candidates from running in city council elections. While the stakes may initially have been about some minor municipal seats, the Kremlin may now be viewing the ongoing standoff as an existential threat. >  > The protests began in mid-July, when officials blocked several high-profile opposition candidates from running in the Moscow elections, even after they fulfilled the races’ onerous logistical requirements. Though the marches started small, they grew tenfold as police cracked down on protesters, sometimes violently. This past Saturday, some 50,000 people turned out in Moscow, according to organizers’ estimates. >  > The increasing numbers may be painting the Kremlin into a corner, experts warn. Mark Galeotti, a longtime Russia watcher, notes in The Moscow Times that Vladimir Putin and his allies remember the rapid collapse of the Soviet Union, and see giving ground to the protesters as repeating what they view as the mistakes of Mikhail Gorbachev. >  > “It was foolish and shortsighted to have kicked the opposition candidates off the electoral lists,” Mr. Galeotti writes. “Having done so, though, the government has locked itself into a position from which it cannot afford to retreat, or at least to be seen to retreat. This has become a struggle for power.” >  > ~ >   > Arthur Bright > Europe Editor >  @NominallyBright >                                           > 1. How ‘safety first’ ethos is destabilizing US society >   > Eric Risberg/AP >  > What does it mean to feel safe? As perceptions about safety change, so do discussions around how to reconcile random threats and everyday life without becoming overwhelmed.  >  > – Arthur > The 30 Sec. Read > Even before the recent shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, surveys showed that Americans are more fearful about more things in general. Safety may seem more elusive than ever because the very concept of what it means has expanded. It was once defined as a state of physical protection. Now it’s interpreted to mean emotional security, too. >  > While both of those are central to well-being, the way people think about them, some observers say, may be feeding the perception that their environment is unsafe. That leads to less contact with unfamiliar people, and makes even unthreatening acts seem harmful or ill-intended. Instead, they say, people can establish better control over how they choose to perceive their environment. Even without complete control, their fear can be countered through a wider perspective about the preponderance of good in humanity. >  > Diane Urban, who teaches at Manhattan College, suggests that we begin to change our internal narrative about strangers by becoming more conscious of everyday interactions. Watching the news makes people believe the world is a dangerous place, she says. “[W]e’re completely cutting ourselves off from the bigger picture, which is actually a picture of compassion and empathy and kindness.” >  > By Stephen Humphries > Read 9 min. > ( 2053 words ) >       > 2. Inside Kashmir’s lockdown: Barbed wire and a sense of loss >   > Dar Yasin/AP >  > India’s revoking of Kashmir’s special status may reverberate in world capitals. But in Kashmir itself, people’s sense that the world has shifted beneath their feet goes much deeper than politics. >  > – Arthur > The 30 Sec. Read > Rumors have been afloat in Kashmir this week, amid a communications blackout. Rumors, loss, and anger. >  > Since Aug. 5, Indian-administered Jammu and Kashmir has been under strict restrictions. Thousands of troops have flooded the often-volatile area, which is part of the larger Kashmir region claimed by both India and Pakistan. Streets are dotted with barbed-wire barricades, and few people – an especially striking emptiness during Eid. >  > The reason for the lockdown? The Indian government’s decision last week to revoke Jammu and Kashmir’s special status, enshrined in the constitution, which granted some autonomy to the country’s only Muslim-majority state. One day later, parliament voted to revoke its statehood, turning Jammu and Kashmir into two federal territories. Critics have called the moves undemocratic, while supporters argue they will help quell the region’s violent insurgency, and boost economic development. >  > Many Kashmiris feel betrayed, and some argue that politicians are trying to change the culture and demographics of their home. >  > “They removed our guts,” says one policeman, on duty outside a locked-up mosque. “Now what is left of us?” >  > By Fahad Shah > Read 5 min. > ( 1017 words ) >       > 3. Chlorinated chickens! Why swapping trade allies is tough for Britain. >   > A key motivation for Brexit has been independence – specifically to unshackle Britain from Europe's regulatory regime. But the endgame could involve hitching Britons to rules and standards set in the U.S. >  > – Arthur > The 30 Sec. Read > Forging a trade deal with the United States now looks like a top British priority – with trade officials from both sides meeting last week in Washington. Prime Minister Boris Johnson could frame it as a win that offsets the economic hit from a United Kingdom exit from the European Union.  >  > But the economic reality will be less forgiving. Nearly half of all U.K. exports go to the EU, compared with 13% to the U.S. >  > Any free-trade deal with the U.S., moreover, involves a strategic decision that cuts to the heart of Brexit as an economic and geopolitical project. Should the U.K. sign onto U.S.-based rules and standards that govern sectors like agriculture, digital data, and pharmaceuticals – and stop adhering to Europewide regulations after four decades of ever closer alignment? What happens to British companies that compete in Europe’s single market?      >  > Economist L. Alan Winter, at Britain’s University of Sussex, says, “Even if we signed an agreement with the USA that approached the single market in terms of regulations ... it’s likely not to replace the lost trade.” >  > By Simon Montlake > @sjmontlake >  > Read 6 min. > ( 1389 words ) >       > A LETTER FROM              > Honolulu > 4. A tabby by any other name: In Hawaii, a debate over what’s wild >   > What does it mean to be wild? In Hawaii, blurred boundaries between pets and wildlife have been a source of tension, even as residents find common ground in preserving the islands’ unique ecosystem.  >  > – Arthur > The 30 Sec. Read > Hawaii is an animal lover’s paradise: Visitors can watch sea turtles and monk seals bask on sandy beaches, glimpse dozens of species of finches flit through gardens, and even see free-roaming cats claim empty parking lots. Part of the islands’ allure is the chance to see exotic marine life up close, in their natural habitat. Biodiversity has become a kind of currency and industries have sprung up around snorkeling with sea turtles and swimming with dolphins. And residents now live alongside a menagerie of farm animals gone wild. >  > This blurring of boundaries between pets and wildlife has fueled debate, even among animal lovers. The cats are a particular point of contention. Many residents adore them, and have adopted entire colonies. But the cats pose problems for other wildlife, including several endangered species of birds. Both sides bring an intense compassion for animals to this debate.  >  > “The tricky thing about Hawaii is that it is such a unique ecosystem,” says Joshua Atwood, with the Department of Land and Natural Resources. “Species that evolved here evolved without land predators. So a ground nesting bird has almost no defenses against a cat.” >  > By Noelle Swan > @swannoelle >  > Read 4 min. > ( 996 words ) >       > BOOKS > 5. Celebrate summer with the 10 best books of August              >   > Books may seem like luxuries when every day is a struggle for survival. But the story of a hidden library that sustained a town under siege will warm readers’ hearts and feed their minds. In addition to “The Secret Library,” Monitor critics chose two new mysteries, a novel by Richard Russo, and a look at the Cold War as waged in the pages of literature. >  > – Arthur > By Staff > Read 3 min. > ( 632 words ) >       > THE MONITOR'S VIEW              > For Democratic contenders, sharp elbows or big hugs? > The 30 Sec. Read > At least two Democratic presidential candidates speak of bringing grace, civility, and other words of love to politics. Cory Booker calls for “courageous empathy.” Joe Biden praises consensus building. Yet those two find it hard to practice what they preach. Each have thrown ad hominem barbs at the other. They both undercut their most strategic message as a leader: cooperation. Neither candidate has totally abandoned his olive-branch rhetoric, but as they eye the polls, both use it selectively. >  > In his 2016 book “Toward Democracy,” historian James T. Kloppenberg traces the roots of modern self-government to qualities of love, such as deliberation, reciprocity, and plurality. Citizens in a democracy must resolve conflicts peacefully, accept differences in policy and identity, and expect the same in return. Crucial to these attributes of self-governance is a selfless love summed up in the golden rule. >  > Messrs. Booker and Biden need not look back in history to find a persuasive case for political love. They’ve both made the case in recent years. It remains to be seen what happens when love seems less convenient. As the going gets tough in the presidential contest, the toughest must keep loving. >  > By the Monitor's Editorial Board > Read 2 min. > ( 469 words ) >       > A CHRISTIAN SCIENCE PERSPECTIVE                            > ( About this feature ) > From hope to solutions in uncertain times > We may sometimes wish for a way to peer into the future, something to reassure us that we’re on the right path. When one young family faced economic uncertainty, earnest prayer brought the realization that one can never be without God’s goodness and care – which shed light on a solution. >  > By Ingrid Peschke > Read 3 min. > ( 701 words ) >       > VIEWFINDER > Now, voyager >   > Climate activist Greta Thunberg embarks on a transatlantic voyage from Plymouth, England, to New York, Aug. 14, 2019. The Swedish teen eschews air travel and will complete the journey to the United Nations climate summit in New York aboard a solar-powered yacht.               Henry Nicholls/Reuters >  > ( The illustrations in today's Monitor Daily are by Karen Norris. ) >  > A LOOK AHEAD                > Thank you for accompanying our exploration of the world today. Please come back tomorrow, when we look at what China's options really are when it comes to intervening in the protests in Hong Kong. >  >   > Arthur Bright > Europe Editor >  @NominallyBright >  >                  > The Christian Science Monitor is a trademark of The Christian Science Publishing Society, >  > registered in the United States and in other countries. >  > ISSN: 2572-7060 >  > The Christian Science Monitor >  > 210 Massachusetts Ave, Boston, MA, 02115-3195, United States >  > © 2019 The Christian Science Publishing Society >  > Privacy | Unsubscribe > Update Profile  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to daily+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Share your comments with the Sentinel Editors [#5281]
column3: Title * What truly makes us happy and satisfied? Author with Tony Lobl, Tad Blake-Weber, and Annette Kreutziger-Herr Web Address (URL) of page https:/sentinel.christianscience.com/shared/view/29jsx6gy5zi?s=f Name *    LuAnn Condon Email Address *   luannanddan@gmail.com Share your Comments: *  Thx Annette for reminding me of a healing I had some years ago. I had graduated from college with no job prospects, so I returned to a previously held sales job. Every evening it was my job to vacuum the sales floor. Initially this  task seemed to depress me and caused me to wonder why I had gone to university. But after awhile I started to pray about my situation. As I vacuumed I would ponder the words to Me Eddy's hymn, "Satisfied", it matters not what be they lot so Love doth guide. Shortly after that point, I realized that I had loved my way out of that job into a position in line with my studies. Thx for reminding me and thanks for sharing your experience on Sentinel Watch.  Comment Publication *  I give permission to publish my comment.
