column2: Re: After mass shootings, Republicans wrestle with politics of race
column3: I think before we fight white supremacy we need to Define what it is! I grew up in a nation that was 85 to 95% White is it white supremacy if I want to maintain that? By such a definition all of the founding fathers and all of the presidents of the United States up until the 1960s would be white supremacist! And the fact of the madman use the invasion of America by Mexico as an excuse to commit heinous acts does not there for justify the illegal Invasion by Mexico! Any more than the fact that the Dayton Ohio Mass killer being a socialist and Elizabeth Warren supporter mixed socialism and Elizabeth Warren evil! But of course the Dayton Ohio Killers politics are not being made an issue because it doesn't fit the narrative of the fake news media   Sent from my Verizon, Samsung Galaxy smartphone        08/06/2019 Perspectives matter.                      @import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Playfair+Display:700,900');    @import url('https://fonts.googleapis.com/css?family=Open+Sans:300,400,600,700');    h1, h2, h3, h4 {     margin: 0;     padding: 0;    }    p {     margin: 0;     padding: 0;    }    a {     text-decoration: none;     color: #000;    }    a:hover {     text-decoration: underline;    }    ul {     padding: 0 0.5em 0 0.75em;     margin-top: 0;    }    li {     padding-bottom: 0.5em;    }    blockquote {     margin-top: 0;    }    .mini p,    .intro-text p {     padding-bottom: 20px;    }    .viewfinder a {     color:#fff;    }    .viewfinder .mini p {     padding: 0;    }    .button:hover,    .twitter a:hover,    .whatIsThis a:hover,    a:hover {     text-decoration: none;    }    .intro.editor-intro .intro-text a,    .outro.editor-intro .intro-text a {     border-bottom: 1px solid #424242;     padding-bottom: 1px;    }    .separator-design{      text-align:center;      font-size: 1.5rem;    }    @media only screen and ( max-width: 415px ){     #main-content,     .content-container,     .announcement {       max-width: 100% !important;     }    }       -------- Original message --------From: Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com> Date: 8/6/19  3:17 PM  (GMT-08:00) To: ratfieldscheezegarden@yahoo.com Subject: After mass shootings, Republicans wrestle with politics of race                                                           Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress.                                                                                                                                                                                                         August 06                                                                                                             Full Version                                                                                                Listen                                                                                                                                                                  In today’s edition, our five handpicked stories explore GOP solutions (to mass shootings), justice (rape in Sierra Leone), relationships (U.S.-China, human-sea gull), and innovation (jet-engine hoverboard). But first, let’s look at Toni Morrison’s legacy. The first African American woman to win a Nobel Prize in literature (1993) died Monday. Her novels lyrically and unflinchingly plumbed slavery, sisterhood, racism, justice, sexual abuse, rage, guilt, and liberty. She’s “a national treasure ... ,” wrote former President Barack Obama today, “a challenge to our conscience and a call to greater empathy.”She leaves an indelible mark on America and a generation of black writers. I asked Monitor culture critic Candace McDuffie what Ms. Morrison means to her.  “Toni Morrison made me feel valued and seen in a genre where we are usually neglected,” writes Candace in an email. “In white American literature, black women are either completely ignored or reduced to racist tropes. We are not docile Mammys, nor are we hypersexual Jezebels or inexplicably angry Sapphires. We are multidimensional and beautiful beings whose experiences run deep. Morrison managed to embody our complexities through works that showcased our humanity and wholeness.”Candace respects that Ms. Morrison “never jeopardized her artistic integrity. ... Topics like slavery and racism and colorism and black feminism dominated her works and were powerful and revelatory because Morrison prioritized black authenticity over white comfort. And because of this, she will always be one of the most important writers of our time.” Ms. Morrison will be missed. But her unique expression of dignity, defiance, and cultural honesty endures. As Mr. Obama wrote, “time is no match” for her works.                                                                                                                                                                                                                            David Clark Scott                          Audience Engagement Editor                                                     @davidclarkscott                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                ANNOUNCEMENT    Have you set up your password?    Please set up a password to get full access and    no ads on CSMonitor.com.                                                                                                                                                                                      1.  After mass shootings, Republicans wrestle with politics of race                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Our reporters look at how Republicans are shifting their approach to dealing with the problem of mass shootings motivated by hate.                                                                                                                                                                               –  David                                                                                                                                                                                           The 30 Sec. Read                                                                                           As the nation grapples with the aftermath of two horrific mass shootings – one allegedly committed by an avowed white supremacist – the Republican Party has been engaging in a kind of soul-searching of its own.  Many leading Republican politicians, including several from states with large Latino populations, have made a point of calling out “white supremacy” by name and urging others in their party to take an unequivocal stance.Other top Republicans haven’t joined the chorus, however, instead blaming mental illness and video games for the actions of mass shooters. And while some in the party see an urgent need to take a strong moral stand, others see a political trap – since many Democrats are arguing that it is hypocritical for any Republican to denounce white supremacy unless he or she also denounces President Donald Trump. Still, the shift in thought is significant, observers say. Fighting white supremacy will require leaders from both sides of the aisle to consistently and specifically condemn it wherever it emerges, says Cynthia Miller-Idriss, an American University professor who studies far-right youth extremism. “I do think this is a genuine shift happening,” Ms. Miller-Idriss says. “We’re seeing a much stronger condemnation now than we have in the past.”                                                                                                                                By                Jessica Mendoza                                                                                            By                Linda Feldmann                                                                        --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to daily+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Women Should be at Core of U.S. Talks on Withdrawal from Afghanistan
column3: View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/marianne2020/women_afghan_8_17_19-254129?e=86750cd953) https://www.marianne2020.com/ FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE August 17, 2019 Patricia Ewing Communications Director Press@marianne2020.com (mailto:Press@marianne2020.com) 443-906-1495   Women Should be at Core of U.S. Talks on Withdrawal from Afghanistan Marianne Williamson today reminded the Trump administration that any deal made to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan without ensuring the rights and protection of women is unacceptable. Williamson has said for years that engaging the women of Afghanistan is necessary for any successful and lasting plan for the withdrawal of U.S. troops and for creating peace in the region. Williamson said, “The Taliban’s history of brutality towards women must not be forgotten or ignored in these negotiations.”  Women in Afghanistan have made gains in education, employment and political spheres in Kabul, but any gains made in rural areas controlled by the Taliban are still slow and not guaranteed. Williamson called upon the Trump administration to make certain that women are included in the talks, and that safeguards for women’s roles in the economy and government are included in every phase of the talks.  Williamson said, “As President, I would make no move in Afghanistan until I talk to the women. I want to hear from them first. I am well aware of the history of the Taliban in relationship to Afghan women, so nothing happens until I talk to them.”  ###  ============================================================ ** (https://twitter.com/marwilliamson) ** (https://www.facebook.com/williamsonmarianne/) ** (https://www.instagram.com/mariannewilliamson/) ** (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXAMXGAP0YnBxtc8brSSbjg) ** (https://www.marianne2020.com) Copyright © 2019 Marianne Williamson for President, All rights reserved.  Our mailing address is: Marianne Williamson for President 1787 Tribute Rd Ste K Sacramento, CA 95815-4404 USA  Want to change how you receive these emails? You can ** update your preferences (https://marianne2020.us20.list-manage.com/profile?u=7d2c52ee9b55adf2cd969c713&id=0761d20e98&e=86750cd953) or ** unsubscribe from this list (https://marianne2020.us20.list-manage.com/unsubscribe?u=7d2c52ee9b55adf2cd969c713&id=0761d20e98&e=86750cd953&c=d116fe7f4f) . The art of Embroidery and Uniform Equipment has been engrained in the hands of skilled, professionals who have adopted this profession since generations family partnership concern entered into the International market as exporters and manufacturers of UNIFORM BADGES and UNIFORM ACCESSORIES. We also produce Hand Embroidered Uniform Badges in Pak Bullion as well as in French Bullion the following qualities i.e. REGULAR BULLION, HALF FINE GOLD AND SILVER BULLION, GOLD PLATTED BULLION, GOLD PLATTED WITH CONFIRMED GUARANTEE. column2: Show Guest / Review Op - How to Become a Multicultural Church
column3: Dear Stephanie Hanes :  In Matthew's gospel, Jesus tells us to "make disciples of all nations,” and seasoned pastor Douglas J. Brouwer takes the initiative in his insightful book, How to Become a Multicultural Church. Drawing upon his own experiences as a pastor in Zurich, Switzerland, where 30 percent of the population hails from elsewhere, he shares his discerning wisdom on issues such as language barriers, theological differences and cultural stereotypes.   I would be happy to send you a complimentary copy of this thought-provoking book in consideration of an interview, review or feature. Please read the following press release, and contact me to schedule an interview. I'd also be happy to send you JPEGs of Brouwer and the book cover. Thank you.  Please see Brouwer at: http://ascotmedianews.com/em/lt.php?c=18393&m=20753&nl=1198&s=f56e244f21aead307c5458b70ab88d81&lid=273943&l=-https--www.youtube.com/watch--Q-v--E-X9VkW7rR0Uw--A-t--E-1s.  Anna Jones Ascot Media Group, Inc. Post Office Box 2394 Friendswood, TX 77549 news@ascotmedianews.com ascotmedia.com 281.333.3507 Phone 800.854.2207 Fax  (This press release may be reprinted in part or entirety by any print or broadcast media outlet, or used by any means of social media sharing)  FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE  How to Become a Multicultural Church Shares Ways To Engage And Welcome Diverse Congregations  **Grand Rapids, MI, August 16, 2019** — In 2014, Douglas J. Brouwer, a seasoned American pastor, took on the unique challenge of serving a multiethnic, multiracial, multicultural church in one of Europe's largest cities — Zurich, Switzerland, where 30 percent of the population comes from somewhere else. Between the covers of How to Become a Multicultural Church, Brouwer distills the lessons he learned from that experience into timely wisdom on issues every multicultural church faces, including language barriers, theological differences and cultural stereotypes.   A multicultural church, he posits, is one with an intentional engagement of cultures — not just a mix of races and nationalities. Honestly recounting his own questions and challenges in multicultural ministry, and writing in the form of a memoir of his experience, Brouwer shows how churches everywhere can adjust attitudes and practices to embrace racial, ethnic and cultural diversity.  How to Become a Multicultural Church includes chapters on topics such as reconsidering a church's name, being theologically generous and taking an honest look at what the church's flag might mean.   Many churches aspire to be more culturally diverse but lack a practical approach. How to Become a Multicultural Church identifies 10 factors that contribute to the life and vitality of a genuinely multicultural church to help churches everywhere support their efforts toward diversity.  Author Douglas J. Brouwer spent 40 years serving churches in Illinois, Michigan, Florida and Switzerland before retiring to Michigan. He studied philosophy at Calvin College in Grand Rapids, Michigan, and earned master's and doctoral degrees from Princeton Theological Seminary in Princeton, New Jersey. He is also a husband, father and grandfather, and recently the author of The Truth About Who We Are, written in the form of a letter to his grandchildren.  To read more from Brouwer, visit his blog at http://ascotmedianews.com/em/lt.php?c=18393&m=20753&nl=1198&s=f56e244f21aead307c5458b70ab88d81&lid=273944&l=-https--dougsblog.org/, or connect with him on  Facebook at http://ascotmedianews.com/em/lt.php?c=18393&m=20753&nl=1198&s=f56e244f21aead307c5458b70ab88d81&lid=273945&l=-https--www.facebook.com/douglas.brouwer.1 or on Twitter, Instagram and LinkedIn at DouglasBrouwer.   How to Become a Multicultural Church  Publisher: Eerdmans Publishing Company  ISBN-10: 0802873936  ISBN-13: 978-0802873934 Available from Amazon.com, BarnesandNoble.com and Eerdmans.com  ###  TIP SHEET  Q & As available upon request.  Excerpts from online reviews:   "In an age when diversity can be demonized, Doug Brouwer reveals its beauty as the heart of the gospel and the embodiment of the kingdom of God on earth. Through his rich pastoral experience, particularly at the beloved IPC, he reveals the joys, frustrations and gifts that emerge in a multicultural congregation. He is an honest, seasoned and wise guide who will fill readers with the hope that Pentecost is still possible today.”  "One of the key takeaways from this book is the reminder that there is a difference between being multi-racial and multi-cultural. One can have an ethnically diverse church that is still monocultural… many multiracial or multiethnic churches continue to reflect the liturgical and governing style of the dominant culture … Perhaps the most important lesson here has to do with the vision, and finding ways of moving toward its fulfillment.”   "Anyone living in this shrinking world of ours, constantly rubbing shoulders with the 'other' (whoever that might be), would benefit from his gentle nudges, clear clarifications and urge to move forward with respect, hospitality and acceptance.”  "Even as someone with no intentions to enter the ministry or start a church, I found it a fascinating read, and one that bridges the gap between churches (a more conservative topic) and multiculturalism (a more liberal topic) without ruffling too many feathers.”  Possible discussion topics for Douglas J. Brouwer:  1)    At a time when people are worried about immigration and its impact  on American life, the church has an opportunity to reach beyond the  dominant (white) culture and find ways to include the lost, marginalized,  vulnerable, etc. 2)    What it was like living in a decidedly multicultural environment in one of  Europe's most important cities. 3)    Multiculturalism has been a failure in several western countries, but some  have had more success than others. Why is that?  Ascot Media Group is compliant with the can-spam act. Contact information: Ascot Media Group, Inc. Post Office Box 2394, Friendswood, TX 77549. Main: 281.333.3507. Fax: 800.854.2207. If you would prefer not to receive press releases and other information from Ascot Media Group, Incorporated, please respond with the word "remove” in the subject line. Please note the removal process can take up to 48 hours before it is fully in effect. If this is a second request for removal, please indicate this so we may research. In this instance, we may not have the correct email address on file, therefore please provide all possible email addresses that route directly or forward to you. Thank you.  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Desiring a conversation with college students
column3: Dear Editors,  A wonderful thing happened recently. While purchasing a copy of the 2017 Hymnal at a local branch church's Reading Room, I happened to glance down at the counter where I was standing, and saw a pamphlet, titled "*Engaging with the Monitor*". I quickly picked it up, and handed it to the librarian and asked her to include it with the Hymnal. Several minutes later, a woman came out of the study room, turned towards me and said, "You should have "*Step By Step*". It's great for college students". Wow! A miracle. How did she know I've been cherishing the idea of sharing Christian Science with college students? Later, I recalled what Mrs. Eddy said about "miracle". "The miracle of grace is no miracle to Love" (S&H, p. 494:15-16). So, no problem. This woman, whom I had never met, voiced my need, and with a warm, radiant smile, met it. After she left the Ladies Room, she came over to the counter and showed me "Step By Step". The librarian said it was the only copy for sale - one was in the Study Room. Without hesitation, I knew I would purchase the one for sale. What a joyous day it was at that Reading Room!  I found myself reminiscing afterwards, about an experience I had at Teacher's College, Columbia University. Last year, passing through the corridor on my way home, I noticed a group of hashtags posted on one side of the wall. I went closer and saw that these hashtags, "Arm Me With", were put up by students at the College. I quickly went across to the lounge nearby, dropped by briefcase, took out my cell phone, came back to the wall and took pictures. When I arrived home, I looked at them and saw that these students were asking for some of what I've seen as subjects in the Christian Science magazines. Then, I counted them and found I had photographed sixteen and remembered that that number is stated in the Manual. Mrs. Eddy used it as a requirement for starting a branch church (Manual, p. 72:26), and so there was no hesitation when the thought came to put each hashtag on 2-inch square paper, fold them twice, and put them in the big vase on the top level of a desk in the Reading Room. All I had to do now, was know that "Divine Love always has met and always will meet every human needs" (S&H, p. 494: 10-11).  Another college incident is keeping the desire for sharing Christian Science on college campuses. Happened in October, 2014, when John Tyler gave his Talk for my branch church. He spoke at Union Theological Seminary, directly across the street (Broadway) from Teacher's College. The title of his Talk, "Can we break the chains of materialism?", was an interesting title for college students. He used scenes and ideas from the film "Matrix" as a metaphor. Shortly after his talk, another branch church in New York City asked him to lecture for them. The title was 'Beyond the sixth sense". I took invites to a few colleges and in one Psychology Department, they immediately posted a flyer on their bulletin board. I thought, here is Christian Science, reaching out to college students. So wonderful! I'm asking myself, could the incidents mentioned above be a prelude to conversations with college student? I want to answer - Yes. If yes, then I must continue to know what Mrs. Eddy says in Science and Health: "Desire is prayer; and no loss can occur from trusting God with our desires, that they may be molded as exalted before they they form in words and in deeds" (p 1:11). I am looking forward to having conversation with college students.  Lovingly, Marie Lawrence

column2: Sept 8 - The Day Faith Leaders End Food Waste
column3: [cid:image001.png@01D554F0.E6C8A110]  Hello,  Re: Important information for all clergy in the Church of Christ, Scientist.  We are now only a few weeks from Food Waste Weekend - the global event for the entire faith community. Food Waste Weekend takes place September 6-8, 2019. I am asking for your help in sharing the attached information with every faith leader in your community.  Food Waste Weekend helps Christian (and other religions too) faith leaders prepare sermons on the important issue of ending food waste - important because reducing the waste of food reduces hunger, climate change and improves the environment.  This is an opportunity to speak about ending hunger rather than just feeding the hungry. The scriptures speak of food waste but most faith leaders have never actually discussed it.  Everything your ministers/priests/pastors will need, including an introduction to the issue of food waste, a sample sermon from the Christian perspective, sample bulletins for their newsletters, and even a game show for the Sunday school, are all available at FoodWasteWeekend.org<http://www.foodwasteweekend.org/christian>/Christian.  We also have material for individual Christians who either don't or can't go to church at FoodWasteWeekend.org/IAmChristian<http://www.foodwasteweekend.org/IAmChristian>.  Food Waste Weekend, endorsed by the National Council of Churches and other faith groups, was created 3 years ago by a nonprofit called AmpleHarvest.org which was founded by a CNN Hero and World Food Prize nominee. They work to help billions of pounds of excess fresh food get to more than 8,500 food pantries nationwide. Important:  If your church has a food pantry, make sure they sign up at AmpleHarvest.org/food-pantries<http://ampleharvest.org/food-pantries> to get fresh food that would have otherwise been lost to waste.  It's free!  Imagine imams talking about food waste on Friday, rabbis on Saturday, and ministers and priests on Sunday (along with other faith leaders). All with the goal of reducing the waste of food and hunger, and all on the same weekend. That's powerful!  Everything you need to get started is available at FoodWasteWeekend.org<http://www.foodwasteweekend.org/christian>/Christian. Note that if Sept 8 does not work for you, do it on another Sunday that works better.  All of the material remains available all year.  Please share this with all faith leaders in the Church of Christ, Scientist.  Additional material is available at FoodWasteWeekend.org/launch<http://www.foodwasteweekend.org/launcch>.    Kind Regards,  [cid:image002.jpg@01D554F0.E6C8A110]  [cid:image003.png@01D554F0.E6C8A110]

column2: RUSI Defence and Security Newsletter
column3: Good morning, ,  A delivery truck, a low hanging wire and a slow response from my ISP have conspired  to suspend this newsletter for several weeks. Now back in operation, we can  begin to look at a number of events around the globe that interest us.  The most visible situation is the continued incarceration of Canadians Michael  Kovrig and Michael Spavor by China. I note that this has not been recently  in the news and I fear that these two people may drop from public attention.  They have been in a Chinese prison for 249 days -- eight months, and there  doesn't appear to be much ink or air time given to it by Canadian news media.  The more jaded of us may say that this situation does not warrant the same  level of attention as it an old situation, however I believe that with each  passing day Canadians should be collectively demanding more assertive action  by our federal government and any provincial governments which may have any  influence.   Foreign Affairs Minister Chrystia Freeland's contact information is:  Telephone: 613-992-5234  Fax: 613-996-9607  Email: Chrystia.Freeland@parl.gc.ca Postal address:  House of Commons, Ottawa, Ontario Canada K1A 0A6     Maritime Executive writer Mark Hoskin writes that China has a historic claim  on the South China Sea, that it purports to be internal waters. I doubt if  this makes China's claim more valid, but it is an interesting perspective to  take.  Clive Hamilton (Conversation Canada) warns that Australia "must wake up to  the risks of researchers linked to China's military." The same warning can  me directed to Canadian universities and business as well. Let us not lose  sight of the content of Johathan Manthorpe's recent book,  (https://www.amazon.ca/Claws-Panda-Beijings-Influence-Intimidation/dp/177086539X).  Clive Hamilton also authored Silent Invasion: China's Influence in Australia.     Al Jazeera's writer Leonid Ragozin believes that the current Russian pro-democracy  movement may jeopardize Vladimir Putin's hold on government.     *         *          *  This newsletter is a free service of the Royal United Services Institute of  Nova Scotia, whose volunteers work hard to provide information about Canadian  defence and security affairs at no cost. Please pass this newsletter along  to anyone you feel may find it interesting. The articles, reports and commentaries  are selected based on the relative significance of the issues, and do not necessarily  reflect the policies, positions and opinions of the Royal United Services Institute  of Nova Scotia or the editor of this newsletter.  If you receive this newsletter directly from me, then you are already a subscriber.  If you receive it from another source and would like to have a free subscription,  please send me a brief email in reply to this newsletter.  If you would like to unsubscribe, please click here.  I welcome your comments and suggestions.  Best wishes for a good weekend.  Tim Dunne, CD Editor - D&S Newsletter  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to daily+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Tom Steyer Statement on Israel’s Decision to Bar Representatives Omar and Tlaib
column3: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Thursday, August 15, 2019 CONTACT: press@tomsteyer.com  Tom Steyer Statement on Israel’s Decision to Bar Representatives Omar and Tlaib  (SAN FRANCISCO, August 15, 2019) — Candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination Tom Steyer released the statement below following the decision by Israel to bar Democratic Representatives Ilhan Omar and Rashida Tlaib from entering the country after receiving pressure from Donald Trump.  “Donald Trump’s demand that Israel bar the entry of Representatives Omar and Tlaib as U.S. officials is an affront to core American ideals. His divisive demands of our allies are contrary to the principles of free speech and open, vigorous dialogue.  Mr. Trump’s attempt to isolate, vilify, and stigmatize members of Congress with whom he disagrees strikes at the central notion of our democracy and continues his attempt to separate and divide Americans along racial and religious lines, and further his bigoted and destructive agenda.”  Paid for by Tom Steyer 2020.  ###  About Tom:  Tom Steyer left his successful investing business seven years ago to give his own money and all his time and energy to fighting for progressive causes. He soon became one of the country’s leading forces in registering more young voters and voters of color, fighting climate change, working for racial justice, and helping secure better lives for all Americans. Tom has led a number of people-first, grassroots campaigns that have repeatedly defeated powerful special interests, beating big oil to win clean air laws, forcing big tobacco to pay its share of healthcare costs, and closing a billion-dollar corporate tax loophole to fund public schools.  Tom and his wife Kat Taylor were early signers of the Giving Pledge, a commitment to give the bulk of his fortune to good causes before they die. Tom’s dedication to doing what is right comes from his parents. His father was a lawyer who prosecuted Nazis at the Nuremberg Trials; his mother was a journalist and teacher who volunteered to teach prisoners in New York City jails. Tom says his parents showed him the power of having the courage to do the right thing. Their greatest lesson, he says, was that our actions speak louder than our words – what we do is more important than what we say.  ============================================================ Tom Steyer 2020 | P.O. Box 626 | San Francisco, CA 94104 | USA  Want to change how you receive these emails? You can ** update your preferences (https://tomsteyer.us3.list-manage.com/profile?u=19050e87bef316243d0543d86&id=74b0c16992&e=8cbfa1c52b) or ** unsubscribe from this list (https://tomsteyer.us3.list-manage.com/unsubscribe?u=19050e87bef316243d0543d86&id=74b0c16992&e=8cbfa1c52b&c=230caf2f63) .  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: NEWS: NY Probation Officers to Start Screening Youth for Suicide Risk
column3: Hi Stephanie?,  As you may have heard (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB375m3apwpj19XOVrGZZYs62uIEEcFJCpn322neO9hZNVmHjg2XDNIaQ2OSMDAfVZ38g6rIPXbNzohILn6CNdqoGjxKwBKtkK-2FCDysWGH3AT1Hx1lW5KstACCx3nktxPrX2xt6OTIBU-2BfLX7yrJQGAvA5v11aKm9LRY8-2Bkw-2FhqdR_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs19opZC2naQuJsxwHrTdEBRffAqPqHmmmAi2nWJSrXfiVozWQ0vhl-2Bw5Ue9pqj4t69Ulw1MKAtH6-2BNqR6x98RSkGhIrW28L7sxn3ITwhVW5SBZbmOmZxLAAseD9ESRwo6CGuz2gSnNA3qxB2SptJB4-2FI7O6vW-2BGFmNbFrxslygGBU8w5T3EjWZpvlh-2FVMaSc7YkNtFLhbY0ryoM-2Fc-2Fb2Nh8pnTEr6DW6xQaTcwFvYgQ9nwTaNTmZzn0niBK46c4Y2c-3D , probation departments across New York have started screening young offenders for risk of suicide as a way to connect them with mental health services. Research (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQBwqEYthmZRAEg5fQxZlFPZ62bWSTA0sPV6XeG6RDj5mKAeQmWvTbuodoD8cTMwmd7gdK3M3a9U4LUKd9V74xeW8-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs19opZC2naQuJsxwHrTdEBRffAqPqHmmmAi2nWJSrXfiVozWQ0vhl-2Bw5Ue9pqj4t69Ulw1MKAtH6-2BNqR6x98RSkGhIrW28L7sxn3ITwhVW5SLa0TjAEvGyYNX3M1LVBNekOMBtFjZmADTPFV-2FUFDHbSnBgaf1NznorUfhtc9hk-2FP42RHZ1RwY90cfQ-2Bd4O2w9EH37UubNy4ynmOOaDcAWy4lWoU6fj-2BKdKeEwNiePhKXEOjwL4-2B9ulyti5FEfnm-2BmM-3D has shown that suicide rates among young adults has been rising nationally; by implementing e-Connect, a program developed by Columbia University, officials hope that, by addressing the mental health needs of young offenders, it will reduce their chances of getting in trouble again in the future.  To weigh in on this news, I’d love to connect you with Psychiatrist, Dr. Neeraj Gandotra, MD, Chief Medical Officer at Delphi Behavioral Health Group (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=84Em28S1K9SvtzcUtu04EhKhZsSZb2-2B8Sm7TGYtcO9k-2Bj6fqXuLKCWKUFFZNL1gt_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs19opZC2naQuJsxwHrTdEBRffAqPqHmmmAi2nWJSrXfiVozWQ0vhl-2Bw5Ue9pqj4t69Ulw1MKAtH6-2BNqR6x98RSkGhIrW28L7sxn3ITwhVW5SBtS5ouZrzm-2FG3grxC9KNejSmJfBYcZfs05Ita0XNEg4Q-2BwtCYUe9QY3QLiLcCmBBVxu2RchfKQRm8H38s5bielWvJz9cdHY7OQDdxb-2FTIuzOMBSxW0gXQwGY2Xf9zOeFMycsWQTAIezIZ2goa62nB8-3D , who can speak to the following and more:   · The Possible Benefits of Implementing Programs Like e-Connect, Like Potentially Decreasing Rates of Recidivism · The Link Between Socioeconomic Status & Crime In Young Adults · How Socioeconomic Status Can Affect Mental Health in Adolescents · The Relationship Between Mental Health Care Access and Suicide  If you’re interested in connecting with a Delphi expert please let me know, and I’d be happy to coordinate.  Warmest,  Nandi  About Delphi Behavioral Health Group  Delphi Behavioral Health Group was created in 2016 with the goal of creating long-term recovery from addiction for individuals suffering from substance abuse and chemical dependence. Addiction and medical professionals use proven methods to heal individuals with the disease of addiction through a variety of detox and residential options designed to address the core issues behind the disease. With over 350 inpatient beds available currently, we are able to extend our services across the country, offering much-needed programs and services to those suffering and seeking help with their addictions. For more information visit www.delphihealthgroup.com (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=84Em28S1K9SvtzcUtu04EhKhZsSZb2-2B8Sm7TGYtcO9k-2Bj6fqXuLKCWKUFFZNL1gt_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs19opZC2naQuJsxwHrTdEBRffAqPqHmmmAi2nWJSrXfiVozWQ0vhl-2Bw5Ue9pqj4t69Ulw1MKAtH6-2BNqR6x98RSkGhIrW28L7sxn3ITwhVW5SNujxU9w-2BMc-2Fcs5aH0dK0QkAn4SGj6c-2F-2BMzSVoiTPkxP0R3hGuSsGS4zYTrIByHD3UEAMyIGBuShfonNsKbEVnK5kqEWHFqIB811MlG8am-2BuvbcqlH9z0E03CjtMwmiW0yUDvPchg8a9nF3Ls-2BzZgcQ-3D .  Nandi Millett  Account Executive  5W Public Relations  D (646) 763-8297  nmillett@5wpr.com (mailto:nmillett@5wpr.com)    ______________________  If you would rather not receive future communications from 5W PUBLIC RELATIONS, please go to https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=NBhTsVIXpTHrhf0NvhZzDd-2BIuOQfkp6rENL5eiggmwgjfXorV-2Bb730JV2hl5MB8DDGD70P4-2FMyrpjiijdaX1TEXTlJKJc4zqUJjOLRNTzy6uSNovHu8EUF5q5IiGvXBhlSc-2F2PdbzbaZfGkhSON7Iu9MyWIvAlkRNovLlq6RxjQ-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs19opZC2naQuJsxwHrTdEBRffAqPqHmmmAi2nWJSrXfiVozWQ0vhl-2Bw5Ue9pqj4t69Ulw1MKAtH6-2BNqR6x98RSkGhIrW28L7sxn3ITwhVW5SGLyRtnL9h6GSOR7wX4JaVrV5OJKuzgr8y8j2itUxWLwTqZ-2BKQ-2BMVLUjID9uMFf9oZhqWfJae1mXtyiR5qxELUQvWxm3RTphN8vkzcO0udJdNOL2MDO-2BOmWdyrRzaRjWlqMnLHlhuMJ0Cf4HX3sVVkc-3D  5W PUBLIC RELATIONS, 230 PARK AVENUE, 32ND FLOOR, New York, NY 10169 United States  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Campaign Update - 8/14/2019
column3: [https://nvlupin.blob.core.windows.net/images/van/NGP/NGP30/1/75695/images/ADM_JOE_LOGO.png]  Stephanie,  We've had a busy few days - and some great press coverage to go with it. Check out this great profile in Vox by Sean Collins ( here [https://www.vox.com/policy-and-politics/2019/8/13/20680106/joe-sestak-2020-presidential-campaign-policies-admiral-navy-specter-obama-medicare-public-option] ) and my op-ed on accountable leadership in the Daily Caller ( here [https://dailycaller.com/2019/08/13/sestak-campaign-accountability/] ).  We've got lots of events coming up over the coming week - you can see me speak here:  Wednesday, August 14th:   *     I    will    be    speaking    to    Johnston    Area    Democrats    at    6:15pm    at    the    Cozy    Café    (8385    Birchwood    Ct,    Johnston,    IA    50131).  *     Hear    me    speak    at    the    Hamilton    County    Democrats    Next    Generation    Picnic    at    7:30pm    (West    Twin    Park    Band    Shell,    Webster    City,    IA    50959).  Thursday, August 15th:   *     I    will    be    speaking    at    the    Fearless    Fighter    Women’s    Awards    Dinner    (doors    open    at    5pm,    event    starts    at    6pm,    speaking    at    6.40pm    –    Forté    Events    Center,    615    3rd    Street,    Des    Moines,    Iowa    50309).          Friday, August 16th:   *     I'll    be    holding    a    “Cup    of    Joe    on    the    Issues”    event    at    6pm    at    the    Corning    Public    Library,    603    9th    St,    Corning,    IA    50841.    We’ll    be    talking    about    how    our    agriculture    and    food    policy    must    take    care    of    family    farmers,    the    environment    and    health,    and    how    “Training    for    a    Lifetime”    is    the    prerequisite    for    a    labor    force    where    technology    changes    so    rapidly    (for    example,    wireless    GPS-guided    tractors—    what    happens    to    our    tractor    drivers?).    You    can    check    out    our    agriculture    and    food    policy    paper     here    [https://www.joesestak.com/issues/agriculture/]     ,    our    jobs    and    economic    policy    paper     here    [https://www.joesestak.com/issues/jobs-economic-protection/]     (including    “Training    for    a    Lifetime”),    and    RSVP    here:     https://www.facebook.com/events/1340545252764307/    [https://www.facebook.com/events/1340545252764307/]  Saturday, August 17th:   *     I    will    be    addressing    the    Iowa    Democratic    Party’s    Central    Committee    at    10am    at    Carpenter’s    Local    Union    Hall    106,    1555    1st    Ave    N,    Altoona,    IA    50009.  *     I    will    be    speaking    to    West    Des    Moines    Democrats    at    11am    (Tavern    Pizza    &    Pasta    Grill,    1755    50th    Ct,    West    Des    Moines,    Iowa    50266).  *     I    will    be    marching    in    the    Vinton    Parade    with    Benton    County    Democrats    at    2pm    at    the    Benton    County    Fairgrounds.  *     I    will    be    holding    a    town    hall    with    Fox    Brewing    in    West    Des    Moines    (Fox    Brewing,    103    S.    11th    Street    West    Des    Moines,    IA    50265)    from    6pm-8pm. Tuesday, August 20th:   *     I    will    be    speaking    to    the    Guthrie    County    Democrats    at    6pm    at    The    Owl’s    Nest,    124    West    Main    Street,    Panora,    IA    50216.  *     Hear    me    speak    to    Ankeny    Area    Democrats    at    6.30pm    at    the    Des    Moines    Area    Community    College,    Ankeny,    Iowa. column2: As tuition fee costs rise, U.S. students turn to online jobs
column3: Dear Stephanie,      Since 2012, the price of college in the United States has risen almost eight times quicker than wages. As a result, many students are choosing remote online work as a way to supplement their expenses.      Among popular online jobs such as freelance writing, translation, and app development, translation is one of the fastest-growing.     GoTranscript is a human-driven transcription provider who employs high-school and university students as part of its 20,000 strong team. As part of its corporate responsibility programme, it also offers scholarships to students across the world as a way of alleviating their living costs.      Please see the press release below.      To unsubscribe from this mailing list, click here.     Many thanks,  Eva        For immediate release      Transcription Jobs Growing in Popularity Amongst Students Seeking Remote Job Opportunities     Remote work becoming more attractive for students seeking more flexible working options to fit around their studies     August 14, 2019: In recent years, the cost of attending college in the United States has risen almost eight-times as fast as wages. As a result, many US-based students will struggle to make ends meet during their academic career.      As one way of offsetting the rise in living costs, around 50% of students undertake part-time work, and online jobs have been rising in popularity. These include app development, freelance writing, as well as translation.     One of the most popular forms of online work for students is transcription, which is the conversion of the spoken word to written text from audio or video files. Its popularity amongst students has been driven via its freelance nature, meaning students can fit it around their schedule by choosing to work as little or as much as they wish.     GoTranscript is a human-driven transcription service which employs both high-school and university students from across the globe as part of its 20,000-strong team of freelance transcribers. Earnings can reach up-to $1,250 per-month and employees are paid weekly.      As part of its corporate social responsibility (CSR) programme, the company also gives students the opportunity to earn a scholarship which pays $1,000 per-year during their course of study as a way of alleviating the increasing costs of living.      To apply, candidates must submit an essay of between 500 to 1000 words explaining how language has helped them as a vehicle for self-expression, as well as their personal and academic achievements. The application will then be assessed by a team of specialists.      Applications for the GoTranscript scholarship programme are open until 2022, and are accepted throughout the year.     In addition to its scholarship programme, GoTranscript offers academic transcription services as part of its commitment to students. Academic transcription is when a student records a lecture instead of taking notes. They then send it to the GoTranscript team to be written up, who will return the recording in as little as six hours.      According to GoTranscript CEO, Peter Trebek, the academic transcription service was created with the intention of allowing students to concentrate on the lecture and the ideas being conveyed.      “We understand that entering university can be a challenging time for many, and as a company, we hope to alleviate some of the difficulties that students face whether they be in relation to focusing on studies or increasing living costs,” he said. “As part of our corporate pledge, we are also very happy to give young people a chance to enter the job market.”      In addition to its scholarship programme, employment opportunities, and academic transcription services, GoTranscript also gives students a 20% discount on all of its services.        -      END -   ABOUT GO TRANSCRIPT   Founded in 2005, Go Transcript specialises in easy-to-use, quality-focused human-powered transcriptions delivered online around the world. For more information and a free trial, visit http://gotranscript.com/.        --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Amtrak Offers Additional Service and Service Modifications on Northeast Corridor to Improve Travel Experience
column3: FOR PLANNING PURPOSES ONLY  Aug. 15, 2019    Amtrak Offers Additional Service and Service Modifications on Northeast Corridor to Improve Travel Experience  Popular stations to receive more access to major markets in the Northeast and Virginia    NEW YORK- Beginning Monday, Aug. 19, Amtrak is altering the schedules for some of its Northeast Regional<https://www.amtrak.com/routes/northeast-regional-train.html> trains along the Northeast Corridor to better serve the populations along the East Coast with a more efficient travel experience. These changes will also offer additional access to and from urban areas in Virginia, New York, and Boston, ensuring that there is a seamless travel option to and from these locations.    Customers traveling in New Jersey to or from New Brunswick and Princeton Junction will now have the opportunity to travel via expanded Northeast Regional service, including additional trains throughout the day.    Weekday Southbound trains will now stop at New Brunswick at the following times (new service highlighted in blue): Train Number New Brunswick, NJ Princeton Junction, NJ 111 5:55 a.m. 6:18 a.m. 89 6:31 a.m. 6:45 a.m. 171 1:20 p.m. 1:35 p.m. 193 -- 6:13 p.m. 177 10:46 p.m. 11:01 p.m.    Weekday Northbound trains will now stop at New Brunswick and Princeton Junction at the following times: Train Number Princeton Junction, NJ New Brunswick, NJ 148 7:35 p.m. 7:49 p.m. 138 8:35 p.m. 8:49 p.m.    Weekends will also see additional trains stopping at these locations, though frequency is more limited. Schedules are subject to change. Up-to-date schedules are always available on Amtrak.com<http://www.amtrak.com/>.    Amtrak is committed to improving the customer experience and quality of travel on Amtrak train by focusing on several factors, including efficiency. These slight changes are meant to better serve areas with high ridership between major cities on the East Coast. Amtrak is committed to the customer experience and to continuous improvement and innovation throughout the entirety of its rail network, on its trains and at its stations.    For more information and ticket sales, customers may visit the Amtrak website at http://www.amtrak.com.    ###    CONTACT:  Amtrak Media Relations  Jason Abrams  212.630.6933  Jason.Abrams@Amtrak.com<mailto:Jason.Abrams@Amtrak.com>

column2: DeCordova Awards 20th Annual Rappaport Prize to Boston-based Visual Artist Daniela Rivera
column3: Good morning,  DeCordova Sculpture Park and Museum announces Boston-based visual artist Daniela Rivera as the 2019 recipient of its annual Rappaport Prize<https://decordova.org/rappaport-prize>. This year marks the twentieth anniversary of the prestigious award, which is presented to a contemporary artist with strong connections to New England and a proven record of achievement.  Please see press release below and attached for more details. Images of the artist and her artwork can be downloaded here<https://www.dropbox.com/sh/lgwfber9tjpiwkp/AADiGozPocWpqJEnmsOrPVnra?dl=0>. I'd be happy to coordinate interviews, as well.  __________________________________   DeCordova Awards 20th Annual Rappaport Prize to  Boston-based Visual Artist Daniela Rivera  Boston & Lincoln, MA -- August 14, 2019 – DeCordova Sculpture Park and Museum announces Boston-based visual artist Daniela Rivera as the 2019 recipient of its annual Rappaport Prize<https://decordova.org/rappaport-prize>. This year marks the twentieth anniversary of the prestigious award, which is presented to a contemporary artist with strong connections to New England and a proven record of achievement. Established in 2000, the Rappaport Prize is one of the most generous contemporary art awards of its kind. In 2010, the Prize was endowed in perpetuity by the Phyllis and Jerome Lyle Rappaport Foundation, assuring the ongoing support of contemporary art and artists in New England. In 2019, The Rappaport Foundation made an additional gift of $500,000 in order to increase the annual award amount from $25,000 to $35,000, beginning with this year’s Prize.  “I’m delighted for deCordova to award this year’s twentieth Rappaport Prize to Daniela Rivera,” says John B. Ravenal, The Trustees’ Vice President for Arts & Culture and Artistic Director at deCordova. “She has deep ties to New England and the Boston area, and I’ve long admired her sophisticated site-specific installations with their fascinating intersection of politics, history, and perception. I can’t think of a more deserving recipient.”  Daniela Rivera (born 1973 in Santiago, Chile) is a painter and installation artist, often working with immersive architectural forms on a monumental scale. Having grown up under the Pinochet dictatorship in Chile before moving to Boston in 2002, Rivera addresses the specific history of repression that she experienced firsthand while also drawing her viewers into larger global narratives of dislocation and turmoil.  “The Rappaport Prize is an incredible honor to receive. It is such an affirming recognition of my work over the last 17 years in Massachusetts,” says Rivera. “It gives value to my experience as a U.S. and New England resident, as well as to the choices I've made and the life circumstances I've faced here. This prize also opens up so many possibilities for my work, including an opera on immigration that I have been wanting to create and can now begin planning as a result.”  The public is invited to attend the annual Rappaport Prize Lecture with Daniela Rivera on Wednesday, October 23 at 6:30PM at deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum featuring a reception with and talk by the artist.  “We are thrilled to help celebrate deCordova’s twentieth anniversary of this important award,” adds Trustees President & CEO Barbara Erickson. “We look forward to welcoming our newly combined Trustees and deCordova members and supporters to join us for Daniela’s upcoming lecture this fall.”   Program Details  The Rappaport Prize Lecture with Daniela Rivera will be held on Wednesday, October 23, in the deCordova’s Dewey Gallery. The evening will begin with a reception and cash bar at 6PM followed by the artist’s talk at 6:30PM. Event is free; space is limited, and registration is required. Please reserve tickets at decordova.org/rappaport. DeCordova Sculpture Park and Museum is located at 51 Sandy Pond Road in Lincoln, MA.   About the Artist  Daniela Rivera received her BFA from the School of Fine Arts, Pontifica Universidad Católica de Chile, Santiago (1996) and her MFA from the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (2006), and was a fellow at Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, Maine (2006). She has been featured in solo exhibitions at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (2017); the Museo de Arte Contemporaneo, Santiago, Chile (2012); LaMontagne Gallery, Boston; and the Davis Museum, Wellesley, MA (2010). She has also been included in group exhibitions at the Institute of Contemporary Art/Boston (2010, 2011). Rivera is currently an Associate Professor of Art at Wellesley College, where she has taught since 2008.  Born the year of Augusto Pinochet’s seizure of power in Chile in 1973, Rivera’s coming-of-age was profoundly shaped by the ensuing years of military dictatorship, including the disappearance of activists and government critics. Her work is informed by the politics of repression that she experienced growing up in a dictatorship with a philosophy that the role of the artist today is to provide visibility to questions that may not yet have been asked or perhaps have been buried for a variety of reasons.  When Rivera moved to Boston in 2002, she turned from painting to sculpture and installation. Daniela Rivera: The Andes Inverted, a 2017–2018 exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, resulted from research that Rivera undertook into an evacuated mining town on the edge of Chile’s Chuquicamata copper mine. Removing a section of the museum’s pristine walls to expose the building’s inner structure and installing a monumental sculpture of the Andes, the exhibition was both productive and destructive, additive and subtractive, which is how Rivera describes the long-term social and ecological effects of mining. Exemplifying Rivera’s architectural installations, The Andes Inverted surrounded its viewers in such a way that its references to mining, labor, and dictatorship did not seem far away, but instead urgent and ever-present.   About the Rappaport Prize  Since its inception in 2000, the Rappaport Prize has been an investment in both individual artists and the broader art community. Founded and funded by the Phyllis and Jerome Lyle Rappaport Foundation, the Rappaport Prize follows the Foundation’s mission of promoting leadership in art, public policy, and medical research. Endowed at, and selected annually by, deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum, the Rappaport Prize supports artists while educating the public about developments in American contemporary art.  The prize celebrates the achievement and potential of an artist who has demonstrated significant creativity and vision, and encourages the recipient to continue a career of innovative art making. Together, deCordova and the Rappaport Foundation hope to create a community of accomplished artists whose careers have been enhanced by the recognition of the Rappaport Prize. In 2010, the Rappaport Foundation permanently endowed the prize, ensuring its continuation in perpetuity.  Each year deCordova invites art professionals from around the country—museum directors, curators, collectors, and artists—to submit nominations for the Prize based on set criteria. Each nominee is asked to meet the following criteria:    *   Produce artwork of exceptional quality   *   Demonstrate excellence and leadership in their chosen practice   *   Engage with aesthetic issues which have had a significant impact on contemporary art   *   Have a relationship to New England—whether they were born, educated, resided, or currently reside in the region.  All forms of media are considered. The Museum does not discriminate based on age, financial status, reputation, race, sexual orientation, or gender. After reviewing the nominations, as well as suggesting their own nominations, deCordova's curators and Director select the Prize winner.   Past Rappaport Prize Winners  2018 Titus Kaphar  2017 Sam Durant  2016 Barkley Hendricks  2015 Matt Saunders  2014 Liz Deschenes  2013 Ann Pibal  2012 Suara Welitoff  2011 Orly Genger  2010 Liza Johnson  2009 Dave Cole  2008 Ursula von Rydingsvard  2007 Maria Magdalena Campos-Pons  2006 Abelardo Morell  2005 Sarah Walker  2004 Debra Olin  2003 John Bisbee  2002 Lars-Erik Fisk  2001 Annee Spileos Scott  2000 Jennifer Hall  __________________________________  Best, Emily   [cid:61c70f09-8534-4040-8b88-004325f54a28] Emily Kowalski Marketing & Communications Consultant  The Trustees | deCordova Sculpture Park and Museum 51 Sandy Pond Road  |  Lincoln, MA 01773 ekowalski@thetrustees.org | 781.259.3616 (office)   Take a hike… we dare you!  The 2019 HIKE TRUSTEES Challenge is on.  thetrustees.org/hiketrustees<https://www.hiketrustees.org/>  <http://www.thetrustees.org/newhorizon/>

column2: Making HERE happen starts with YOU!
column3: Join us this month and support Adams County through United Way  DONATE VOLUNTEER United Way of Adams County announces plans to raise $1.1M for the 2019 #MakeHEREHappen campaign. Over 100 community leaders and volunteers filled the historic Washington Theater in downtown Quincy the evening of Thursday, August 1 to officially kickoff the 2019 #MakeHEREHappen campaign for United Way of Adams County. WATCH OUR 2019 CAMPAIGN VIDEO The Abbey will donate a portion of daily sales to United Way this Wednesday Dine-in or carry-out and support United Way in the process. Our 2019 restaurant days tour continues at The Abbey (18th & Spring) this Wednesday, August 14. Come join us for some great food all for a great cause. LEARN MORE Everyone is invited to attend. Come join us! Join United Way staff, volunteers, partner agencies, Board members, and advocates for our Business Before Hours event on Thursday, August 22 starting at 7:00am at the United Way office located at 936 Broadway, Suite F, in downtown Quincy. We'll have door prizes courtesy of Mercantile Bank and Blue Cross Blue Shield, food provided by County Market, and giveaways for everyone. A few of our valued partner agencies will also have materials on hand to help explain their mission and how they benefit the people of Adams County. United Way fights for the health, education and financial stability of every person in every community. We have one life. To live better, we must LIVE UNITED®. United Way of Adams County | 936 Broadway, Suite F, Quincy, IL 62301 Unsubscribe info@churchofchristscientist.org Update Profile | About Constant Contact Sent by info@unitedwayadamsco.org in collaboration with Try email marketing for free today!

column2: Steyer Calls Out Corporate Control of Politicians in Latest Ad
column3: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Wednesday, August 14, 2019 CONTACT: press@tomsteyer.com Steyer Calls Out Corporate Control of Politicians in Latest Ad In “Trust the People,” Steyer advocates for term limits and a national referendum— the first for a Democrat seeking the nomination  (SAN FRANCISCO, August 14, 2019) — Today, candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination Tom Steyer released his campaign’s latest ad “Trust the People (https://youtu.be/_9_bZ2Qmg88) ,” which highlights the stranglehold corporations have on Washington politicians. In the ad, Steyer advocates for term limits for Congress and a national referendum in order to put the power of our Democracy back in the hands of the American people.  The ad will run today through August 20 locally in Iowa, New Hampshire, South Carolina, and Nevada — the first four primary and caucus states.  “I trust the people, not the politicians in Washington, to fix this. As president, I’ll establish a national referendum to make your voice heard. And term limits for Congress, to ensure politicians focus more on you than getting re-elected,” Steyer said in the ad.  On Tuesday, August 13th, Steyer reached the donor requirement of 130,000 to make the September debate. He is now just one qualifying poll away from making it onto the September DNC debate stage in Houston, TX. In only a few weeks, Steyer has surpassed candidates who have been in the race much longer, in polling from Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada, and South Carolina. Steyer has been steadily gaining traction in early primary states, as indicated by three qualifying polls in Iowa and South Carolina, the most recent of which, from Monmouth University, had the candidate polling at 3%. Other non-DNC sanctioned polls show Steyer joining the top tier of Democratic contenders. On Monday, Morning Consult (https://morningconsult.com/2020-democratic-primary/) had Steyer polling at 6% in early states, tying for fourth place with Kamala Harris, Pete Buttigieg, and Cory Booker. A new Change Research Poll (https://tomsteyer.us3.list-manage.com/track/click?u=19050e87bef316243d0543d86&id=e214f1557f&e=bbde25d330) has Steyer at 3% in Nevada, besting Beto O’Rourke.  See below for the full script:  Our democracy is under attack. It’s been bought by corporations that put profits over people.  I’ve been taking on corporations and winning for 10 years.  I trust the people, not the politicians in Washington, to fix this.  As president, I’ll establish a national referendum to make your voice heard.  And term limits for Congress, to ensure politicians focus more on you than getting re-elected.  I’m Tom Steyer and I approve this message. Let’s make change happen.  Paid for by Tom Steyer 2020.  ###  About Tom:  Tom Steyer left his successful investing business seven years ago to give his own money and all his time and energy to fighting for progressive causes. He soon became one of the country’s leading forces in registering more young voters and voters of color, fighting climate change, working for racial justice, and helping secure better lives for all Americans. Tom has led a number of people-first, grassroots campaigns that have repeatedly defeated powerful special interests, beating big oil to win clean air laws, forcing big tobacco to pay its share of healthcare costs, and closing a billion-dollar corporate tax loophole to fund public schools.  Tom and his wife Kat Taylor were early signers of the Giving Pledge, a commitment to give the bulk of his fortune to good causes before they die. Tom’s dedication to doing what is right comes from his parents. His father was a lawyer who prosecuted Nazis at the Nuremberg Trials; his mother was a journalist and teacher who volunteered to teach prisoners in New York City jails. Tom says his parents showed him the power of having the courage to do the right thing. Their greatest lesson, he says, was that our actions speak louder than our words – what we do is more important than what we say.  ============================================================ Tom Steyer 2020 | P.O. Box 626 | San Francisco, CA 94104 | USA  Want to change how you receive these emails? column2: The Broken Promise of Colombia’s Peace Deal
column3: N Logo.jpgCONTACT: The Nation | press@thenation.com (mailto:press@thenation.com)  | 212-209-5426  Jonathan Levi (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB9bXhhUpyvbHnr1dhutjDPBDjJoJOLfHvmvUwFyNiDUSFQuoehs6iHD9Shqr-2FZ1jlA-3D-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs39wq8IFBlaqcpf81tbxF6zMX4bb-2Feyz-2Br1wLIrKILckdvcopqAEVnirrR7OBoZNIF3taFR0X8L-2BfahuX5BbWQ7COJDOSOCn-2BrMI8xonr3qpg0O3o2CgK0QaG0oWbuFNNQ-2BbrKaXe0-2Fgt4VnwVy88gaJ6fTZ30-2B9zJyf4D-2F-2FxrbJokLGOZt21CZ1FzDbQgg6yVAdYwC4k9SndmzklWBps83kzpQ7bdDMo-2FHQIWSryhDHEte8M8MC0MvFw-2BLzAtwUm8-3D and Marta Orrantia (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB9bXhhUpyvbHnr1dhutjDPD71ig95ujMrZtK4yWvk-2BaiIwZefK8IZ9R8qv877bZweg-3D-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs39wq8IFBlaqcpf81tbxF6zMX4bb-2Feyz-2Br1wLIrKILckdvcopqAEVnirrR7OBoZNIF3taFR0X8L-2BfahuX5BbWQ7COJDOSOCn-2BrMI8xonr3qpn5VBsqXTzWUXRPFsw5Ks8Ug-2BwqBirY8zV5lVudG6XPvJ2hZ6bgV5U2zvPDeYDis7UnVJJ7F4SOeuVsNf9SuA9zdIyQsyoDJnE-2F8aDbN7rw6kVUGFYNQmWH-2BOAHQdbzcxsC5IX33jvwiooI-2FOn4fbHI-3D | The Broken Promise of Colombia’s Peace Deal (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB9bXhhUpyvbHnr1dhutjDPBZHnPibLcmFTAUrj-2FMHONjFnW658LKfOlFvpYSmYyIrlHGSlO761EM-2FLPIOe-2BrSM8-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs39wq8IFBlaqcpf81tbxF6zMX4bb-2Feyz-2Br1wLIrKILckdvcopqAEVnirrR7OBoZNIF3taFR0X8L-2BfahuX5BbWQ7COJDOSOCn-2BrMI8xonr3qpgG1SPGv71V3YXf88kgvkW7w4x6X917WU9VGqQ4WOCh6EpSMCp9P5duZ05KZ4C65CGFJkfZfe1LqLrWbN3jDkMwnwFzqGyFD5BydMA9HVduHX8UCaBKEkvASST1R1GH492EfpbjisFppAZwZRqYzGEI-3D  Will President Ivan Duque reignite his country’s 50-year-long civil war?  Peace Now Cover.jpgLevi and Orrantia traveled to Caño Indio, Colombia, to teach former guerrillas how to write: giving the tools of writing to former paramilitaries, putting the power of storytelling into their hands. Over the course of their trip, they spoke with former members of the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia, or the FARC, and military commanders alike, to give readers a lay of the post-peace landscape.  As part of the 2016 peace treaty signed by the leaders of the FARC and the Colombian government, guerrillas traded their rifles and tents for a village of adobe and zinc and running water. These Espacios Territoriales de Capacitación y Reincorporación, or ETCRs, were constructed by the Colombian government to provide safe havens and to reintegrate, into the workforce and social life of their country during the transition from war to peace. Along with the Jurisdicción Especial Para la Paz, or JEP, an independent court set up to try war crimes like murder, kidnapping, and rape by all the actors in the conflict, including the army and the government, the ETCRs are at the heart of the peace plan of former Colombian president Juan Manuel Santos, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating an end to over 50 years of civil war.  But the current president, Iván Duque, has other ideas. Although the peace plan was the result of a negotiation between the Colombian government and an armed group that was never defeated, Duque says that the deal gave the FARC too much, including amnesty and positions in Congress. And now funding is poised to run out for dozens of ETCRs around the country.  Continue reading… (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB9bXhhUpyvbHnr1dhutjDPBZHnPibLcmFTAUrj-2FMHONjFnW658LKfOlFvpYSmYyIrlHGSlO761EM-2FLPIOe-2BrSM8-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs39wq8IFBlaqcpf81tbxF6zMX4bb-2Feyz-2Br1wLIrKILckdvcopqAEVnirrR7OBoZNIF3taFR0X8L-2BfahuX5BbWQ7COJDOSOCn-2BrMI8xonr3qplnqTL-2F7HI2ipt7BAbz95XYIr3GdNnv66AW7ujLrgfwnC3s9-2Bp9lVVU8d6n4sMWjcOw0SMDX8VtDV7NQTMq550zuPDlOqmPp7OBabSZwQRfPzxOX5dXVco29rHSFx-2FBCfw0cfVC-2Bo5dSW4mNCNeGaJg-3D  This story will appear on the cover of the August 26/September 2, 2019, edition of The Nation. Should you hit paywall, complimentary logins are available upon request for members of the media. column2: Williamson’s Weekend in Iowa; Check out her “David & Goliath” speech
column3: View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/marianne2020/update_8_12_19-250957?e=86750cd953) https://www.marianne2020.com/ FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE August 12, 2019 Patricia Ewing Communications Director Press@marianne2020.com (mailto:Press@marianne2020.com) 443-906-1495   Williamson’s Weekend in Iowa Check out her “David & Goliath” speech   Des Moines Register:Marianne Williamson calls on Register Soapbox crowd to 'rise up,' and say, 'Hell, no' (https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/elections/presidential/caucus/2019/08/09/marianne-williamson-election-2020-iowa-state-fair-soapbox-caucus/1881526001/)  - 8/9  National Review:Marianne Williamson Offers Priestly Wisdom for a Nation Adrift — Seriously (https://news.yahoo.com/marianne-williamson-offers-priestly-wisdom-103038883.html)  - 8/12  The Atlantic: Marianne Williamson Goes for the Gut (https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/08/marianne-williamson-iowa-state-fair/595921/)  - 8/11  Indian Country Today: Iowa's powwow trail had a campaign stop (https://newsmaven.io/indiancountrytoday/news/iowa-s-powwow-trail-had-a-campaign-stop-GSowHA4SjUy3zPbHWWNsAw/)  - 8/12  https://gallery.mailchimp.com/7d2c52ee9b55adf2cd969c713/images/53021a4f-1ee7-41fa-9f68-1ad97c6c948d.jpg  ------------------------------------------------------------  Transcript of Marianne Williamson's remarks in Clear Lake, Iowa August 10, 2019 (link to video) (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6hZI_0veerk)   DAVID AND GOLIATH Hello everyone. Thank you so much. What an honor to be here. Thank you, first place, to Democrats of Iowa. Thank you Pat and Chris, thank you.  I want to talk to you tonight about how we're going to beat Donald Trump. We're not going to beat him with a political argument. We're not going to meet him with an economic argument. I respect Tom Steyer, all of the things that he was saying. Tom said we're going to beat him with an economic argument. The economy will either be good or the economy will be bad. But even if the economy is good, and it's even going to be harder, or even if the economy is bad, I don't believe we're going to beat him with an economic argument. I don't even think we're going to meet him with a rational argument. We're going to meet him with a moral argument. That is how we're going to beat him.  And I'm going to tell you what that argument is, but first of all, I want to tell you why it works. I want to refer you to a story in the Bible of David and Goliath. Now, David and Goliath is obviously a biblical tale, but there have been many secular psychological books about the mythology of the story. Even the very well known writer Malcolm Gladwell wrote a book about David and Goliath.  David and Goliath In the story of David and Goliath, the greatest warriors of the Israelites were cowering, afraid. They were the greatest warriors that the nation of Israel had. And yet, Goliath was a giant. And so the warriors were afraid about the battle that was going to be happening the next morning.  Now, David was not a warrior. David was a shepherd. David was a musician. David was an artist. David took care of people and sheep. And he was there to tend to the warriors. He was there to provide them food. And seeing how afraid all of the warriors were, he said, "I'll do it." And they said, "You'll do it?" And he said, "Yes, send me." For those of you who know the Great Gospel tune, he said, "Yes, send me, I will do it."  Now, it's very interesting that king Saul, seeing that David was prepared to go into battle with Goliath, said, "Well, the least that I can do is give you my suit of armor." And David put it on for a moment and then he took it off. And he said, "If I'm going to do this, I have to do it my way."  And we know what happened. We know that Goliath was laughing. We know that all the giants were laughing at the thought that David could defeat them. But we know that David had a slingshot. Now, let's look at what David did with that slingshot. He hit Goliath in the one place where Goliath had no defense. And that is how we are going to defeat Donald Trump, in that one place where he has no defense. He has no conscience. He has no empathy. He has no ethics. He has no morals. And we're going to shoot him right in that place. And that is how we're going to do it.  Now, it has been said by quite a few Democrats that the president's policies are immoral, and I agree with that. But in every other area, that Democrats understand that it's not enough to just say what we're against. We also have to say what we're for. So on the moral argument, the same is true. We can't just say the president's policies are immoral, we have to stand for a moral politics. And that is why I'd like to present you the four pillars of my campaign, which I believe are the pillars of a moral politics.  Economy One has to do with economics, the same economics that most Democrats have, and that all progressive Democrats have. Forty years ago, we transitioned into an amoral economic capitalism, an amoral economic system, which posits that a corporation's fiduciary responsibility to its stockholders matters before and above any other moral or ethical concern and at the expense, even, of other stakeholders. So, as long as the stockholders got their money, that was all, theoretically, that the American Corporation was supposed to have to care about, even if it's at the expense of the workers. Even if it's at the expense of the community. Even if it's at the expense of the environment. And in a way, all Americans are stakeholders in what happens in corporate America.  That amoral economic system, as we well know, as every Democrat is clear about, has corrupted our government. It has corrupted our government because of the undue influence of money and it has hijacked America's value system. And that is why the politics of the Democrats have got to stand, not only for the economic argument but for the moral argument. And take a stand for justice, the moral obscenity of an economic system that does more to help the rich get richer and makes it harder for everybody else to even make it through the day.  That is a moral wrong. It is not only an economic injustice, injustice itself is moral. We want love. And where there is no justice, there is no love.  Now, the second pillar, that is why, of course, like every other Democrat, I want to repeal the 2017 tax cut. Eighty-three cents [on the dollar] given to the very richest among us and the very richest corporations. Why I want to put back in the middle-class tax cut. It's why I want to stop those subsidies. $26 billion to oil and gas in one year to the fossil fuel companies? Ladies and gentlemen, this is immoral. This is wrong. This is why we need to have the $15 an hour minimum wage, because it's immoral to make people work two and three jobs in the richest country in the world in order for them to even get a modest two-bedroom apartment.  That is why we must do all of the things that we know must be done in order to bring economic fairness to the people because it is immoral. An amoral economic system has, and always would have, immoral consequences. We stand on the moral argument.  Children Secondly, we have to look at our own house. And we have to stand for some things that, maybe, Democrats aren't always used to standing for. And that has to do with what is happening to America's children. We have millions of American children, and yes, they are here in Iowa too, who are chronically traumatized. We have millions of American children who go to school every single day in schools that don't even have the adequate school supplies with which to teach a child to read. If a child cannot learn to read by the age of eight, the chances of high school graduation are drastically diminished. The chances of incarceration are drastically increased.  Millions of these children are hungry, ladies and gentlemen. We have 43 million food-insecure people in this country. The Democrats should be saying, "We will end poverty." The Democrats should be saying, "We should end... We will end hunger in America. It is the moral thing to do."  We have elementary school students in the United States who are going to classrooms every day and asking the teacher, "Do you have food for me to eat?" We have millions of American children going to schools and classrooms so chronically traumatized by the violence in their homes and in their neighborhoods that psychologists tell us that they have PTSD that is no less severe than the PTSD of a returning veteran from Afghanistan and Iraq.  It's not enough that we say, "We don't like that you put children in cages." We have to say, "We will not allow, either, the children who are already here in this country to be chronically neglected the way we are.” We stand up for America's children. They have nothing to keep them safe.  Reparations Third of all, our politics is we will spend up for reconciling America with our past. It is a principle of transformation. Psychological, spiritual, moral. You cannot have the future that you want, whether you're a nation or an individual unless you're willing to clean up the past. And that is why the Democratic Party should stand for more than race-based policies. We should stand for genuine atonement. We should stand for reparations. We should stand for reparative justice, not only to the descendants of slaves but also reparative measures with the Meskwaki and other Indian tribes throughout this country.  And I'll say to this president, "Mr. President, the first thing I'm going to do when I get in that office is take down that picture of Andrew Jackson. It is an insult." He will have nothing to say.  War Profiteering And the fourth has to do with our national security. This man, for the sake of $350 billion in an arms sale to Saudi Arabia in a way that would make our grandparents roll over in their graves, ladies and gentlemen. We are providing for the sake of that $350 billion in arms sale. We are participating through aerial support in a genocidal war. In America, we're doing this. We are participating in the genocidal war that the Saudis are prosecuting the Yemenis. Tens of thousands of people have died, including children. Where are the Democrats, ladies and gentleman? That is immoral. We stand for the moral thing to do. We will bring moral leadership back.  Winning back the Soul of America And that's how we're going to beat him, because on all those things, he will have nothing he can say. And I believe that there are people all over this country who believe that the moral core of America... And by the way, this is not just Democrats, this is not just lefties. There are people who are conservative. There are people who are liberal. There are people from every group. We have to worry not only about the big supporters of Donald Trump. Donald Trump didn't win time just because of the people who passionately supported him. He won, also, because of the people who did not vote and the people who voted for Jill Stein.  If the president wins again... If the president wins again, it will not be just because of the people so excited about Donald Trump. If he wins again... If he were to win again, it would be because of too many people not voting, and too many people voted for a third party. Ladies and gentlemen, we must give people a reason to vote for us.  If all we talk about is how qualified we are... We were qualified last time, then we lost the election. We need to be real. We need to be deep. We need to be honest. We need to talk about the fact that America's involved in passive child neglect of millions of American children. We have to talk about the fact that we have allowed our moral leadership to completely be eroded. We have to talk about the fact that there's a deep psychic underbelly regarding race, regarding native Americans. We should not be afraid of the truth. Because let me tell you something ladies and gentlemen, when we speak with conscience and we speak with genuine moral principle, you come out every time a Democrat.  Traditionally, in this country, the right side of the political spectrum has traditionally focused on issues of private morality. Abortion and so forth. But traditionally, the left side of the political spectrum spoke about issues and public morality. Tax injustice, economic injustice is a moral issue. War and peace is a moral issue. Environmental degradation, destroying our planet, what it's doing to the food, what it's doing to the topsoil, what it's doing to the farmers, what it's doing to future generations. This is a moral issue. International relations, this is a moral issue.  Over the last four decades, however, the conversation in the Democratic party, unlike the Democratic party of my years, has become so orbitized, so over-secularized, so much about external things, but not about values. And no, it's not enough to come in now and say, "We're going to talk about values. We're going to talk about freedom. We're going to talk about values. We're going to talk about school." No, no, no, no, no. You got to do more than talk about it. Trust me, I've got a 35-year career on this. You got to act on it. And once the Democratic party does more than talking about it, because it seems to work in new focus groups, and instead puts forth some policies which has the moral spine, we'll do more than Donald Trump. We will win the soul of this country back.  ###  ============================================================ ** (https://twitter.com/marwilliamson) ** (https://www.facebook.com/williamsonmarianne/) ** (https://www.instagram.com/mariannewilliamson/) ** (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXAMXGAP0YnBxtc8brSSbjg) ** (https://www.marianne2020.com) Copyright © 2019 Marianne Williamson for President, All rights reserved.
