column2: Please forward to every parent and teacher you know…
column3: Fighting stigmas and advancing opportunities for and with people with disabilities  About RespectAbility | Solutions Center  Hello Stephanie,  I hope you are having a great summer. Personally, I just started a “stay-cation” to spend some summer days with our family. Speaking of family, I am hoping that you can share the piece below with all the parents of school aged children and teachers you know. Great teacher-parent relationships, open communications and high expectations are vital to enable students with disabilities to succeed.  On another note, the movie The Peanut Butter Falcon is opening on Friday. We featured this film at our national conference recently, showing a trailer along with a video greeting from the directors, and now it’s about to hit the theaters. It’s a fantastic film that stars Zack Gottsagen who has Down syndrome. He’s terrific and you will love the film! Don’t just take my word for it - it has a score of 96% on Rotten Tomatoes! Also, take a look at this fab piece from yesterday’s USA Today on disability employment. See HERE.  Best to you and yours! Respectfully, Jennifer Laszlo Mizrahi President, RespectAbility Tips for Parents of Children With Disabilities Who Want Them To Succeed in School By Jennifer Laszlo Mizrahi As someone with a disability myself, and who also knows what it means to parent a child with multiple disabilities, I’ve become an advocate for my children on so many fronts, including their education. After all, when it comes to disability and inclusion, despite good intentions, many schools don’t even know what they don’t know. Also, only 61% of students with disabilities get a high school degree — so it is up to people with disabilities, and their loved ones, to educate and advocate for disability inclusion and success. This is especially true when enabling children with disabilities to have full access to education. While today on average only 1-in-3 working age adults with a disability have a job, studies show that 70% of young people with disabilities can get jobs and careers. But we have to do our part. Here are some tips I’ve used in the past that may be helpful to you:  1. Know you are not alone. Fully 1-in-5 Americans has a disability. While parenting a child with differences feels lonely at times, seek out other families with similar experiences. Peers can offer good advice, and may become your new best friends. They reside in your local community and online. 2. Research which schools in your area have real experience and success working with children with disabilities. While all public schools are required to accommodate students with disabilities, some schools may have magnet programs specifically for your child’s educational needs. In other cases, you may want to resist when your school district wants to bus your child across town to a school for other kids with disabilities, when accommodations can be easily made at his or her neighborhood school.  Call your local disability groups to see what resources and leads they can offer. Ask other parents of children with disabilities about their experiences with different schools. Go online to look at the school’s website. Does it say they welcome and serve people with disabilities?  3. Write an “all about how to succeed with my child” letter. Yes, you should also prepare a file with your child’s Individualize Education Plan (IEP), including suggestions for success from any speech, physical, occupational, mental health or other therapists that works with your child. But don’t expect all teachers to be knowledgeable enough to understand some of the technical material. Your letter should be easy to read. Provide a toolkit for working with your child. Put things into simple language with bullets of information that the school needs to know to make your child’s experience safe and successful. Remember, as a parent, you have unique insights about your child that can help your child’s teacher understand his/her strengths and needs. Your candor, experience and advice will be much appreciated. Depending on the age of your child, you may want your child to help write the memo.  4. Request a meeting with your child’s teacher and team. Yes, everyone is busy. However, if you miss out on having a real substantive conversation, you may create a situation that turns your child off to school and learning. Additionally, it is not enough to meet with the school principal. You need to sit face-to-face with teacher who will be in the classroom with your child, as well as the school leaders who support that teacher. If appropriate, bring your child’s therapists. Depending on the age of your child, you may want to bring them to this meeting. Before the meeting, you should send your memo about your child to all the meeting participants. Bring copies of it to the meeting as well, and have your “elevator pitch” about your child ready to go. You may want to practice it in front of someone who can offer constructive criticism. It is important to get your points across quickly so they can ask questions. Teachers will really appreciate your efforts, resources and transparency. Once the teachers learn about your child, the school may want to put an extra aid in the classroom to support your child’s needs. Alternatively, they may want to match your child with a different teacher who is more experienced. If so, do your “elevator pitch” and Q&A with that teacher as well. The school may benefit from having your child’s occupational or physical therapist meet with them, or join the class for a day, to give the teacher some tips. 5. Ask the teacher and team about their preferred method of communication. Mutual respect and trust are important to all relationships. This includes the relationship you want to cultivate with your child’s teacher. That’s why it’s important to find out which method of communication suits them the best. Many prefer emails. 6. Be fully transparent with your child’s team. If your child has tantrums, be sure the staff understands what causes the tantrums, and how to prevent them. If your child needs notification before a transition, or has a tick or expression that they use to indicate he or she is anxious, the team needs to know, so they can best serve your child. This is not the time to worry about privacy - you need to focus on safety and success.  7. Be upbeat. Teachers want proactive parents. A positive relationship with your child’s teacher will help your child feel good about school. Before you hit “send,” look over emails, making sure they’re respectful of the teacher’s time and also of their efforts to help your child. It’s great for you to ask questions and make suggestions as long as your message conveys your trust that the teacher is performing her job ethically, responsibly and to the best of their ability. You want to be their partner. Remember that a teacher is a person first. Send thank you notes, volunteer, let them know when your child really enjoyed a particular lesson, and try to be considerate of their schedule; teachers have families too.  8. Share your enthusiasm for learning with your child. Talk with your child about they will be learning during the year, and why it is important to you. Let your child know that you have confidence in their ability to master the content, and that you believe it will be a positive part of their life. Reinforce the natural progression of the learning process that occurs over the school year. Learning skills take time and repetition. Encourage your child to be patient, attentive, and positive. 9. Slow down and take the time to do it right. Transitions are often difficult for children with disabilities. There will be a few bumps in the road. Your child will have a successful year at school in spite of difficulties. As we move into the first few weeks of school, stay calm and positive. Remember to take care of yourself. Know your limitations, and don’t be afraid to ask for help. Make sure your child has enough sleep, plenty of time to get up, eat breakfast, and get to school.  10. Familiarize yourself with the other professionals. Make an effort to find out who it is in the school who can be a resource for you and your child. Learn their roles and how best to access their help if you need them. This can include the principal, cleaning and kitchen crew, front office personnel and others who may work with kids with disabilities on a daily basis. 11. Reinforce your child’s ability to cope. Give your child a few strategies to manage a difficult situation on his or her own, but encourage your child to tell you or the teacher if problems persist. Maintain open lines of communication with the school.  12. Help your child make at least one real friend there. Arrange play dates. Try to arrange get-togethers with some of your child’s classmates during the first weeks of school to help your child establish positive social relationships with peers. Go to holiday events with other children and help facilitate actual friendships for your child. Parents of other children both with and without disabilities who are friends with your child can become your new best friends as well.  13. Listen to Your Child’s Feelings. When your child shows any anxiety about going back to school, the worst thing you can do is brush it off with a “don’t worry about it” response. Listen and be responsive to your own child and empower them to advocate for themselves as well. Show them your love. Sometimes you need to take a little step back in order to move forward.  14. Enjoy their childhood. It goes way too fast!  Read More  DON'T MISS THESE UPCOMING OPPORTUNITIES!  Education Resources on Disability Issues Ensuring children with disabilities receive the education and training they need to succeed is vitally important. Nationally, only 65 percent of students with disabilities graduate high school each year. Only seven percent of students with disabilities graduate college. On our solutions center website, you will find resources to teach students about disability and assist students with disabilities to succeed. summ  Learn More  Politics & Disability: The RespectAbility Report As the 2020 election cycle starts to heat up, check out The RespectAbility Report for nonpartisan political coverage with a focus on disability issues. Read fact-based updates and analysis including pieces about all of the 2020 presidential candidates’ disability policies. Launched in 2015, The RespectAbility Report neither rates nor endorses candidates.  Learn More  Applications Open For The National Leadership Program The National Leadership Program is ideal for people with and without disabilities who want to go into careers in public policy, advocacy, communications or nonprofit management while making a positive difference for people with disabilities. We have three cohorts of Fellows – fall, spring and summer. We are accepting applications for Fall 2019, so send in your application now!  Learn More  X  About RespectAbility  |  Solutions Center  RespectAbility  |  11333 Woodglen Drive, #102  |  Rockville, MD 20852  |  202-517-6272  (C) 2019 UNSUBSCRIBE   LEARN MORE   VOLUNTEER WITH US     -- To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Melissa Mohr / Oxford Comma
column3: Dear Ms. Mohr,      Thank you for your piece on the Oxford Comma.  I was in the medical field before my retirement and didn't do a lot of writing, but recently I have been doing more.  My own feeling was that a comma before the "and" in a series was more to my style and preference--although I was taught that it was incorrect-- and I arrived at my conclusion before your article informed me that there was such a thing as the "Oxford comma."  Now I'm happy to know that it exists, as it reinforces my "gut instinct," and that "it is the subject of fierce online arguments." (We obviously read different online items.)      I really enjoy your column and it is much more readable and "accessible" in the Monitor Weekly's new format. Gratefully, Kevin J. McCarthy Arroyo Grande, CA

column3: Hope you are doing great!   I sent you email and I never heard back from you. So, I wanted to follow up today to see if you have any question about RPO. column2: Learn how to build an Agile Learning Organization— from the Josh Bersin Academy
column3: Learn how to build an Agile Learning Organization— from the Josh Bersin Academy                                                                     [ img: josh bersin academy ]                                                                                                                              Hi Karen, We’re getting ready to launch our next five-week Program [ The Agile Learning Organization ] ( 1 ) —which kicks off on August 21st . As a member of the program, you’ll be challenged to think differently about learning across your organization. You’ll be coached by Josh Bersin, along with other global HR and business leaders, on new development approaches for reimagining the power and purpose of modern learning tools and strategies. The Program will help you answer these critical questions: What is the evolving strategic role of learning in our organizations? How is technology changing learning—for individuals, teams, and organizations? How is learning key to solving the organization’s current and most critical challenges? How can formal learning initiatives support informal day-to-day learning? How can we create programs that are learner-centered? What are the technology trends that will likely impact future purchasing decisions? How can we think of ourselves as “behavior change architects”? [ Explore The Agile Learning Organization ] ( 2 ) program to learn more about how you can design a learning culture built for the future. Ready to get started? [ Choose the membership plan ] ( 3 ) right for your organization. Happy learning! — The Josh Bersin Academy Team                                                                                         [ img: 2 ] Copyright © 2019 Josh Bersin Academy, All rights reserved.     [ Josh Bersin Academy ] ( 4 )                                             33 Irving Place, 5th floor • New York, NY 10003 • United States • [ Click here ] ( 5 ) to unsubscribe. column2: Story? Tips for Flying with Kids (Get Financial Compensation + More)
column3: Hi there,  Are you flying with the kids before summer's over? Please find tips below from AirHelp (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQByC20DNpdFjx1bbfX98U7RHiay96LRl2bKOjaqsApkwe_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs2RBuwOX2vN3zzYTcEFQw3pcsdx3OKcXE-2BWATPfG3lPyGykKebz41ll4AFiEBYRaMQZO-2FehY9gYmGqSE29y3LfghS6h5D9npZGTbC8jogmq6480zvsBnSKS9cc7N16AntEenYRIpNVQp-2FObszrz181-2FhEYMTkjbl5KqFS1qMWJcNoNmOqrTQXUnnML90CnHjMY9VEQXLpdJsBsnkM7QCXGMwAThqEo2HUccfSfva7mU34R-2BL1gNLvgwx-2FVlik5KNas-3D , so your family knows your rights when things go wrong at the airport.  Thank you!  Carinna Gano Senior Account Executive 5W Public Relations (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB-2FhHoucr4VmGv2zKx-2BARlJE-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs2RBuwOX2vN3zzYTcEFQw3pcsdx3OKcXE-2BWATPfG3lPyGykKebz41ll4AFiEBYRaMQZO-2FehY9gYmGqSE29y3LfghS6h5D9npZGTbC8jogmq66RfYPgTnrrRJVoatEt76uAr7fRQTUrugijFYlskZ94JWezvA5g-2B727wfXVq8ZIep2mDp-2FRnpmAaFR5n7vr6Q579gFwKMUVNlSyS9Fwvb4u4Py6KsSmJKpr8-2FKlKCW-2FrUbjMOldaAlIapdIhsZqy-2FrE-3D 646-843-1810  Traveling with Your Kids This Summer? Here’s What You Need to Know before Heading to the Airport  AirHelp (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQByC20DNpdFjx1bbfX98U7RHiay96LRl2bKOjaqsApkwe_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs2RBuwOX2vN3zzYTcEFQw3pcsdx3OKcXE-2BWATPfG3lPyGykKebz41ll4AFiEBYRaMQZO-2FehY9gYmGqSE29y3LfghS6h5D9npZGTbC8jogmq62YMsimOJ5UCv8RvWwJhKIsRBvUSW4Im5wGc3j5qfVdAM8ulIX-2BpmWSXJOjI0-2BOLBKPlNwScbXkH1nz1-2FiGg3jXmOFZaSLQgh18879eBgMTS01CkxaXlswWfaxHNBrRffPfc5nD4PbQw4fQGLgeTNPo-3D found 20% of flights are expected to experience disruptions this summer  If a disruption is eligible under European law EC 261, every family member is entitled to financial compensation - even infants   NEW YORK - This summer, 20% of passengers are expected to experience flight problems. Summer is a peak season for family travel due to long summer breaks for kids, and it is important for families to know that all travelers are eligible for compensation in the case of flight disruptions, regardless of age.   Airport and airline strikes, including the potential British Airways strikes, may increase this number even further. During peak family travel season, air passenger rights experts at AirHelp remind travelers that the European legislation EC 261 protects all air passengers, regardless of their age.  “Despite some airlines saying differently, infants suffer from disruptions too, so of course they should receive the same compensation as adults when they experience a long delay or cancellation. As families embark on the last of this summer’s vacations, AirHelp feels it is imperative to raise awareness of the fact that children also have rights,” says Johnny Quach, AirHelp’s Chief Product Officer. “We urge all parents to not let themselves be misled and to always remember to file a claim for children if a flight disruption happens.”  Your Rights When Things Go Wrong   There are many other details that AirHelp urges travelers to understand while traveling.  1. Your family is entitled to receive food and drinks. When you are stuck at the airport waiting for your flight, the airline must provide you – and your children! - with food and refreshments. Some airlines may offer vouchers or reimburse you for any meals and essentials that you purchase during the disruption, so make sure to keep all receipts. The laws say exactly when you should be entitled to this care — it all depends on the length of your flight delay.   2. Your family is entitled to free accommodation and airport transport. During lengthy delays or cancellations where overnight accommodation is necessary, the airline must provide you and your family free accommodation as well as free transport to and from the airport. They should put you in a hotel room or rooms that are large enough to accommodate your whole family.   3. Your child is entitled to the same amount of compensation as an adult. Even if your child’s plane ticket is only a fraction of the cost of that of an adult, he or she is still entitled to the full compensation amount. The amount of compensation that you receive is dependent on the distance of your flight, and the length of the delay — NOT the amount you paid for the ticket. This means if you are flying to the EU on an EU airline and experience a disruption eligible under EC 261, everyone in your family may be able to claim up to $700 in compensation.  4. When flying with kids, they are entitled to flight compensation too. One of the most important things to remember when you are flying with a small child is that your child is entitled to flight compensation in the event of a flight disruption.   The case is pretty straight forward for children ages two and older. You have to pay for their seats, so they are equally deserving of compensation when things go wrong.   But what about flying with a lap infant? Babies often travel on their parents' laps at a reduced infant fee. When flying with an infant aged 2 years and below, most airlines will charge a fee between 10% to 15% of the adult airfare, plus taxes and an extra fee for an infant seat belt.  For years, airlines have been refusing to compensate infants, arguing that because they don't occupy a seat, there is no compensation to pay. This changed in 2017, however, when AirHelp won a lawsuit against Thomas Cook Airlines, creating a legal breakthrough in the EU.   BONUS TIPS!  · You can fly with young infants — but the age allowed varies among airlines. One question that parents often ask is if there are any restrictions to flying with young infants. While there are airlines that allow newborns as young as two days old to fly, most airlines will only allow infants who are at least 14 days old to fly.    · Even infants need a passport. For international flights, infant passports are mandatory. Always check with the airline in question before purchasing a ticket for your baby, and make sure that you have enough time to procure valid identification for your child.  · Sitting together with your child during a flight. You might think its standard practice that adults sit together with their younger children during a flight, but there isn’t currently a law in Europe that mandates it. Though, in most cases, parents can sit with their children without any additional cost.   (If you are traveling with an infant and have assigned seats, you are usually given priority boarding to help make finding and settling into your seats as easy as possible. However, some low-cost airlines will insist that at least one adult pays for a reserved seat. Only then will they allow your child to sit beside you for free — otherwise you are subject to the same seating procedure as everyone else.)   · Baby food and milk are exempt from liquid restrictions. While liquids on airlines are often subject to restrictions, this does not apply to baby food and milk. If you are traveling with a child aged under 2 years, you are allowed to bring as much food as you need for your trip. This includes baby food, milk, fruit juice, and distilled water.    · You can bring car seats and strollers for your baby. You can bring car seats and strollers for your baby on the plane without having to pay anything extra. Strollers may be brought with you as far as the gate, where the flight crew will stow it for you before you are seated. They will return the stroller after you exit the plane. Car seats, on the other hand, can be brought on board and into the cabin. They are simply safer and more comfortable for your baby than having them sit in your lap during the whole flight. However, if you do bring a car seat, you will be required to buy a seat on the plane for your baby. This often means that you have to pay the full fare instead of the infant fee, as your child will be occupying an entire seat. Be sure to inform your airline beforehand that you are bringing a car seat with you to avoid any confusion.  About AirHelp - AirHelp is the world’s largest organization specializing in air passenger rights, helping travelers get compensation for delayed or canceled flights and in instances of denied boarding. The company also takes legal and political action to support the growth and enforcement of air passenger rights worldwide. AirHelp has aided more than 13 million people, is available in 35 countries and has more than 700 employees.    ______________________  If you would rather not receive future communications from 5W PUBLIC RELATIONS, please go to https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=NBhTsVIXpTHrhf0NvhZzDd-2BIuOQfkp6rENL5eiggmwgjfXorV-2Bb730JV2hl5MB8DqG2JiafCl0rxzAnqTh9uK8Hpg0WUM9oPbGMynvv2B1TJhs9NqnO62ojxDQpB-2BQQaDorNpGR9tq0Igg5bfPU1C1uuPfC-2BKWIGWpQmRq9hfdE-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs2RBuwOX2vN3zzYTcEFQw3pcsdx3OKcXE-2BWATPfG3lPyGykKebz41ll4AFiEBYRaMQZO-2FehY9gYmGqSE29y3LfghS6h5D9npZGTbC8jogmq6-2BYMiK1HLV5ULYiV5qqnOnOXuoUv7g3-2F8kJwgutTFXe05SqFk3BkuiUihdhovF2hrjU6b0H5MbjAK3hCO7y1dCIWH4CyGkODTZYhkRBU7eDOP3RVTtX-2F4f0ABAme9ko3jIzdoA0Ak3B7N5-2Fs9M4TfKg-3D  5W PUBLIC RELATIONS, 230 PARK AVENUE, 32ND FLOOR, New York, NY 10169 United States  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: How Following Her Heart Led One Woman to the Mafia
column3: Hi Stephanie,  I’d like to introduce you to Barbara Roberts, MD (http://www.thedoctorbroad.com/) .  There are people in the know who say that Dr. Roberts caused the downfall of the New England Mafia. She did this, not by killing someone, or sending someone to jail, but by keeping undisputed mob boss, Raymond Patriarca, alive, and out of prison, for about a year too long, thanks to her testimony that he was too ill to stand trial. During this time, Dr. Roberts also became the secret lover of the alleged #3 man in the New England Mafia, Louis "Baby Shanks" Manocchio. Along the way, she battled politics, career stereotypes, her children’s fathers, the Family Court system, public scrutiny, and even her own conscience at times. And she made it through all, proving to be the hero of her own unique journey. Her story was even featured on an episode of the Crimetown podcast (https://www.crimetownshow.com/transcripts/2017/3/5/chapter-eleven-the-doctor-broad) .  Dr. Roberts will be releasing her memoir, The Doctor Broad: A Mafia Love Story (http://www.thedoctorbroad.com./)  [Heliotrope Books, September 3, 2019].  “I wrote this book because the world has changed so much from the world I grew up in,” Dr. Roberts recently told NBC 10’s Coffee Break with Frank and Friends Facebook TV Show (https://www.facebook.com/nbc10/videos/433692753951930/) . “I wanted particularly younger women to be able to learn some lessons in how to survive adversity, how to overcome heartbreak and how to come out in the end and really have led a full and happy life.” She adds, “I don't regret following my heart instead of my head. I became a much stronger person as a result of my relationship with Louis. I also became a better doctor by taking care of Raymond, in that I put his welfare ahead of my own, even though I paid a price.”  Can I send you a copy for review or schedule an interview with Dr. Roberts?  More information on Dr. Roberts is below.  Thanks in advance for your consideration and feedback.  Have a great day,  Joelle  ------  About Barbara Hudson Roberts, MD  Barbara Hudson Roberts, MD was the first female adult cardiologist in the state of Rhode Island. She graduated from Barnard College and Case Western Reserve School of Medicine. As a resident at Yale New Haven Hospital, she became active in the pro-choice movement, before Roe v Wade made abortion legal. She helped found the Women’s National Abortion Action Coalition (WONAAC) and was the keynote speaker at the first national pro-choice demonstration in Washington DC in November 1971. She also was active in the anti-Vietnam War movement, and spoke at the last mass anti-war demonstration on the grounds of the Washington Monument on the day of Nixon’s inauguration in 1973. She was a staff physician at Planned Parenthood for many years, and continues on the voluntary faculty at Brown where she is an Associate Clinical Professor of Medicine.  Connect with Barbara Roberts on Facebook @barbara.roberts.14 (https://www.facebook.com/barbara.roberts.14) , Instagram @bhrdoc (https://www.instagram.com/bhrdoc/?hl=en) , Twitter @BarbaraHRoberts (https://twitter.com/BarbaraHRoberts)  and visit www.thedoctorbroad.com (http://www.thedoctorbroad.com/) .  The Doctor Broad: A Mafia Love Story releases on September 3, 2019.  You are receiving this email because your information is listed in the Vocus (https://www.cision.com/us/)  Media Database. By opting out through the link below, you will no longer receive emails about Barbara H. column2: MEDIA AVAIL: St. Jude Child Sleep Expert Shares Ways to Keep Your Kids Sleep Hygiene on Schedule as They Go Back-to-School
column3: StJude Logo v2.png  FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: Tuesday, August 13, 2019  CONTACT: Katy Hobgood Ray, Katy.Hobgood@STJUDE.ORG (mailto:marvin.stockwell@stjude.org) , Office | 901-568-9869 Cell | 901-568-9869   ** MEDIA AVIAL: Sleep Better as Back-to-School Starts ------------------------------------------------------------  **   ------------------------------------------------------------  ** St. Jude Child Sleep Expert Shares Ways to Keep Your Kids Sleep Hygiene on Schedule as They Go Back-to-School ------------------------------------------------------------  **   ------------------------------------------------------------  ** With Kids’ Returning Back to School Schedules, Healthy Sleep Patterns are Vital to Overall Physical, Mental and Emotional Health ------------------------------------------------------------  **   ------------------------------------------------------------  MEMPHIS, TENNESSEE – As America’s school children prepare to return to school after their summer break, pediatric sleep experts at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital are reminding people of the importance of sleep hygiene during this time of year to maintain their children’s overall physical, mental and emotional health and have released a list of sleep recommendations for parents.   Dr. Valerie Crabtree, Chief of Psychosocial Services at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital, (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB-2Fic46wAvoSRQPKHsnf9rMHPXZ0NA9pXXTExTADfvHDW6kOXOfOdDy-2FH69tWM1IyLcVj-2B8-2Fdcj4kC4vu0u4MVnM-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs3pLSZqc0y-2BOjmQcgYRv5dEjGAy11E9MU4onbMFNezUkFh0ML9G1pwa7uVdKx2PgMgB94OG2yCSpKQcCcHYlCXPRLSMXs77usvEE8HWI13IfHU5G-2FW01PhV0WlMHvNGfmwyhCQzdGN7Gj-2FnUnQWeOIAOYTq6r6b6XYSsoaKhEh-2BO-2Bpde8vAkiH6idsiuZUJF25mkEX73jsIOQd6FTVHBvf-2BmIZA7m59BBKXkQWDKRAlatdVwZbCM5gVHbbhYx8fyfM-3D a lead researcher on sleep and fatigue in children and a national leader in the effort to advocate for school districts to follow the Center for Disease Control (CDC) and American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) guidelines on school start times, authored a list of ten ways parents can continue a healthy sleep hygiene for their children as they go back-to-school.    “In children and teenagers, poor or insufficient sleep is related to poorer organization, poorer memory, and academic difficulties.  And, frighteningly, chronic sleepiness is correlated to higher rates of depression and increased rates of automobile accidents,” said Dr. Valerie Crabtree, Chief of Psychosocial Services at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital.  ** 10 Key Ways to Maintain Children’s Sleep Hygiene as ------------------------------------------------------------  ** Back-to-School Approaches: ------------------------------------------------------------  1. Keep a consistent sleep schedule – Make sure you wake your kids up and have them go to bed at about the same time on weeknights and weekend nights. Bedtime and wake time should not differ from day to day by more than an hour.  1. Establish a regular, relaxing bedtime routine - Make the 30 minutes before bed wind-down time. Do not let children watch TV, use electronic devices (smartphones, tablets, etc.) or exercise during this time. Instead, have them do something relaxing, such as playing with quiet toys, reading a book or listening to soothing music.  1. Create an environment in your kid’s room that is only for sleeping – This means kids’ bedrooms should be comfortable, quiet and dark. Make sure the bedroom is not too warm (keep it 74 degrees or lower), as warm temperatures interfere with sleep. It is also very important to get all technology, including TVs, cell phones, computers, tablets, etc., out of the bedroom.  1. Make sure your family is eating regular meals throughout the day and having a light snack before bed - Do not feed kids large amounts of sugar or chocolate just before bedtime.  1. Children should exercise regularly, but not too close to bedtime - The best time for kids to exercise is first thing in the morning or in the late afternoon. If possible, they should avoid strenuous physical exertion right before bedtime.  1. Let kids enjoy the sunshine in the morning – Make sure your kids have the opportunity to spend time outside every day, especially in the morning, as exposure to sunlight or bright light helps keep the body’s internal clock on track.  1. Limit your children’s light exposure in the evening, especially after dinner - Dim overhead lights and reduce the brightness of screens.  1. Avoid putting kids down for naps if they are having trouble falling asleep at bedtime - Naps are developmentally appropriate in young children, and some adolescents benefit from a short afternoon nap (30-45 minutes right after school).  1. Do not allow kids to consume caffeine after 4 p.m. or within six hours of bedtime - Caffeine has a half-life of four to six hours, which means it should still be helping you stay awake four to six hours after you take it. Consuming caffeine too close to bedtime makes it hard to fall asleep.  1. Be mindful of teenager’s unique sleep clock - If you have teenagers in the house, keep in mind that most teens’ biology will not allow them to fall asleep any earlier than 10:30 or 11 p.m. And teens need eight-10 hours of sleep per night.  As a lead researcher on sleep and fatigue in children undergoing cancer treatment and brain tumor survivors, sleep is a major focus for Dr. Crabtree’s work.  She recently spoke at a TedX Talk (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB0EkkfiL-2FRh3yUZZj7WJzVbzG1v5ueAvGcDEjg7CeL-2F59hvzTzSL8uhD2E4tlSXEM44wyOK31sANMCn2hX0jYbPISm1zelKDUMLVJOa7GMhN7DURJiLP3-2Bz0XpButLwlkQ-3D-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs3pLSZqc0y-2BOjmQcgYRv5dEjGAy11E9MU4onbMFNezUkFh0ML9G1pwa7uVdKx2PgMgB94OG2yCSpKQcCcHYlCXPRLSMXs77usvEE8HWI13IfPok-2BmvURg5u8ayv5SM251iNek2YJ76RTch3IWxswKZQNZYEzd3-2Bhns4bc7-2Flb6HQORSgeryCtEDpQ-2B6EKOMBfOArpj6R31AO-2B5U5q6l7aDBR5fDkr9kTRE9LC2Ai6-2Fc5HDy-2FlZYA2UPbslmHbrDCvM-3D in Memphis on how very early school start times are detrimental to the health of teenagers as well as those around them.  Dr. Crabtree underscores how insufficient sleep in kids and adults contributes to making us overweight, sick and sluggish.   “Sleep is the third pillar of health, along with nutrition and movement, that keeps us healthy and balanced. Yet, as a society, we really undervalue the role of sleep in keeping us healthy,” said Dr. Crabtree.  ** To Speak with Dr. Crabtree, please contact Katy Hobgood Ray at 901-595-0564     ------------------------------------------------------------  # # #  St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital (https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=G62jSYfZdO-2F12d8lSllQB8pBJtPqkpprIHSF-2F92IAYo-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs3pLSZqc0y-2BOjmQcgYRv5dEjGAy11E9MU4onbMFNezUkFh0ML9G1pwa7uVdKx2PgMgB94OG2yCSpKQcCcHYlCXPRLSMXs77usvEE8HWI13IfNFTk7XXtMwIOuVIL6r-2B4PHCP-2FGjli-2Fep08oO07twswTsLlDZ8jn3fYMsPyqMqRgho0FKtPK38J2bk1hq6kSYzEybvl-2BL1VYwyr4RfLJkApcH5SPZoeMyEpojxAG8DKbBaRfSF58joFaHJySCTa2Z2c-3D is leading the way the world understands, treats and cures childhood cancer and other life-threatening diseases. It is the only National Cancer Institute-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center devoted solely to children. St. Jude is ranked the No. 1 pediatric cancer hospital by U.S. News & World Report. Treatments developed at St. Jude have helped push the overall childhood cancer survival rate from 20 percent to 80 percent since the hospital opened more than 50 years ago. St. Jude freely shares the breakthroughs it makes, and every child saved at St. Jude means doctors and scientists worldwide can use that knowledge to save thousands more children. Families never receive a bill from St. Jude for treatment, travel, housing and food — because all a family should worry about is helping their child live. To learn more, visit stjude.org or follow St. Jude on social media at @stjuderesearch.    ______________________  If you would rather not receive future communications from St. Jude Children's Research Hosptial, please go to https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=L-2FFwtmwdVCnghCTvKJrs3Wf9Qd-2FbV258L9drW7v0yv5HdJfjZDJ4ZkMt4dCLmk9TcoBXY2UcgsCY2tLUvqbHRg1jZwNuvAgGhDFyCgRE-2F88rpB4tQymRr3mCiZjDzt61VWqamlZT4ErWom7pRvMuUMl3Mq6j9vs8-2FYE6bG1VLQK4xUfp5n0dnH33FyNWvjRW_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs3pLSZqc0y-2BOjmQcgYRv5dEjGAy11E9MU4onbMFNezUkFh0ML9G1pwa7uVdKx2PgMgB94OG2yCSpKQcCcHYlCXPRLSMXs77usvEE8HWI13IfEi0e0KSsrkmpJI5xVfMfcnoSL8h2HoSON0rnnSUpbok3ThdN9Bh3wisdij9yp9u5fdj295WYd-2FgAERr6UJRsiScqX9SvQQ1xxryJK-2Bp-2FOKiHQM-2BTWGmmg5MDH8EPI2Z5wCRGfa6-2FXtkmJIgjYomq4k-3D  St. Jude Children's Research Hosptial, 262 Danny Thomas Place, Memphis, TN 38105 United States  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: PLACEMENT
column3: Dear Sir/ Madam,  I am Mr. Daniel Alfonso Gomez, an Independent Non-Executive Director &  Audit Committee here in Spain. During audit of Bank Accounts, Safe  Deposit Facilities and other Financial Instrument, I discovered a  concealed vault (Safe Deposit Box) with large amount of funds domiciled  in a storage facility as revealed by the deposit dossiers.    The said vault was unveiled to belongs to one of our Foreign Deceased  Customer(Mr. Wang Jian), The Co-founder and Co-chairman of HNA Group, a  Chinese conglomerate with significant real estate ownerships across the  U.S., died in an accident while on a business trip in France.  Please go through this  link:https://observer.com/2018/07/wang-jian-hna-founder-dies-tragic-fall/  I am writing to request your placement as Heir/Beneficiary to the  deceased (Mr. Wang Jian) Foreign Business Partner. Meanwhile, prior my  correspondence with you, all efforts to contact the next of kin or  family relation to the deceased person has proved abortive.  As a seasoned professional I have done extensive research, thus can  guarantee the application process as viable with no risk involved. Upon  your consideration and acceptance of this offer with kin interest;  detailed information will be forwarded swiftly. Following my position; I  can guarantee successful transmission of the funds to you only if we can  secure a good deal.  Cordially, Mr. Daniel Alfonso Gomez  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Abstract Submissions Open I 2020 National Sustainability Conference
column3: ABSTRACT SUBMISSIONS OPEN - NATIONAL SUSTAINABILITY CONFERENCE  The Program Advisory Committee for the 2020 National Sustainability Conference are currently seeking abstract submissions for the fourth annual conference.  This year's National Sustainability Conference was the best yet, with record numbers and a suite of outstanding speakers. Join us for 2020 and share your sustainability insight with a range of fellow industry professionals.  Follow these three easy steps to get involved:  1. Choose your presentation type: - Oral presentation - Panel presentation - Workshop presentation - Tabletop presentation - Poster presentation  2. Choose your topic: - Good health and wellbeing - Clean water and sanitation - Affordable and clean energy - Industry, innovation and infrastructure - Sustainable cities and communities - Responsible production and consumption - Climate action - Life below the water - Life on land - Technology solutions - Impact investing - International trends, research and findings - Policy update - Open topic  3. Prepare and submit - 300-word presentation overview - 100-word biography - 3 key learnings points from your presentation  For more information on the 2020 abstract topics or conference, please visit the website here.  If you are interested in registering for the conference at the early bird rate, please click here.  Kind regards,  Shae.  Shae Mengersen, Conference Secretariat 2020 National Sustainability Conference 27 – 28 April 2020 l The Calile Hotel Brisbane Email: secretariat@sustainability.asn.au    --------------------------------------------------------------------------- This email was sent by Conference Secretariat, Phone: 07 5502 2068 to service@csmonitor.com  Edit my Profile: https://www.vision6.com.au/forms/e/KdPWMQM4wjhviNtTHrL7iE_JdyY8zptvYQV5u6n3VMQ/74173/8398571.html  Preferences Link: https://www.vision6.com.au/forms/p/KdPWMQM4wjhviNtTHrL7iE_JdyY8zptvYQV5u6n3VMQ/74173/8398571.html  Unsubscribe: https://www.vision6.com.au/forms/u/KdPWMQM4wjhviNtTHrL7iE_JdyY8zptvYQV5u6n3VMQ/74173/8398571.html ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

column2: Hudson in the News: New Podcast Featuring J.D. Vance, Shifting Political Ideologies, Hong Kong, and More
column3: Hudson Deciphers Shifts in American Political Ideologies  The United States is in the midst of a dramatic political shift in conventional views on national security, economics, technology, and the role of government. Hudson scholars are examining these changing norms as topics like American nationalism and the convergence of domestic and foreign policy take center stage in national debates.  In particular, Hudson launched a new podcast last week, The Realignment, which will explore these changes. The podcast is hosted by two of our new Media Fellows  Saagar Enjeti [https://www.hudson.org/experts/1278-saagar-enjeti] and  Marshall Kosloff [https://www.hudson.org/experts/1279-marshall-kosloff].  In the latest episode, they interview conservative thinker and author George Will. The episode covers a wide range of issues including the role government should have in regulating technological advances, how to deal with the threat of a rising China, and whether the United States should pursue a manufacturing-based national economic strategy to confront it.  Click here to listen to the episode [https://www.hudson.org/research/15243-the-realignment-ep-2-george-will].  If you missed it,  Episode 1 [https://www.hudson.org/research/15229-the-realignment-ep-1-j-d-vance] featured a discussion with best-selling author of Hillbilly Elegy, J.D. Vance.  “I think that we should consider China as our nation should have considered Nazi Germany in the mid-1930's. Only we should recognize that it’s more dangerous because it’s larger and it’s more ambitious. I think that Hitler wanted to rule Europe. I think that China wants to rule over a much larger share of the world—maybe the entire world.” – J.D. Vance ( The Realignment, Episode 1 [https://www.hudson.org/research/15229-the-realignment-ep-1-j-d-vance])  Click the buttons below to listen and subscribe to The Realignment.  Christopher DeMuth  interviewed [https://www.hudson.org/research/15192-national-conservatism-a-conversation-with-national-security-adviser-john-bolton] National Security Adviser John Bolton at the Edmund Burke Foundation’s “National Conservatism Conference" in July.  DeMuth followed up with an Op-Ed considering the role of the nation-state in American society in the  Wall Street Journal [https://www.hudson.org/research/15197-america-s-nationalist-awakening], writing:  The American nation-state is rich, powerful and less constrained than any other, yet it is much more constrained than we have led ourselves to believe. Thinking of ourselves as a nation-state is, as Peter Thiel has observed, a means of unromantic self-knowledge. National conservatism, by directing our attention to our nation as it is—warts, wonders and all—is a means of reminding ourselves of our dependence on one another in the here and now, and of facing up to the constraints that are the sources of productive freedom.  Hudson Highlights  Rebeccah Heinrichs debated former DHS Sec. Jeh Johnson at the  Oxford Union [https://www.hudson.org/research/15242-is-trump-s-foreign-policy-preferable-to-obama-s-foreign-policy], arguing that Trump’s foreign policy is preferable to Obama’s.  John Lee assesses how China's coercion in Hong Kong has caused more problems than solutions for the Chinese Communist Party in  The Australian [https://www.hudson.org/research/15228-china-squirms-in-global-spotlight-on-hong-kong].  Mike Watson considers the risks associated with the foreign policy proposals from Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren in the  National Review [https://www.hudson.org/research/15214-why-the-middle-east-policies-favored-by-sanders-and-warren-would-be-counterproductive].  Nina Shea explores how Iraq's proposed legal changes would allow mullahs to sit as judges, unraveling religious freedom efforts in the country in  RealClear Politics [https://www.hudson.org/research/15216-is-iraq-set-to-follow-iran-and-curb-religious-freedom].  Rob Spalding argues for permanent tariffs on China in order to ensure American manufacturers remain in the U.S. in  The Hill [https://www.hudson.org/research/15225-bring-back-america-democracy-and-freedom-make-china-tariffs-permanent].  Hudson co-founder Max Singer considers how the U.S. and Israel can achieve victory in the Israel-Palestine conflict for the  Begin-Sadat Center for Strategic Studies [https://www.hudson.org/research/15241-an-israeli-victory-is-necessary-if-peace-is-to-be-achieved].  Commentary  U.S.-China Trade Talks  Michael Pillsbury discusses the current round of U.S.-China trade talks in an  interview on Bloomberg’s Balance of Power [https://www.hudson.org/research/15218-the-current-state-of-the-u-s-china-trade-talks].  In  an interview with Shannon Bream on Fox News [https://www.hudson.org/research/15237-consumers-may-start-to-feel-pinch-during-next-phase-of-trump-trade-war-with-china], Pillsbury considers warning signs from experts who say if the President keeps up the pressure in his trade war with China, that the country could be in a recession in three quarters.  Rob Spalding discusses how trade tensions between China and the U.S. illuminate growing tensions between two rival superpowers in  Asia Times [https://www.asiatimes.com/2019/08/article/a-battle-for-supremacy-between-china-and-the-us/]:  Early in June, Robert Spalding, a retired Air Force general who is now a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, but who was a central figure in the development of Trump’s national security strategy, gave an illuminating newspaper interview.  Asked why the US is in a trade war with China, Spalding replied: “It’s really not about trade. It’s really about what kind of world we want to live in. When you look at everything, the full scope of everything that China does, it mixes its own brand of expansive influence into its economics. And so, it’s not only the goods that we receive here, it’s the principles too.”  Spalding went on to say that what is at stake in the contest with China is American freedoms and the values on which the country was founded. More than that, the influence of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) on global affairs undermines the values that have been built into international institutions under US leadership.  Spalding’s thoughts are echoed throughout the Trump administration and even more widely in the US. The dream that economic development in the People’s Republic of China would make Beijing into a reliable “stakeholder,” and foster political reform, achieved its zenith when, backed by former President Bill Clinton, China joined the World Trade Organization on December 11, 2001.  Spalding also provides perspective on Huawei, the trade war with China, and National Security in the U.S. in  an interview with Squawk Box on CNBC [https://www.hudson.org/research/15238-the-chinese-are-not-prepared-to-make-a-trade-deal].  U.S.-Iran Conflict  Mike Doran considers Trump’s strategy with Iran in  Politico [https://www.politico.com/story/2019/07/30/trump-iran-nuclear-waivers-1441065]:  Yet even some who have pushed to end the waivers acknowledge that doing so poses a real risk of military escalation. “The administration fears that if it cancels the waivers and invokes snapback, it risks escalating the military confrontation,” said Michael Doran, who penned an essay in June arguing for ending the waivers, which was circulated widely in the administration.  But, Doran said, “The question is this: Is it better for the US to start a negotiation when Iran's nuclear program is legitimate in the eyes of international law and enjoying international partnerships with Europe, Russia and China? Or is it better to start when the program is illegitimate and has no partners? The latter is obviously preferable.”  John Lee discusses why the U.S. requests help from Australia to protect tankers in Iran in  an interview on The Drum with Kathryn Robinson [https://www.abc.net.au/news/2019-08-05/the-drum-monday-august-5/11385576].  Seth Cropsey examines how Iran’s actions in the Middle East are impacting U.S.-Israel strategic priorities in  The Hill [https://www.hudson.org/research/15232-iran-s-grand-strategy-gulf-crisis-keeps-us-from-helping-israel-in-a-two-front-war]:  Continued harassment of international shipping presents the U.S. with a difficult challenge: keeping open the strategically vital choke point of the Strait of Hormuz as well as denying Iran its larger goal of regional dominance. Iran’s challenge to shipping in the Gulf seeks the near-term objective of sanctions relief. But its extensive arming of Hezbollah and leverage in Syria aim at subduing Israel and consolidating Iran’s position as regional hegemon.  Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty Withdrawal  In an interview on  Fox Business [https://www.hudson.org/research/15227-china-unlikely-to-make-nuclear-pact-with-us], Rebeccah Heinrichs discusses the U.S. and Russia withdrawal from the INF Treaty.  Masashi Murano considers the strategic implications of the U.S.’s withdrawal from the INF Treaty in  RealClear Defense [https://www.hudson.org/research/15213-ensuring-indo-pacific-security-post-inf]:  The strategic environment is critical for the successful deployment of U.S. defenses. The Chinese People’s Liberation Army (PLA) Rocket Force is asymmetric compared to the U.S-Japan alliance and can take advantage of the strategic depth to ensure the survivability of many TELs. Japan and the United States have only five to six major operational air bases in the western Pacific. A strategically reasonable option is to deploy robust and adequate land-based missiles in the Southwestern island chain, including Okinawa. However, political tension over U.S. military bases in Japan jeopardizes U.S.-Japan cooperation, and China could easily divide public opinion through information warfare. These measures must be carried out after diligent diplomacy with allies.  Given these political factors, regardless of the ground-based system, the most efficient and reliable approach is to expand the role of the Japanese Self-Defense Forces’ (JSDF) offensive and defensive capabilities, seamlessly combining them with U.S. conventional and nuclear capabilities.  Great Power Competition  Nadia Schadlow discusses great power competition in  The Atlantic [https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2019/08/what-genesis-great-power-competition/595405/]:  The theme of great-power competition “was there from the beginning” of the process of developing the NSS, Schadlow, now a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, told me. The decision to make it central to the administration’s strategic vision won the support of the president, senior National Security Council officials, and leaders at the top national-security agencies.  “From my personal experience, [Trump] did not push back against the frame” of great-power competition, said Schadlow, who briefed the president on the NSS, when I asked whether he resisted given his desire to cultivate good relations with Russia. “While I think overall he wants to keep lines of cooperation open with all these leaders, he is realistic about the nature of their national interests.” (While the Trump administration has taken a number of tough stands against Russia, from  expelling [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-administration-expels-60-russian-officers-shuts-seattle-consulate-in-response-to-attack-on-former-spy-in-britain/2018/03/26/8ada3d8e-30f0-11e8-8bdd-cdb33a5eef83_story.html?utm_term=.946b986ae272] Russian intelligence officers to  approving [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/josh-rogin/wp/2017/12/20/trump-administration-approves-lethal-arms-sales-to-ukraine/?utm_term=.33964a56c42a] the sale of lethal defensive weapons to Ukraine, critics would argue that Trump has gone out of his way to mollify Putin.)  …  Still, Schadlow noted that there is now more “bipartisan consensus for the necessary adjustments [in U.S.-China relations] than people think,” and that “it’s going to be hard to go back.”  In Case You Missed It  Event:  Ensuring U.S. Technological Superiority: An Update from Under Secretary Michael D. Griffin [https://www.hudson.org/events/1712-ensuring-u-s-technological-superiority-an-update-from-under-secretary-michael-d-griffin82019]  Transcript:  Combating Transnational Crime in the Americas: A Conversation with U.S. Sen. John Cornyn [https://www.hudson.org/research/15204-transcript-combating-transnational-crime-in-the-americas-a-conversation-with-u-s-sen-john-cornyn]  Event:  Countering Emerging Economic Threats [https://www.hudson.org/events/1711-countering-emerging-economic-threats82019]  Transcript:  Dialogues on American Foreign Policy and World Affairs: A Conversation with U.S. Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse [https://www.hudson.org/research/15210-transcript-dialogues-on-american-foreign-policy-and-world-affairs-a-conversation-with-u-s-sen-sheldon-whitehouse]  Defense & Aerospace Report Interview:  Patrick Cronin discusses the US-China trade war, Beijing & Hong Kong protests, and Seoul-Tokyo tensions [https://www.hudson.org/research/15235-us-china-trade-war-beijing-hong-kong-protests-seoul-tokyo-tensions]  Event:  Prospects and Challenges for an Emerging New India [https://www.hudson.org/events/1713-prospects-and-challenges-for-an-emerging-new-india82019]  Bloomberg Radio Interview:  Brendan Brown discusses monetary policy and the political pressures on the Fed [https://www.hudson.org/research/15223-two-year-fed-rate-is-more-important-than-spot-rate]  Scholarship  Hudson's Rebeccah Heinrichs and Brandi Jackson dispel myths surrounding the land-based leg of the nuclear triad in a new report,  Modernizing the La [https://www.hudson.org/research/15212-modernizing-the-land-based-leg-of-the-nuclear-triad-myths-and-facts] nd-Based Leg of the Nuclear Triad: Myths and Facts [https://www.hudson.org/research/15212-modernizing-the-land-based-leg-of-the-nuclear-triad-myths-and-facts]. column2: Why it's good to have an acidic vagina
column3: Stephanie??,  Most people think of acid in the body as bad (like in your esophagus). However, in the vagina acid is good-and a good pH in the vagina is in the 3.8-4.5 range. A pH anywhere in the basic range is bad. What keeps the vagina acidic?"Good guy" bacteria, known as lactobacilli, are responsible for making an acidic environment.   Lakeisha Richardson, MD, OB/GYN is available to discuss what dictates the amount of lactobacilli in the vagina, how to tell if your vaginal pH is thrown off, and ways to support healthy a healthy vaginal environment.   Let me know if you'd like to speak with Dr. Richardson.  Thanks,  Lindsay  Lindsay Gross  646.964.4446  lindsay@gcomworks.com     ______________________  If you would rather not receive future communications from Global Communication Works, please go to https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=JI3XGwl6BvjKk-2FipdOLyJRqWBmlRgMQWinaiZ-2BLdpTdLppdtFJkbzPlQbksQElRPywxtm2A4agRgmy7Eh9JNnF6z16kId9iH5AEEHfpFsV4uxegzrxMIfArRkdylQm-2Bu1hf8Vp4YJ9RfohK3b698jWCUXcTD5QxIlLWvWbDovceLyVFR5DEuvJNiDuGITCYt_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs3l3SEcNPtunJZdbD-2FHCJ4zhduFUesdJxf-2BOd8LrNTuZOseObMM4j-2FeCNkmEhRAi7DZXYWcHfOg5iH9ntNLbxrUZ9qmkPOSmaGCoOWXQxxdiBl-2BefH4ROZtFeIUzn9oAymre1FkNK21eIyysGfX4T8CPz93ZTI1CHQdOafKP03nVSezzBWeS-2BQXMhjbMIbqe8Dbj85o5Q9P95GOI-2BLkymgurccvkb-2FreC-2Fu0dcKV-2Fankxtm2OyqLgFo5jZ8h1nEk0U-3D  Global Communication Works, 261 Madison Avenue, New York City, NY 10016 United States  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: New Study: Massachusetts Ranks No. 17 in Robocall Complaints as Epidemic Rises
column3: Stephanie - Robocall scams are a growing epidemic and a new study shows Massachusetts ranks No. 17 among states with 119,103 robocall complaints filed in 2018.    In April 2019, there were 3.5 billion telemarketing and robocalls made to mobile phones in America. As A.I. technology expands, robocalls are expected to keep rising.  While some businesses use robocalls for legitimate purposes, an astounding 43% of all robocalls are scams.    SocialCatfish.com<https://socialcatfish.com/> today released a comprehensive study on The Rising Robocall Epidemic in America<https://socialcatfish.com/blog/how-to-stop-robocalls/#10> using the latest data from the Federal Trade Commission and Federal Communications Commission.    Here are key findings from the study:      *   5 States with the Most Robocall Complaints: California (747,829), Florida (427,404), Texas (402,316), New York (348,615) and Illinois (252,935).   *   Robocalls By Category: Scams (43.31%), Alerts and Reminders (23.49%), Payment Reminders (19.89%) and Telemarketing (13.31%).   *   Best Call-Blocking Apps: There was a 495% increase in the number of available call-blocking apps between October 2016 and March 2018 including RoboKiller, Nomorobo and Truecaller.   *   Most Common Scams: Are calls purported to be from the IRS, health insurance companies and foreign consulates.  A new scam claiming to be from the Chinese consulate has cost more than $40 million in total or $164,000 per victim.    Here are 5 practical tips to avoid being a victim of a robocall scam:      1.  Register your number with the Do Not Call List   2.  Do not respond to questions that can be answered with “yes” from unknown numbers   3.  Set up a password for your mobile voicemail to avoid being hacked   4.  Download robocall blocking apps   5.  If you receive robocalls take action and file a complaint with the FCC<https://consumercomplaints.fcc.gov/hc/en-us/articles/115002234203-Unwanted-Calls>.    Please let us know if you have any questions or need more information.    Thanks,  Haley  Haley Helms RN Public Relations Account Executive haley@rnpublicrelationsgroup.com  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: The Trump Administration Just Took an Important Step for Religious Freedom
column3: The government won't be able to coerce organizations into abandoning principle...  View this email in your browser (https://mailchi.mp/caapusa/bill-owens-of-caap-215485?e=f4925dc692) https://secure.anedot.com/coalition-of-african-american-pastors-usa/dream-derailed-sponsors?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] Share (http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) http://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+Trump+Administration+Just+Took+an+Important+Step+for+Religious+Freedom:&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485 Tweet (http://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+Trump+Administration+Just+Took+an+Important+Step+for+Religious+Freedom:&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485) http://us6.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=92112f469785e1152be1993c1&id=3d6869ff27&e=f4925dc692 Forward to a Friend (http://us6.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=92112f469785e1152be1993c1&id=3d6869ff27&e=f4925dc692)   ** The Trump Administration Just Took an Important Step for Religious Freedom ------------------------------------------------------------ Dear Partner,  It wasn't long ago when I was writing to warn you about the trend toward using government to bully Christians into discarding their values.  I wasn't just referring to wedding cakes. Organizations that worked with state and federal governments were at risk of losing that opportunity unless they toed the line on social issues. There was little room for freedom of conscience or the tenets of your faith if they clashed with the prevailing administration's views of sexual morality, same-sex marriage, abortion, or gender.  Depending on who held power, it was easy to imagine a situation where Christian organizations would not be permitted to work with the government unless they shed their beliefs. Because that was out of the question, the result was an anti-faith bias in federal contracting.  Fortunately, we now have an administration that protects religious freedom.  President Trump has already issued an executive order regarding respect for religious freedom and conscience. Now, his administration is expanding those protections. The Department of Labor’s Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs (OFCCP) has issued a new proposed rule clarifying that religious organizations that contract with the federal government are protected. They may make business and employment decisions consistent with their beliefs without fear of sanction.  You can read the proposed rule here (https://s3.amazonaws.com/public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2019-17472.pdf?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) . Note how it references some of the recent Supreme Court decisions protecting religious freedom and states that the government's role should be, "to protect religious exercise - and not to impede it." It also instructs federal agencies to construe the rule broadly, giving the highest level of protection to religious freedom.  In CAAP's press release (https://caapusa.org/2019/08/press-release-caap-praises-trump-administration-for-protecting-religious-freedom/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) on the rule, we praised the Trump administration for keeping the promise to protect freedom of religion. Too many organizations were concerned that the federal government would try to coerce them into abandoning their principles, and the administration took action to fix that. As I said in the release:  "Finally, people of faith have an assurance that they are not being pushed out of the public square and that their beliefs will be respected. Freedom of religion is the real civil rights battle of our time, and it’s good to see President Trump defend it."  Of course, we still need to wait for the rule to become final. And we need to recognize that a future president could undo it. That's why it's important to keep working to elect politicians that recognize the importance of religious liberty.  This rule is an important step towards protecting Christianity in the public square, but there's still more work to be done. Fortunately, CAAP is ready to keep fighting for our rights!  For faith, family and freedom, Rev. Bill Owens  P.S. Your prayers and financial support will help us put this country on the right path. Please help us as we strengthen our grassroots network and work to educate and inspire pastors, community leaders, and politicians to defend our Christian rights. Donate to CAAP today!  (https://causes.anedot.com/caap-email-appeal?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID])  The Coalition of African American Pastors, [aka] The Coalition for American Action and Principles, is a grass roots movement of Christians who believe in traditional family values in American public life.  We believe in protecting the lives of the unborn, and defending the sacred institution of marriage. CAAP does not endorse, support, or oppose any candidate for political office. Any mention of public figures herein is purely for discussion and educational purposes and should not be interpreted as a statement of electoral support or opposition.  *The Coalition of African American Pastors is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.  Your donations to The Coalition of African American Pastors may be tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.  No goods or services were received in exchange for any contributions.  You should consult a tax advisor regarding any tax deductions.  CAAP does not endorse any politician or political campaign. Make a Donation to CAAP! (https://causes.anedot.com/caap-email-appeal?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] Share (http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) http://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+Trump+Administration+Just+Took+an+Important+Step+for+Religious+Freedom:&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485 Tweet (http://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=The+Trump+Administration+Just+Took+an+Important+Step+for+Religious+Freedom:&mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] https%3A%2F%2Fmailchi.mp%2Fcaapusa%2Fbill-owens-of-caap-215485) http://us6.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=92112f469785e1152be1993c1&id=3d6869ff27&e=f4925dc692 Forward to a Friend (http://us6.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=92112f469785e1152be1993c1&id=3d6869ff27&e=f4925dc692) http://caapusa.org/membership/rise/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] Rise is CAAP's exclusive grassroots network, uniting people of every race, creed, culture, and background. You donâ€™t need to be a Pastor. You donâ€™t need to be African American. All you need in order to join RISE is a desire to help us create a new movement for faith, family, and justice. Join RISE! (http://caapusa.org/membership/rise/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) http://caapusa.org/membership/caap-clergy-membership/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] Men and women of faith working together to promote and protect the values we hold dear. We welcome clergy (bishops, pastors, ministers, evangelists, every member of the clergy) from any race to join our movement to protect and defend faith and family! CAAP Clergy Membership (http://caapusa.org/membership/caap-clergy-membership/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) http://caapusa.org/caap-womens-ministry/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID] The CAAP Womenâ€™s Ministry is composed of women of faith and conviction, working together to support and serve women. We welcome women of all races to join our womenâ€™s ministry to unify and give voice to religious, social, cultural, moral and public policy issues of our day. Join the CAAP Women's Ministry! (http://caapusa.org/membership/caap-womens-ministry-membership/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID])  ============================================================ Send all donations and correspondence to: CAAP-West Business Office 2654 W. Horizon Ridge Pkwy Suite B5-139 Henderson, NV 89052 ** (http://www.twitter.com/?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) ** (http://www.facebook.com?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) ** (http://mailchimp.com?mc_cid=3d6869ff27&mc_eid=[UNIQID]) Copyright © 2019 newsletter@caapusa.org, All rights reserved.  You are receiving this e-mail because you were recommended as someone who might be interested in working with our organization.  Our mailing address is: newsletter@caapusa.org 2654 West Horizon Ridge Parkway, Suite B5-139 Henderson, NV 89052 USA Want to change how you receive these emails? You can ** update your preferences (https://caapusa.us6.list-manage.com/profile?u=92112f469785e1152be1993c1&id=928bd2ec88&e=f4925dc692) or ** unsubscribe from this list (https://caapusa.us6.list-manage.com/unsubscribe?u=92112f469785e1152be1993c1&id=928bd2ec88&e=f4925dc692&c=3d6869ff27)

column2: Expert Available: Psychologist Talks Back to School Anxiety - for Students and Parents
column3: Hi Stephanie,  If you are planning any stories on back to school anxiety or worry for both students and parents, I'd love to have you consider interviewing Dr. Scott Symington (https://drsymington.com/) , author of Freedom from Anxious Thoughts and Feelings: A Two-Step Mindfulness Approach for Moving Beyond Fear and Worry (https://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Anxious-Thoughts-Feelings-Mindfulness/dp/1684032326) . He is a licensed clinical psychologist dedicated to helping adults and families overcome worry and anxiety, negative moods, addictive behaviors, and other conditions stealing people’s joy and freedom. A regular expert source, You can see him in action on Good Morning LaLa Land (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zEYEFjvq_QM) and Finding Your Frequency (https://www.voiceamerica.com/episode/116225/uncover-yourself-with-dr-scott-symington) and in Thrive Global (https://thriveglobal.com/authors/scott-symington/) and Forbes (https://www.forbes.com/sites/nomanazish/2019/05/30/how-to-de-stress-in-5-minutes-or-less-according-to-a-navy-seal/#763738853046) among others.  Topics Dr. Symington would love to work with you on:  · His recommend C.A.R. approach to help combat any anxiety about starting a new school year · From kindergarten through high school, tips to help students of any age who are worrying about going back to school · How to create a home structure and rituals at the beginning of the new school year that support what you know is good and healthy for your student · How parents can make sure not to manifest any worry or anxiety about back to school on to their child · Breathing techniques and a two-step mindfulness approach that parents and students can to do (together or separately) to help with any anxiety, stress or worry  I look forward to hearing from you and hope to put you in touch with Dr. Symington soon.  Thanks!  Erin  ______________________ If you would rather not receive future communications from Smith Publicity, please go to http://tcismith.pr-optout.com/OptOut.aspx?519228x41213x218486x1x5080076x24000x6&Email=customerservice%40csmonitor.com. column2: New book / family theme: SHAMED AND ASSAULTED FOR THEIR LOVE, INTERRACIAL COUPLE FLEES AN UNFORGIVING CULTURE
column3: Stephanie? -  I thought you might be interested in checking out a complimentary review copy of this new memoir, which features a deep examination of family structures and how they impact children from two different cultures who ultimately fall in love. It's all true, and turns scary, tearful and fun.  Let me know if I can send you a copy or put you in touch with the author!:  SHAMED AND ASSAULTED FOR THEIR LOVE, INTERRACIAL COUPLE FLEES AN UNFORGIVING CULTURE  In New Memoir, Two People Shunned and Damaged by Society Must Fight Astounding Odds to Stay Together  Kirkus Reviews Praises Stealing Cinderella: How I Became an International Fugitive For Love (October 2019) as “Engrossing and Poignant”   A recent college grad who grew up the unwelcome only child of his parents' failed marriage, Mark Diehl went to South Korea with $20 in his pocket to teach English to adults in the city of Taegu, unschooled in the nuances of adapting respectfully to a foreign culture.   There he met Jennifer, the unwanted second daughter of a controlling and powerful Korean family.  Bonding deeply over similar childhood traumas, Mark and Jennifer transcended cultural divides and fell in love.  But cultural divides were not all they had to transcend.  In his new memoir Stealing Cinderella: How I Became an International Fugitive For Love, award-winning dystopian novelist Mark Diehl brings us the astounding story of what he endured to be with the woman he loves.  As their love blossomed, Mark learned that interracial romance, particularly with Americans, was vehemently condemned in South Korea.  In those times—the early 1990s—much of Korea was insular and  leery of foreigners after 5,000 years of hostile invasions.  Locals viewed him as stealing one of “their” women.  Jennifer’s parents saw him as interfering with plans to marry her well and increase the family’s societal status.  Soon both Mark and Jennifer became the targets of beatings and other vicious attempts to put an end to their relationship, first from society and then, when the parents found out, from the powerful family.  Jennifer—wickedly smart, fiercely independent—had always been a silent outlier in Korean society, reading translations of foreign classics and dreaming of a life where she had some choice.  With no money, no jobs and no support system, the two were ultimately forced to flee to Hong Kong, where their situation only became more dire. But having overcome such unthinkable circumstances to get there, and driven by the desire to stay together and build a loving home of their own, they found the strength to make it through hunger, poverty and ostracization and ultimately, to escape with their lives and love intact.  Told in the hallucinogenic style of a twenty-something falling in love for the first time, Stealing Cinderella asks its audience to consider the lengths they’re willing to go to for love and to remain true to themselves despite society’s pressures. It demonstrates how a shared experience—like surviving abusive families—can bond two people more tightly than race, religion or culture.  “I’m used to being excluded and feeling unwelcome. I’ve been a hoodlum my whole life. They want to tell me I’m stealing her? Fuck it. Okay, I’m stealing her,”  Diehl writes.  Mark and Jennifer now live in the United States, and have been married for 20 years.  Advance Praise for Stealing Cinderella: How I Became an International Fugitive For Love  “An engrossing, poignant, and often disturbing adventure loaded with historical and cultural details….  [Stealing Cinderella] combines the drama and excitement of a novel with some sociological commentary, offering both a tender love story and an eye-opening depiction of Korean values, restrictions, and strengths in the early ’90s.”  —Kirkus Reviews  “Stealing Cinderella is a thrilling, high-stakes memoir—emotionally intense, in which two memorable lovers fight against injustice and toward a satisfying conclusion.”  —Foreword Reviews  About Mark Diehl  Mark D. Diehl has been homeless in Japan, practiced law with a major multinational firm in Chicago, studied in Singapore, fled South Korea as a fugitive, and been stranded in Hong Kong.  After spending most of his youth running around with hoods and thugs, he eventually earned his doctorate in law at the University of Iowa and completed a two-year graduate workshop in creative writing at the University of Chicago.  The first book in his dystopian sci-fi trilogy Seventeen won the Maine Literary Award for Speculative Fiction and became an Amazon best-seller.  Mark currently lives with Jennifer in Cape Elizabeth, Maine.  Title: Stealing Cinderella: How I Became an International Fugitive For Love Author: Mark D. Diehl Print: $15.99 Publisher:  Fencetree Press Language: English ISBN-13: 978-1732819931    ______________________  If you would rather not receive future communications from BSPR, please go to https://u7061146.ct.sendgrid.net/wf/click?upn=mAHw-2B8ZZluKmvldupnv96uLo9Y9fajlVzzV3E2AQMMy3o0jRx7vDS35Oho-2BRYwxVM-2F-2BL7LaoyWUUZGT3ACwSPFkJqFcQsqPw4Ked25yd0ugJky7FLiutBDxjkhoL17ZQt40yAqPnyAOv5evTkDB8dtJhZerS78nx8sFcy6-2B5YN4-3D_6pchHAirW10eM8b14ZAlkZkRllITHdt0G4CIxpgEX-2FYMT-2FVtvkhkoxOwXdc140hQDKip1v9w6NG6f4yMNdzd3I0JbBoOspHl9BOjIgd0xs1LXgkhZeXpW8sBYmfs9SY-2FcSnM-2F66YqFjsEInfDkQ6PtTXiWXoO0W0-2BfuTgcs7loYyYkB6gN4xwwQHeWDKG-2Bq7i0OjtzTyK4LHfUjz32EVCIJ1-2FRusOt8rggAU4E73GctdVMXLA-2BLb9n-2F-2FAvGJeojzZyjKrt8JaO1-2F-2F7cwr3uzBwC70JhJf6JWxxvc0qu4HogaOy73yuqckuiGUvWeGx1ggDnNpNNktPRiHU0Y9qR1-2BcInbdVewh-2B3Oqtw97s4nPY-3D  BSPR, 18 Main Street, Extension, Suite 409, Plymouth, MA 02360 United States  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to customerservice+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Christian Comedian John Crist announces the release of his first book during a town hall on SiriusXM's The Catholic Channel
column3: Christian stand-up comedian and social viral sensation John Crist stopped by SiriusXM Studios yesterday to chat with Jennifer Fulwiler, host of The Jennifer Fulwiler Show on SiriusXM's The Catholic Channel.  During the discussion, Crist announced the release of his first book "Untag Me: The Subtle Art of Appearing Better Than You Really Are" which will hit stores in the Spring of 2020. The book will focuse on the digital age and take a deeper dive into the way we live online, as well as explain the ways to carefully curate the perfect life on social media. Crist describes it as "trying to present a better version of your actual self."  Crist and Fulwiler also discussed the worlds of both comedy and faith and removing the labels people put on clean comedians. Whether a comedian is clean or not does not matter, Crist says "Jerry Seinfeld is clean... the best part about him is funny, you'd rather lead with that."  To hear the full interview tune in to SiriusXM's The Catholic Channel (Ch. 129)  on Wednesday, August 14 at 3:00 pm ET with replays Thursday, August 15 at 1:00 am ET, Saturday, August 17 at 6:00 am, 9:00 am and 1:00 pm ET, and Sunday, August 18 at 9:00 am, 6:00 pm and 9:00 pm ET.  Videos below and photos attached. If used, please credit SiriusXM's The Jennifer Fulwiler Show, and photography to Maro Hagopian/SiriusXM  Comedian John Crist announces the release of his first book 'Untag Me' https://youtu.be/s0iCV04H3aQ  John Crist discusses removing labels put on clean comedians https://youtu.be/ndFjCWNVZqU  [cid:image003.jpg@01D551F9.273FD920]  [cid:image007.jpg@01D551F9.273FD920]  Chelsea Kaufman | Manager, Corporate Communications 1221 Avenue of the Americas | New York, NY 10020 O: 646.949.8591 Chelsea.Kaufman@siriusxm.com<mailto:Chelsea.Kaufman@siriusxm.com> [cid:image001.png@01D5371E.C9682590]
