column2: Re: Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico
column3: Hi. Since Friday, and today,Not able to listen to or read the christian Science perspective.Thank you,Helen Harper     On Monday, August 12, 2019, 06:17:35 PM EDT, Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com> wrote:         |    | |   Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress.   |    |    |   |      |   August 12    | |    Full Version      Listen    |       |   Welcome to your Daily. Today we look at U.S. guns crossing borders, a risky repositioning in the Mideast, new perspective on Guatemala, how Woodstock still reverberates, and what’s up with 5G.   But first, a look at perseverance and adaptation.   Thursday’s report from the U.N.’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change did more than lay out the sobering scope of desertification and land degradation and the implications for feeding the world. It also hinted at hope.   “The good news is [that] there’s ample room for mitigation,” Michael Mann, a professor of atmospheric science at Penn State, told CNN. One key piece, he and others say: coaxing more productivity from land. Technological innovation will help. Both consumer and land-use practices will need to shift worldwide. What about local action?   Last fall, the Camp fire burned more than 153,000 acres in Northern California and erased the town of Paradise (most of its population remains displaced). But as Martin Kuz reported in May, some residents emerged with renewed purpose.   And more recently, ecosystem restoration there has become hands-on. In pockets, reports Yes! Magazine, residents are trying permaculture. In its fullest form that’s an approach where native crops and animals are positioned to help one another thrive – think nut trees surrounded by farmed pigs. The self-sustaining, soil-enriching cycle that results can dramatically boost per-acre yields.  “Welcome to the experiment!” Matthew Trumm, founder of the Camp Fire Restoration Project, tells those who have turned up to help. (His own work was inspired by an agronomist’s mid-1990s project in China.)   Already taking root in parts of Paradise: a constructive outlook to pass along.   “Because you’re bringing the next generation [into] thinking about this stuff,” said Mr. Trumm, “you’re healing that next generation.”  ~   |      |      | |   Clayton Collins    Director, editorial innovation      @ClayCollinsCSM     |      |            |       |   |  |  |  |   ANNOUNCEMENT  Have you set up your password?  Please set up a password to get full access and  no ads on CSMonitor.com. |   |   |   |    |       |    1. Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico    |     |      |       |    Security is a two-way street. The cross-border movement of migrants gets more media attention because of its direction; we asked our reporter to look at reactions to traffic in U.S.-originating guns.    |      |   – Clayton    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Guns bought from vendors in the United States and then smuggled illegally abroad are a fact of life across the Americas. But the mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, this month have emboldened foreign stances against lax U.S. gun laws and shifted conversations about what that means for crime and safety north and south of the U.S. border.  Weaker gun regulations in the U.S. have long undermined Canada’s much stricter rules, as guns get trafficked north. The U.S. massacres came the same weekend as 17 shootings in 14 different incidents across Toronto. Border Security Minister Bill Blair said Canada could reduce violence with more money toward stopping guns from the U.S., which he called “the greatest arsenal in the world.”  Some 70% of guns recovered by law enforcement in Mexico and sent to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) between 2011 and 2016 were originally purchased from a licensed U.S. dealer. And of course, more than a third of those killed were Mexican citizens – prompting a withering response from Mexico.  President Andrés Manuel López Obrador urged U.S. leaders to reflect upon the “indiscriminate sale of guns.” Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard went further, threatening to open up a terrorist probe across the border.    | |   By Sara Miller Llana    | |   By Whitney Eulich    | |  Read 6 min.  | |   ( 1429 words )    | |       |       |    2. What Russian deal? Israel and Jordan cast wary eye toward Syria.    |     |       Ammar Awad/Reuters    |       |    The setting of hard lines, with consequences, is as standard in foreign policy as it is in parenting. As one analyst says, citing southern Syria, it’s also “a game of brinkmanship where you can lose control.”    |      |   – Clayton    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Russia, the main power broker in Syria, pledged to both Israel and Jordan in 2018 that security arrangements for the south would keep Iranian forces 70 to 80 kilometers from their borders. Israel and Jordan took that pledge to include Iran’s proxies, especially Hezbollah.  But one year later evidence is solidifying that the Lebanese Shiite militant group has become increasingly entrenched in the area. Former Free Syrian Army rebels who have returned to their hometowns in southern Syria after an amnesty agreement with the Assad regime say Hezbollah is effectively “governing” several towns and villages.  Now concern is growing among Israel, Jordan, and regional analysts that an unintended and potentially “devastating” escalation may be around the corner. “Russia promised that the Iranians and militias would be driven out from southern Syria, and Russia did not deliver the goods,” says Ely Karmon, at the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism in Herzliya, Israel.  “We want the U.S. to maintain a presence in Syria, but also to provide diplomacy to give everyone an off-ramp,” says one Arab diplomat, who requested anonymity. “If the U.S. does not create that ramp, we don’t know who can.”    | |    |         Jacob Turcotte/Staff    |     | |   By Taylor Luck    | |  Read 6 min.  | |   ( 1250 words )    | |       |       |    3. Why Guatemala’s next president is already bound by Trump    |     |       Santiago Billy/AP    |       |    Stop migrants, or pay a price. That’s more or less the choice the U.S. administration has given Guatemala. But will it reduce migration – or just change whose problem it is?    |      |   – Clayton    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Guatemala’s new president-elect, Alejandro Giammattei, won’t actually enter office for several months. But one day after the election, he’s already inherited a hornet’s nest from his predecessor: an unpopular migration deal with the United States.  Threatened by President Donald Trump with possible tariffs, taxes on remittances, and a travel ban, current President Jimmy Morales agreed to require asylum-seekers traveling through Guatemala to apply for asylum there, effectively cutting off requests from Salvadorans and Hondurans at the U.S. border. The U.S. administration has pressured Mexico to sign a similar agreement.  Critics argue that Guatemala, which is the No. 1 country of origin for people apprehended on the U.S. border this year, is in no position to give safety, or much opportunity. Last year, the country’s asylum system processed only 262 applications.   In the border region of Huehuetenango, a highland state that has one of Guatemala’s highest migration levels, Helen Mauricio Palacios sat on a motorbike outside the polls with her 5-year-old and her groceries, deciding whether it was worthwhile to cast her vote – whether either candidate would bring change.  “If we were a safe country, there would not be so many people migrating from here,” she says. “If people could find the success here that they’re searching for elsewhere, they wouldn’t leave.”    | |    |         Karen Norris/Staff    |     | |   By Maya Averbuch    | |  Read 6 min.  | |   ( 1267 words )    | |       |       |  A deeper look     | |    4. Woodstock at 50: How it shaped a generation    |     |       Melanie Stetson Freeman/Staff    |       |    At a time of upheaval, one music festival defined an era with its counterculture spirit of protest, peace, and equality. Fifty years later, in the midst of similar unrest, its message, and mythology, endure.    |      |   – Clayton    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Many Americans would dismiss the gathering as a bacchanalia in the mud – three days of drugs, nudity, subversive music, and psychedelic indulgence. But 50 years ago, Woodstock became a cultural touchstone that defined an era. A number of social protest movements of the 1960s – opposition to the Vietnam War, a push for free love and personal autonomy, a clamor for civil rights and equality – seemed to converge in that field in upstate New York.   Nowadays, the hippie is an endangered species and the idea of music as a counterculture movement doesn’t resonate with a younger generation. Yet in some ways, there are parallels between the idealism of the Woodstock generation and the so-called woke generation. Like their grandparents, the millennials and iGen display a zeal to change the world. Like their forebears, they’re willing to eschew some of the status symbol comforts they grew up with, like cars and homes.   David Crosby, a musician who performed at Woodstock, says the meaning of the festival remains with him. “Woodstock was a glimpse – a momentary glimpse – into what’s possible. Into us being able to live with each other decently and peacefully.”    | |   By Stephen Humphries    | |  Read 15 min.  | |   ( 3370 words )    | |       |       |  The Explainer     | |    5. What is 5G, and how will it affect me?    |     |      |       |    The tech industry touts its next-generation cellphone network as a giant leap in capabilities. But the industry jargon does little to explain it to consumers. We look at what “5G” really means.    |      |   – Clayton    |       |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    The name 5G stands simply for the fifth generation of cellphone service. In practical terms, that means a superfast and much more reliable service – plus the potential for the rise of an “internet of things” where items like home appliances are increasingly web-connected.   Some analysts worry about drawbacks. Rising prices are one issue. Also, 5G carriers will have to build a much denser network of small transmitters to complement today’s cell towers. Some critics have raised concerns that exposure to so many radio waves could have health effects. The industry says no studies have uncovered any problems. The other big concern is privacy, as more data goes online and is tracked.  The positives: Download speeds will ramp up, so you could download a full movie to your phone in seconds rather than minutes. Wireless companies could begin competing with cable firms to offer home internet and TV service. Your city’s traffic grid would communicate with cars and vice versa to reduce bottlenecks and improve safety. All this won’t happen at once. By 2025, just under half of Americans will have 5G connections, according to Deloitte.    | |   By Laurent Belsie    | |    @lbelsie    | |  Read 3 min.  | |   ( 589 words )    | |       |       |  The Monitor's View     | |    A seed for society’s safety: Gun buybacks    |     |  The 30 Sec. Read  | |    Since July 13, more than 7,000 gun owners in New Zealand have handed over their firearms to police under the country’s first program to buy back guns. “We have to do for the greater good of our society,” said one man as he handed over his AR-15 firearm.  The voluntary nature of gun buybacks gives them a special place in the worldwide debate over gun regulations.  In the United States, buybacks have been very popular since the 1990s, even though most scholars say they do not curb gun violence over time. In the U.S. presidential race, several Democratic contenders now advocate for buybacks after the recent mass shootings in Texas and Ohio.  Yet about 70% of gun owners say they could never imagine themselves not owning some sort of firearm.  Buyback programs help bring gun owners in contact with police and others in a community, fostering a dialogue about the ways to keep everyone safe.  While criminals or potential mass shooters are very unlikely to turn in their guns, their ability to find guns or their willingness to see gun use as normal can be diminished if enough owners decide society would be safer without guns.    | |   By the Monitor's Editorial Board    | |  Read 3 min.  | |   ( 641 words )    | |       |       |  A Christian Science Perspective  ( About this feature )   | |    What has infinity got to do with healing?    |     |    Understanding the concept of infinity plays a key role in the practice of Christian Science, as one man found out when he prayed for a horse in need of healing. As he turned to God for inspiration, a powerful sense of God’s goodness as infinite came to him. That changed the way he saw the horse, which was soon free of all the ailments.    | |   By Mark Swinney    | |  Read 3 min.  | |   ( 616 words )    | |       |       |  Viewfinder     | |    History, in midair    |     |       Simone Biles competes on beam at the U.S. Gymnastics Championships Aug. 11, 2019, in Kansas City, Missouri. She became the first gymnast to land a double-double dismount on the beam and a triple double (three twists and two flips) on the floor exercise in competition on her way to her sixth national championship. The last (and only other woman) to be a six-time national champ was Clara Schroth Lomady in 1952. Charlie Riedel/AP    |      |     |       |   ( The illustrations in today's Monitor Daily are by Karen Norris. )   |       |  A LOOK AHEAD   | |    Come back tomorrow. Harry Bruinius is working on a portrait of a youthful bloc of voters in Queens – one with a distinctive take on how democratic socialism could look at the local level.     |      |      | |    Clayton Collins    Director, editorial innovation      @ClayCollinsCSM    |      |    |            The Christian Science Monitor is a trademark of The Christian Science Publishing Society,   registered in the United States and in other countries.   ISSN: 2572-7060    The Christian Science Monitor    The Christian Science Monitor210 Massachusetts Ave, Boston, MA, 02115-3195, United States   © 2019 The Christian Science Publishing Society   Privacy  |  Unsubscribe  Update Profile    |        --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to daily+unsubscribe@csps.com.

Could you possibly help me with this issue or connect me with someone who can? Or, if it is preferable, could you let me know which application and forms I can download from the website? JSH-Online: Daily Thought CSM Commentary Newsletter Monitor Daily JSH-Online: C.S. Journal JSH-Online: C.S. Sentinel CSM Perspective Newsletter JSH-Online: Tip of the Week CSM Books Newsletter CSM Weekender Best of the Monitor CSM Politics Newsletter CSM CS Perspective Newsletter   Once in a while I get to read them. Sometimes I find myself reading something like the CSM Books Newsletter and clicking on READ NOW only to discover that —   "You've read 3 of 3 free articles. Subscribe to continue."   Which must, I think, obviously, mean that I am not subscribing.   So, maybe you could sort this out for me.   At home I get the regular issues of The Christian Science Monitor Weekly and the Christian Science Sentinel.   I guess what I am asking is — How do I consolidate all of this into one thing, instead of many different subscriptions, including, I guess, JSH-Online.   Thanks.   Frank Geltner 541-961-1482

column2: RE: Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico
column3: What happened? I am a subscriber but receipt of the daily emails no longer takes me to the article when click the listen icon.    The instructions below advise me to set-up an account with a password.  That was completed when I first subscribed and have benefited until the last week or earlier, can read or listen with a simple click as previously did.  I tried to follow the direction to set-up an account, but it directed me to help and sent an email and still didn’t get to listen to the articles below.  Shirley Schmidt  271B Braeburn Circle  Meadowlakes, TX 78654-6619  shirleys@nctv.com        From: Monitor Daily [mailto:daily@csmonitor.com]  Sent: Monday, August 12, 2019 5:17 PM To: shirleys@nctv.com Subject: Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico       The Christian Science Monitor Daily <http://image.cssubs.com/lib/fe6c15707c62047d7614/m/1/2bed9684-079d-4c51-9664-03c424349415.png>    Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress.             August 12     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email>    <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> Full Version       <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=full-audio-block> headphones iconListen       Welcome to your Daily. Today we look at U.S. guns crossing borders <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093943> , a risky repositioning in the Mideast <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093888> , new perspective on Guatemala <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093946> , how Woodstock <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093947>  still reverberates, and what’s up with 5G <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093948> .   But first, a look at perseverance and adaptation.   Thursday’s report <https://www.ipcc.ch/report/srccl/>  from the U.N.’s Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change did more than lay out the sobering scope of desertification and land degradation and the implications for feeding the world. It also hinted at hope.   “The good news is [that] there’s ample room for mitigation,” Michael Mann, a professor of atmospheric science at Penn State, told CNN <https://www.cnn.com/videos/world/2019/08/09/amanpour-michael-mann-ipcc-climate-crisis.cnn> . One key piece, he and others say: coaxing more productivity from land. Technological innovation will help <https://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/the-monitors-view/2019/0808/Climate-gloom-and-innovation-bloom> . Both consumer and land-use practices will need to shift worldwide. What about local action?   Last fall, the Camp fire burned more than 153,000 acres in Northern California and erased the town of Paradise (most of its population remains displaced <https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/07/11/paradise-california-population-camp-fire-california-wildfire-fund/1710525001/> ). But as Martin Kuz reported in May <https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Society/2019/0403/After-California-wildfires-what-survivors-say-they-gained-from-loss> , some residents emerged with renewed purpose.   And more recently, ecosystem restoration there has become hands-on. In pockets, reports Yes! Magazine  <https://www.yesmagazine.org/planet/california-wildfire-survivors-recovery-permaculture-20190723> , residents are trying permaculture. In its fullest form that’s an approach where native crops and animals are positioned to help one another thrive – think nut trees surrounded by farmed pigs. The self-sustaining, soil-enriching cycle that results can dramatically boost per-acre yields <https://charleseisenstein.org/essays/permaculture-and-the-myth-of-scarcity/> .  “Welcome to the experiment!” Matthew Trumm, founder of the Camp Fire Restoration Project, tells those who have turned up to help. (His own work was inspired by an agronomist’s mid-1990s project in China.)   Already taking root in parts of Paradise: a constructive outlook to pass along.   “Because you’re bringing the next generation [into] thinking about this stuff,” said Mr. Trumm, “you’re healing that next generation.”  ~    <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df4d4e193a957c92df4320f2cbf7b6fb298cf740c979191f590d2fd5ec959d3c865256c572660f8efabb85774a921c53706f6c785d865d61ca> https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2017/06/1034591_3_illustration_clay-collins_standard.png?alias=square_400x400   Clayton Collins   Director, editorial innovation    <https://twitter.com/ClayCollinsCSM?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> twitter@ClayCollinsCSM        <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df9c82f58f06063d6e488fed2beacd88fe1bc888982c63ffcb3200a9da7ca75f9ac8d97212e50625d7bd35690bd338ca3dec1f8caa65864657> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df1ba6a0ae42326c6affedf5917fc56e910533e9ad8a5e8501d78c784c7410b7f42a2b1d737d3f476fa7ba1d23b9c0f41659066a5103c66dcb> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Growing%20back%20better%20after%20an%20epic%20wildfire+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Growing-back-better-after-an-epic-wildfire?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share       ANNOUNCEMENT Have you set up your password?  Please set up a password <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=58fe174a0670780264cdb74bb9c22743e9bc4e19283de49c6b54ed7998a0a3ffe5d7ae89b8f3e8b76290c516f4ba566bc753bd17ba5b4d2c>  to get full access and no ads on CSMonitor.com.       1. Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico         <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093943>       Security is a two-way street. The cross-border movement of migrants gets more media attention because of its direction; we asked our reporter to look at reactions to traffic in U.S.-originating guns.   – Clayton    The 30 Sec. Read    Guns bought from vendors in the United States and then smuggled illegally abroad are a fact of life across the Americas. But the mass shootings in El Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, this month have emboldened foreign stances against lax U.S. gun laws and shifted conversations about what that means for crime and safety north and south of the U.S. border.  Weaker gun regulations in the U.S. have long undermined Canada’s much stricter rules, as guns get trafficked north. The U.S. massacres came the same weekend as 17 shootings in 14 different incidents across Toronto. Border Security Minister Bill Blair said Canada could reduce violence with more money toward stopping guns from the U.S., which he called “the greatest arsenal in the world.”  Some 70% of guns recovered by law enforcement in Mexico and sent to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) between 2011 and 2016 were originally purchased from a licensed U.S. dealer. And of course, more than a third of those killed were Mexican citizens – prompting a withering response from Mexico.  President Andrés Manuel López Obrador urged U.S. leaders to reflect upon the “indiscriminate sale of guns.” Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard went further, threatening to open up a terrorist probe across the border.   By Sara Miller Llana    By Whitney Eulich     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093943> Read 6 min.    ( 1429 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df8546c9f243033972706f46142ad8cf549eb0ad1a2a62a779976bd7196b42d9f6ba0893b27bee284459325d81eeb28be5c2e595a5e11efabb> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df7872f1524ecb7a8b5866f06d5406399866fc6413fe06a53ebc8480195a92674d3c26e2e612eac9622f872cb70b666d2c5a25edbcdc7b9217> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Illegal%20border%20crossing:%20How%20U.S.%20guns%20wind%20up%20in%20Canada%20and%20Mexico+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Illegal-border-crossing-How-U.S.-guns-wind-up-in-Canada-and-Mexico?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share    2. What Russian deal? Israel and Jordan cast wary eye toward Syria.         <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093888>    Ammar Awad/Reuters        The setting of hard lines, with consequences, is as standard in foreign policy as it is in parenting. As one analyst says, citing southern Syria, it’s also “a game of brinkmanship where you can lose control.”   – Clayton    The 30 Sec. Read    Russia, the main power broker in Syria, pledged to both Israel and Jordan in 2018 that security arrangements for the south would keep Iranian forces 70 to 80 kilometers from their borders. Israel and Jordan took that pledge to include Iran’s proxies, especially Hezbollah.  But one year later evidence is solidifying that the Lebanese Shiite militant group has become increasingly entrenched in the area. Former Free Syrian Army rebels who have returned to their hometowns in southern Syria after an amnesty agreement with the Assad regime say Hezbollah is effectively “governing” several towns and villages.  Now concern is growing among Israel, Jordan, and regional analysts that an unintended and potentially “devastating” escalation may be around the corner. “Russia promised that the Iranians and militias would be driven out from southern Syria, and Russia did not deliver the goods,” says Ely Karmon, at the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism in Herzliya, Israel.  “We want the U.S. to maintain a presence in Syria, but also to provide diplomacy to give everyone an off-ramp,” says one Arab diplomat, who requested anonymity. “If the U.S. does not create that ramp, we don’t know who can.”     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093888>    Jacob Turcotte/Staff    By Taylor Luck     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093888> Read 6 min.    ( 1250 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853dfe0aad70ce442903a638f4e070a5ac0954c70b6a18a68b1d8f239ba89d295f2881a92fd8180fd6f5e9d40e883c6d4feab284a7853b7914817> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df96eb403caf712a462ef2bb759e46a0c82188dc681d4182e3077d92cb8d66d7ebffa55182aa1f933eb50240a4ab29ffb377ce7d3a3e559e7e> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+What%20Russian%20deal?%20Israel%20and%20Jordan%20cast%20wary%20eye%20toward%20Syria.+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/What-Russian-deal-Israel-and-Jordan-cast-wary-eye-toward-Syria?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share       3. Why Guatemala’s next president is already bound by Trump         <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093946>    Santiago Billy/AP        Stop migrants, or pay a price. That’s more or less the choice the U.S. administration has given Guatemala. But will it reduce migration – or just change whose problem it is?   – Clayton    The 30 Sec. Read    Guatemala’s new president-elect, Alejandro Giammattei, won’t actually enter office for several months. But one day after the election, he’s already inherited a hornet’s nest from his predecessor: an unpopular migration deal with the United States.  Threatened by President Donald Trump with possible tariffs, taxes on remittances, and a travel ban, current President Jimmy Morales agreed to require asylum-seekers traveling through Guatemala to apply for asylum there, effectively cutting off requests from Salvadorans and Hondurans at the U.S. border. The U.S. administration has pressured Mexico to sign a similar agreement.  Critics argue that Guatemala, which is the No. 1 country of origin for people apprehended on the U.S. border this year, is in no position to give safety, or much opportunity. Last year, the country’s asylum system processed only 262 applications.   In the border region of Huehuetenango, a highland state that has one of Guatemala’s highest migration levels, Helen Mauricio Palacios sat on a motorbike outside the polls with her 5-year-old and her groceries, deciding whether it was worthwhile to cast her vote – whether either candidate would bring change.  “If we were a safe country, there would not be so many people migrating from here,” she says. “If people could find the success here that they’re searching for elsewhere, they wouldn’t leave.”     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093946>    Karen Norris/Staff    By Maya Averbuch     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093946> Read 6 min.    ( 1267 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853dfa541b02e13b0609b41831d10ea8abbf464ec55674d7e802e5fa27f3f64ca1c19aaa13d4de3728b13a5ebb444c347e6621df95ec434de2284> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df63d2f73674dd77c05e6a134d750c2b479dbb413b8a4b0981547910421cb2af19de81131ce9d61123f8c5232e0b163b1c5143c5898eb1f2da> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Why%20Guatemala’s%20next%20president%20is%20already%20bound%20by%20Trump+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Why-Guatemala-s-next-president-is-already-bound-by-Trump?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share   A deeper look     4. Woodstock at 50: How it shaped a generation         <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093947>    Melanie Stetson Freeman/Staff        At a time of upheaval, one music festival defined an era with its counterculture spirit of protest, peace, and equality. Fifty years later, in the midst of similar unrest, its message, and mythology, endure.   – Clayton    The 30 Sec. Read    Many Americans would dismiss the gathering as a bacchanalia in the mud – three days of drugs, nudity, subversive music, and psychedelic indulgence. But 50 years ago, Woodstock became a cultural touchstone that defined an era. A number of social protest movements of the 1960s – opposition to the Vietnam War, a push for free love and personal autonomy, a clamor for civil rights and equality – seemed to converge in that field in upstate New York.   Nowadays, the hippie is an endangered species and the idea of music as a counterculture movement doesn’t resonate with a younger generation. Yet in some ways, there are parallels between the idealism of the Woodstock generation and the so-called woke generation. Like their grandparents, the millennials and iGen display a zeal to change the world. Like their forebears, they’re willing to eschew some of the status symbol comforts they grew up with, like cars and homes.   David Crosby, a musician who performed at Woodstock, says the meaning of the festival remains with him. “Woodstock was a glimpse – a momentary glimpse – into what’s possible. Into us being able to live with each other decently and peacefully.”   By Stephen Humphries     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093947> Read 15 min.    ( 3370 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df6e2d321058ab9ea868bc4c4447d0fcc0ebfd266248ec0601dcef6f359007f858fe1f7abbf04f9332aa37ac26dd4bcbbb023d073764b2196e> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df6d24f8e896db91970422085cecb9a497c6370508a47d213a19860e0ba644f92e2fbf1e200aca84a62f7f50ba73823ee8429af18aacd3c979> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Woodstock%20at%2050:%20How%20it%20shaped%20a%20generation+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Woodstock-at-50-How-it-shaped-a-generation?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share      The Explainer     5. What is 5G, and how will it affect me?         <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093948>       The tech industry touts its next-generation cellphone network as a giant leap in capabilities. But the industry jargon does little to explain it to consumers. We look at what “5G” really means.   – Clayton    The 30 Sec. Read    The name 5G stands simply for the fifth generation of cellphone service. In practical terms, that means a superfast and much more reliable service – plus the potential for the rise of an “internet of things” where items like home appliances are increasingly web-connected.   Some analysts worry about drawbacks. Rising prices are one issue. Also, 5G carriers will have to build a much denser network of small transmitters to complement today’s cell towers. Some critics have raised concerns that exposure to so many radio waves could have health effects. The industry says no studies have uncovered any problems. The other big concern is privacy, as more data goes online and is tracked.  The positives: Download speeds will ramp up, so you could download a full movie to your phone in seconds rather than minutes. Wireless companies could begin competing with cable firms to offer home internet and TV service. Your city’s traffic grid would communicate with cars and vice versa to reduce bottlenecks and improve safety. All this won’t happen at once. By 2025, just under half of Americans will have 5G connections, according to Deloitte.   By Laurent Belsie     <https://twitter.com/lbelsie?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> twitter@lbelsie     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093948> Read 3 min.    ( 589 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df217d44db190d6a0505edb3766c197ac36e786f7b7e7e4d4422bc7842fe622bf85ea9b427c0edf39e7fb2b40e5857ad7a117a05ce0c1f6c71> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df312919db802b12e237b6404dba7ab99b092d798655242b29ea518e02f34ff76577ca892a780d3107d260c535f9b3842a621c1d57610764b1> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+What%20is%205G,%20and%20how%20will%20it%20affect%20me?%20+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/What-is-5G-and-how-will-it-affect-me?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share   The Monitor's View     A seed for society’s safety: Gun buybacks        The 30 Sec. Read    Since July 13, more than 7,000 gun owners in New Zealand have handed over their firearms to police under the country’s first program to buy back guns. “We have to do for the greater good of our society,” said one man as he handed over his AR-15 firearm.  The voluntary nature of gun buybacks gives them a special place in the worldwide debate over gun regulations.  In the United States, buybacks have been very popular since the 1990s, even though most scholars say they do not curb gun violence over time. In the U.S. presidential race, several Democratic contenders now advocate for buybacks after the recent mass shootings in Texas and Ohio.  Yet about 70% of gun owners say they could never imagine themselves not owning some sort of firearm.  Buyback programs help bring gun owners in contact with police and others in a community, fostering a dialogue about the ways to keep everyone safe.  While criminals or potential mass shooters are very unlikely to turn in their guns, their ability to find guns or their willingness to see gun use as normal can be diminished if enough owners decide society would be safer without guns.   By the Monitor's Editorial Board     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093824> Read 3 min.    ( 641 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df0f5c49311ed21546ecd3cc05209c217371e323c198997f9ff24246e5b0684a6a6b4d0b2994ab1ac625fc6d0aa7269d7aa210e3c47a798e8e> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853dfeffa252cbff079eb8bc134b34bcf01d99f24a39d78a550cd351d0662abd100122e803eefed3074ff17af5aa6ffc8cc99240fdf62a4ad4e28> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+A%20seed%20for%20society’s%20safety:%20Gun%20buybacks+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/A-seed-for-society-s-safety-Gun-buybacks?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share   A Christian Science Perspective   (  <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=58fe174a06707802837b136fbe41b4fcf34e8e00df7aa95b56d2ca1be8707984243c031a0d2c27bacf30569592c3f0395337d1d7f15b5e6f> About this feature )     What has infinity got to do with healing?        Understanding the concept of infinity plays a key role in the practice of Christian Science, as one man found out when he prayed for a horse in need of healing. As he turned to God for inspiration, a powerful sense of God’s goodness as infinite came to him. That changed the way he saw the horse, which was soon free of all the ailments.   By Mark Swinney     <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093825> Read 3 min.    ( 616 words )     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df53877a433e5db801fdd189e64b69b15333d2a1be94607cdc9ee8af8949ae8386dc3439443af3d4d0ed9e5087c3ec911f2bb78d31172e2b80> Daily facebook share <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853dfa2255a28e2de937558875c9e5962ad8ba4331a8a437b0bc45bd3ae8215eea6fecf8f1540de3f029b9b5b807533371d410489a2862f875c9b> Daily twitter share <mailto:?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's%20the%20article%20on%20CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+What%20has%20infinity%20got%20to%20do%20with%20healing?%20%20+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/What-has-infinity-got-to-do-with-healing?src=shared+%0A%0A+You%20can%20try%20the%20Monitor%20Daily%20free%20for%20a%20week:%20https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> Daily email share   Viewfinder     History, in midair         <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093826>    Simone Biles competes on beam at the U.S. Gymnastics Championships Aug. 11, 2019, in Kansas City, Missouri. She became the first gymnast to land a double-double dismount on the beam and a triple double (three twists and two flips) on the floor exercise in competition on her way to her sixth national championship. The last (and only other woman) to be a six-time national champ was Clara Schroth Lomady in 1952. Charlie Riedel/AP           ( The illustrations in today's Monitor Daily are by Karen Norris. )       A LOOK AHEAD    Come back tomorrow. Harry Bruinius is working on a portrait of a youthful bloc of voters in Queens – one with a distinctive take on how democratic socialism could look at the local level.     <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=495d32841c9853df4d4e193a957c92df4320f2cbf7b6fb298cf740c979191f590d2fd5ec959d3c865256c572660f8efabb85774a921c53706f6c785d865d61ca> https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2017/06/1034591_3_illustration_clay-collins_standard.png?alias=square_400x400   Clayton Collins   Director, editorial innovation    <https://twitter.com/ClayCollinsCSM?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> twitter@ClayCollinsCSM        <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=58fe174a06707802864c6ee6c2d3ac324e11ed2bd917a31b97420e7b30e1bf3fd4d20eeed318daa5a2cbba341691f70ecdccbc5363f0609a> The Christian Science Monitor Daily  The Christian Science Monitor is a trademark of The Christian Science Publishing Society,  registered in the United States and in other countries. column3: Representative's Email *   blairf@csps.com Caller's Name    Virginia Burnett Caller's Phone Number 772-288-9987 Caller's Email Address ginjac53@gmail.com Account number 5885769  Report from CDS?  caller transferred from CDS  Publication / Product * JSH-Online Comments/Feedback *  Virginia was unable to log into JSHO. She spoke to 3 reps at CDS and then was transferred to us. I reset her password and she was able to log in. I let her know that she would stay logged in for 90 days and let her know that she can save her password on her browser and to google how to do that.  She wanted to comment that she had never been told about staying logged in for only 90 days at a time and that none of the three women she spoke to today told her this. Had she known she wouldn't have gotten so frustrated and we need to tell them that they need to tell people about this.  I mentioned that it's in the FAQs and where the FAQs are on JSHO.  Action/Answers given * I thanked her for her feedback and assured her I'd pass her comment forward for a training opportunity.

column2: Re: Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico
column3: Even though I have a subscription, I am blocked from reading stories because it does not acknowledge my subscription. Maryann Riffert  On Mon, Aug 12, 2019 at 3:17 PM Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com> wrote:  > [image: The Christian Science Monitor Daily] > > Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress. > > August 12 > Full Version > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> > [image: headphones icon] Listen > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=full-audio-block> > > Welcome to your Daily. Today we look at U.S. guns crossing borders > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093943>, a > risky repositioning in the Mideast > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093888>, new > perspective on Guatemala > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093946>, how > Woodstock > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093947> still > reverberates, and what’s up with 5G > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?src=email#1093948>. > > But first, a look at perseverance and adaptation. > > Thursday’s report <https://www.ipcc.ch/report/srccl/> from the U.N.’s > Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change did more than lay out the > sobering scope of desertification and land degradation and the implications > for feeding the world. It also hinted at hope. > > “The good news is [that] there’s ample room for mitigation,” Michael Mann, > a professor of atmospheric science at Penn State, told CNN > <https://www.cnn.com/videos/world/2019/08/09/amanpour-michael-mann-ipcc-climate-crisis.cnn>. > One key piece, he and others say: coaxing more productivity from > land. Technological innovation will help > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Commentary/the-monitors-view/2019/0808/Climate-gloom-and-innovation-bloom>. > Both consumer and land-use practices will need to shift worldwide. What > about local action? > > Last fall, the Camp fire burned more than 153,000 acres in Northern > California and erased the town of Paradise (most of its population remains > displaced > <https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2019/07/11/paradise-california-population-camp-fire-california-wildfire-fund/1710525001/>). > But as Martin Kuz reported in May > <https://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Society/2019/0403/After-California-wildfires-what-survivors-say-they-gained-from-loss>, > some residents emerged with renewed purpose. > > And more recently, ecosystem restoration there has become hands-on. In > pockets, reports Yes! Magazine > <https://www.yesmagazine.org/planet/california-wildfire-survivors-recovery-permaculture-20190723>, > residents are trying permaculture. In its fullest form that’s an approach > where native crops and animals are positioned to help one another thrive – > think nut trees surrounded by farmed pigs. The self-sustaining, > soil-enriching cycle that results can dramatically boost per-acre yields > <https://charleseisenstein.org/essays/permaculture-and-the-myth-of-scarcity/> > . > > “Welcome to the experiment!” Matthew Trumm, founder of the Camp Fire > Restoration Project, tells those who have turned up to help. (His own work > was inspired by an agronomist’s mid-1990s project in China.) > > Already taking root in parts of Paradise: a constructive outlook to pass > along. > > “Because you’re bringing the next generation [into] thinking about this > stuff,” said Mr. Trumm, “you’re healing that next generation.” > ~ > [image: > https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2017/06/1034591_3_illustration_clay-collins_standard.png?alias=square_400x400] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322604ef603b4b5bbfa7bff1d51af6755a7c4f801dbe174c15c5d383b578e123c69c53d88a79eb93161722bd3a6fe357a5a4> > > Clayton Collins > > Director, editorial innovation > > [image: twitter] @ClayCollinsCSM > <https://twitter.com/ClayCollinsCSM?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322615bd55c51d0d8ade7edbd13e9f39af261014661f3559aeb2a4906aa9ee12297bfbece9a9e2da784553aa5d607de3561a> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226dec56706be17031863a49a60aa014dde91dff78c89137c075f368f9dab35d3427cd9e935e979c661767098177c567e25> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Growing+back+better+after+an+epic+wildfire+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Growing-back-better-after-an-epic-wildfire?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > 1. Illegal border crossing: How U.S. guns wind up in Canada and Mexico > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093943> > > Security is a two-way street. The cross-border movement of migrants gets > more media attention because of its direction; we asked our reporter to > look at reactions to traffic in U.S.-originating guns. > > – Clayton > The 30 Sec. Read > > Guns bought from vendors in the United States and then smuggled illegally > abroad are a fact of life across the Americas. But the mass shootings in El > Paso, Texas, and Dayton, Ohio, this month have emboldened foreign stances > against lax U.S. gun laws and shifted conversations about what that means > for crime and safety north and south of the U.S. border. > > Weaker gun regulations in the U.S. have long undermined Canada’s much > stricter rules, as guns get trafficked north. The U.S. massacres came the > same weekend as 17 shootings in 14 different incidents across Toronto. > Border Security Minister Bill Blair said Canada could reduce violence with > more money toward stopping guns from the U.S., which he called “the > greatest arsenal in the world.” > > Some 70% of guns recovered by law enforcement in Mexico and sent to > the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives (ATF) between 2011 > and 2016 were originally purchased from a licensed U.S. dealer. And of > course, more than a third of those killed were Mexican citizens – prompting > a withering response from Mexico. > > President Andrés Manuel López Obrador urged U.S. leaders to reflect upon > the “indiscriminate sale of guns.” Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard went > further, threatening to open up a terrorist probe across the border. > > By *Sara Miller Llana* > > By *Whitney Eulich* > Read 6 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093943> > > ( 1429 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226c06d9acc5b4e297ee87900749c25097904d1fd5729a5fdf482a0aa4770ed98b7cc15d49abc79f23a9019060c67f39f7e> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226bfee81109e5a4ca0d8789ec15b07c6943af85f83fc95758d736b347ab7593782df4a102320164b028c9b5599f5cd4262> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Illegal+border+crossing:+How+U.S.+guns+wind+up+in+Canada+and+Mexico+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Illegal-border-crossing-How-U.S.-guns-wind-up-in-Canada-and-Mexico?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > 2. What Russian deal? Israel and Jordan cast wary eye toward Syria. > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093888> Ammar > Awad/Reuters > > The setting of hard lines, with consequences, is as standard in foreign > policy as it is in parenting. As one analyst says, citing southern Syria, > it’s also “a game of brinkmanship where you can lose control.” > > – Clayton > The 30 Sec. Read > > Russia, the main power broker in Syria, pledged to both Israel and Jordan > in 2018 that security arrangements for the south would keep Iranian forces > 70 to 80 kilometers from their borders. Israel and Jordan took that pledge > to include Iran’s proxies, especially Hezbollah. > > But one year later evidence is solidifying that the Lebanese Shiite > militant group has become increasingly entrenched in the area. Former Free > Syrian Army rebels who have returned to their hometowns in southern Syria > after an amnesty agreement with the Assad regime say Hezbollah is > effectively “governing” several towns and villages. > > Now concern is growing among Israel, Jordan, and regional analysts that an > unintended and potentially “devastating” escalation may be around the > corner. “Russia promised that the Iranians and militias would be driven out > from southern Syria, and Russia did not deliver the goods,” says Ely > Karmon, at the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism in Herzliya, > Israel. > > “We want the U.S. to maintain a presence in Syria, but also to provide > diplomacy to give everyone an off-ramp,” says one Arab diplomat, who > requested anonymity. “If the U.S. does not create that ramp, we don’t know > who can.” > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093888> > Jacob Turcotte/Staff > > By *Taylor Luck* > Read 6 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093888> > > ( 1250 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322655e2ff59e932f4b476ccc2e919c0326caeece39f4cc05f8c8ad85958a969fc10ab087a69bebfa7c26de5347155a016d4> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226cf68aca3978a7a0e01036c03776f0f55510664282d747db02609deb72b0f56ef697d61539f7defe31ffcfdd8a9029e09> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+What+Russian+deal?%20Israel%20and%20Jordan%20cast%20wary%20eye%20toward%20Syria.+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/What-Russian-deal-Israel-and-Jordan-cast-wary-eye-toward-Syria?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > 3. Why Guatemala’s next president is already bound by Trump > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093946> Santiago > Billy/AP > > Stop migrants, or pay a price. That’s more or less the choice the U.S. > administration has given Guatemala. But will it reduce migration – or just > change whose problem it is? > > – Clayton > The 30 Sec. Read > > Guatemala’s new president-elect, Alejandro Giammattei, won’t actually > enter office for several months. But one day after the election, he’s > already inherited a hornet’s nest from his predecessor: an unpopular > migration deal with the United States. > > Threatened by President Donald Trump with possible tariffs, taxes on > remittances, and a travel ban, current President Jimmy Morales agreed to > require asylum-seekers traveling through Guatemala to apply for asylum > there, effectively cutting off requests from Salvadorans and Hondurans at > the U.S. border. The U.S. administration has pressured Mexico to sign a > similar agreement. > > Critics argue that Guatemala, which is the No. 1 country of origin for > people apprehended on the U.S. border this year, is in no position to give > safety, or much opportunity. Last year, the country’s asylum system > processed only 262 applications. > > In the border region of Huehuetenango, a highland state that has one of > Guatemala’s highest migration levels, Helen Mauricio Palacios sat on a > motorbike outside the polls with her 5-year-old and her groceries, deciding > whether it was worthwhile to cast her vote – whether either candidate would > bring change. > > “If we were a safe country, there would not be so many people migrating > from here,” she says. “If people could find the success here that they’re > searching for elsewhere, they wouldn’t leave.” > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093946> > Karen Norris/Staff > > By *Maya Averbuch* > Read 6 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093946> > > ( 1267 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df32268677f82266af45580a6154668be1667599b64c5bf76c56ae14794c45fd6ad32cf05997b2b2657f910719d79946ee4d71> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df32267950c22a9c41eadc1c5666af600f4792734343210514808ba6feaef5b61278237f23031ded2ff72d49fa8166cf5be482> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Why+Guatemala’s+next+president+is+already+bound+by+Trump+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Why-Guatemala-s-next-president-is-already-bound-by-Trump?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > A deeper look > 4. Woodstock at 50: How it shaped a generation > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093947> Melanie > Stetson Freeman/Staff > > At a time of upheaval, one music festival defined an era with its > counterculture spirit of protest, peace, and equality. Fifty years later, > in the midst of similar unrest, its message, and mythology, endure. > > – Clayton > The 30 Sec. Read > > Many Americans would dismiss the gathering as a bacchanalia in the mud – > three days of drugs, nudity, subversive music, and psychedelic indulgence. > But 50 years ago, Woodstock became a cultural touchstone that defined an > era. A number of social protest movements of the 1960s – opposition to the > Vietnam War, a push for free love and personal autonomy, a clamor for civil > rights and equality – seemed to converge in that field in upstate New York. > > Nowadays, the hippie is an endangered species and the idea of music as a > counterculture movement doesn’t resonate with a younger generation. Yet in > some ways, there are parallels between the idealism of the Woodstock > generation and the so-called woke generation. Like their grandparents, the > millennials and iGen display a zeal to change the world. Like their > forebears, they’re willing to eschew some of the status symbol comforts > they grew up with, like cars and homes. > > David Crosby, a musician who performed at Woodstock, says the meaning of > the festival remains with him. “Woodstock was a glimpse – a momentary > glimpse – into what’s possible. Into us being able to live with each other > decently and peacefully.” > > By *Stephen Humphries* > Read 15 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093947> > > ( 3370 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226e78ca9f3d85debcde67db0db4d27e2ba41b8ca9b2192639b3b55951ed2451e3616f119e446f11d55d9bc8dede75b3ccb> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322679ecdf7485c3b4051ec74683924a8cfbca19bb0ccd4ff6aecbb349550a50d9c821b30603ea669acd3c8784144f7432e4> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+Woodstock+at+50:+How+it+shaped+a+generation+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/Woodstock-at-50-How-it-shaped-a-generation?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > The Explainer > 5. What is 5G, and how will it affect me? > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093948> > > The tech industry touts its next-generation cellphone network as a giant > leap in capabilities. But the industry jargon does little to explain it to > consumers. We look at what “5G” really means. > > – Clayton > The 30 Sec. Read > > The name 5G stands simply for the fifth generation of cellphone service. > In practical terms, that means a superfast and much more reliable service – > plus the potential for the rise of an “internet of things” where items like > home appliances are increasingly web-connected. > > Some analysts worry about drawbacks. Rising prices are one issue. Also, 5G > carriers will have to build a much denser network of small transmitters to > complement today’s cell towers. Some critics have raised concerns that > exposure to so many radio waves could have health effects. The industry > says no studies have uncovered any problems. The other big concern is > privacy, as more data goes online and is tracked. > > The positives: Download speeds will ramp up, so you could download a full > movie to your phone in seconds rather than minutes. Wireless companies > could begin competing with cable firms to offer home internet and TV > service. Your city’s traffic grid would communicate with cars and vice > versa to reduce bottlenecks and improve safety. All this won’t happen at > once. By 2025, just under half of Americans will have 5G connections, > according to Deloitte. > > By *Laurent Belsie* > > [image: twitter]@lbelsie > <https://twitter.com/lbelsie?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> > Read 3 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093948> > > ( 589 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322631b1641cc28c6d77d28c8daaada540cbdf0f8326c3878c6b46d988db6d22461282f6bce70191b4f59c63f3aa1638ab9e> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322641d3d392664ae5684e6ac3450f5cd9906b176f5f9deac9295997f02b98573557d0f99b27217548ad89c082a640d34b3a> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+What+is+5G,+and+how+will+it+affect+me?%20+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/What-is-5G-and-how-will-it-affect-me?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > The Monitor's View > A seed for society’s safety: Gun buybacks > The 30 Sec. Read > > Since July 13, more than 7,000 gun owners in New Zealand have handed over > their firearms to police under the country’s first program to buy back > guns. “We have to do for the greater good of our society,” said one man as > he handed over his AR-15 firearm. > > The voluntary nature of gun buybacks gives them a special place in the > worldwide debate over gun regulations. > > In the United States, buybacks have been very popular since the 1990s, > even though most scholars say they do not curb gun violence over time. In > the U.S. presidential race, several Democratic contenders now advocate for > buybacks after the recent mass shootings in Texas and Ohio. > > Yet about 70% of gun owners say they could never imagine themselves not > owning some sort of firearm. > > Buyback programs help bring gun owners in contact with police and others > in a community, fostering a dialogue about the ways to keep everyone safe. > > While criminals or potential mass shooters are very unlikely to turn in > their guns, their ability to find guns or their willingness to see gun use > as normal can be diminished if enough owners decide society would be safer > without guns. > > By *the Monitor's Editorial Board* > Read 3 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093824> > > ( 641 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df32262888c871afe74b51762454b5af4542d707dcac96cc9fee5357cf6cc1b6f9c05841190b20d6fcce6abd25e66f5d11b3c3> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df32269061b3c46959eb9a51affc0eda648b6bddd9c7291dd79e918505c024051ecd7a736da7742befb7092ed0a7f33904add7> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+A+seed+for+society’s+safety:+Gun+buybacks+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/A-seed-for-society-s-safety-Gun-buybacks?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > A Christian Science Perspective > ( About this feature > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226c8a7e4edc460a19ea5789fe3e1dd1bcd65d1b7b7bc59740aa7868af37443abf1c75f3a27836503facd04f3fdf69183b2> > ) > What has infinity got to do with healing? > > Understanding the concept of infinity plays a key role in the practice of > Christian Science, as one man found out when he prayed for a horse in need > of healing. As he turned to God for inspiration, a powerful sense of God’s > goodness as infinite came to him. That changed the way he saw the horse, > which was soon free of all the ailments. > > By *Mark Swinney* > Read 3 min. > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email&id=1093825> > > ( 616 words ) > [image: Daily facebook share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226ef32c4d6bca01e9440735d39f245b7ddcfb22c03b28cd6338921618cc2cf622474b5137eb30bbc8441ece503eee3b952> [image: > Daily twitter share] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226639e010854927e9ff714039418fa0a8a2165e9cde2610383a86d132ecdf339e2d1935edf37a1688085629bf63d89171c> [image: > Daily email share] > <?subject=I+think+you%27ll+like+this+article+from+the+Monitor+Daily&body=Here's+the+article+on+CSMonitor.com:+%0A%0A+What+has+infinity+got+to+do+with+healing?%20%20+%0A%0A+https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812/What-has-infinity-got-to-do-with-healing?src=shared+%0A%0A+You+can+try+the+Monitor+Daily+free+for+a+week:+https://www.csmonitor.com/dailyfreetrial> > Viewfinder > History, in midair > > <https://www.csmonitor.com/Daily/2019/20190812?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email#1093826> Simone > Biles competes on beam at the U.S. Gymnastics Championships Aug. 11, 2019, > in Kansas City, Missouri. She became the first gymnast to land a > double-double dismount on the beam and a triple double (three twists and > two flips) on the floor exercise in competition on her way to her sixth > national championship. The last (and only other woman) to be a six-time > national champ was Clara Schroth Lomady in 1952. Charlie Riedel/AP > ( The illustrations in today's Monitor Daily are by Karen Norris. ) > A LOOK AHEAD > > Come back tomorrow. Harry Bruinius is working on a portrait of a youthful > bloc of voters in Queens – one with a distinctive take on how democratic > socialism could look at the local level. > [image: > https://images.csmonitor.com/csm/2017/06/1034591_3_illustration_clay-collins_standard.png?alias=square_400x400] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322604ef603b4b5bbfa7bff1d51af6755a7c4f801dbe174c15c5d383b578e123c69c53d88a79eb93161722bd3a6fe357a5a4> > > Clayton Collins > > Director, editorial innovation > > [image: twitter] @ClayCollinsCSM > <https://twitter.com/ClayCollinsCSM?cmpid=ema:ddp:20190812&src=email> > > [image: The Christian Science Monitor Daily] > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df3226b165942b89fc9226b3467d43f40d1dbcc0277e34bd24bb1ed8a554560d62d9cd7cf5caaf976b8533e4ff09e1ef83ddd5> > > The Christian Science Monitor is a trademark of The Christian Science > Publishing Society, > > registered in the United States and in other countries. > > ISSN: 2572-7060 > > The Christian Science Monitor > > The Christian Science Monitor210 Massachusetts Ave, Boston, MA, > 02115-3195, United States > > © 2019 The Christian Science Publishing Society > Privacy > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df32265e095a5a2b16607940e2b4bf21e2e915dcf4d0e97f13832382973653ef72323038230b0bcc70f0480cafef4155c4b14fb9a25965275610c4> | > Unsubscribe > <https://click.cssubs.com/?qs=4d986bf673df322600f8ad7befeb2ef6cf237742c215302200235166ce5263389088f90239dcecfaa612779140d0418af4ffae9bd0b42cfed0300df13c6cf0d3> > Update Profile > <https://click.cssubs.com/profile_center.aspx?qs=f6ae831827b0b00097cc3b6801d56c6b41692c3d33141718edc77a6a059cc9cff53f887fe4f55c61e7be9461f28eec37f136b26f25e5d28bfe83ed2e81779a9a> >  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to daily+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: Re: Low interest rates are often a cure. Now they’re also a symptom.
column3: Dear friends   There is no audio on The Christian Science Perspective today, Friday 16 August. Any idea when this will be available?  Thanks for all you do Rejoicing always in God's presence and ever constant, unconditional care for.everyone Cathy   Please excuse any 'technical' mistakes in this email sent from my iPad   > On Aug 16, 2019, at 11:18 PM, Monitor Daily <daily@csmonitor.com> wrote: >  >  >  > Going beyond the headlines with the ideas driving progress. > August 16 >  > Full Version                  Listen                                 > In today’s Daily, we look at the slowing global economy, a lawmaker in the limelight, the need for more study in a high-profile debate, progress that's come drop by drop, and an unforgettable documentary. >  > Rep. Rashida Tlaib isn’t going to the West Bank to see her grandmother after all. The House Democrat and fellow Rep. Ilhan Omar had planned to visit the Israeli-occupied territory, and Israel seemed amenable – despite the women’s support of the anti-Israel boycott movement. Then President Donald Trump took to Twitter, and within hours, Israel had barred the visit.  >  > Ultimately, Israel relented, but Ms. Tlaib – profiled in her district in Michigan in today’s Monitor Daily – rejected the new conditions. >  > It’s not every day that Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, top Republicans, and AIPAC, the pro-Israel lobby group, agree. But they did here. AIPAC tweeted that despite the women’s politics, “we also believe every member of Congress should be able to visit and experience our democratic ally Israel firsthand.”  >  > That message could easily be broadened. Anybody with a chance to visit Israel would learn so much about its rich history and culture, and its welcoming people, as I was able to do in 1984 – from Jerusalem and Tel Aviv to the West Bank and Lebanese border. We rented a car and drove the entire country, an experience that shows just how small and vulnerable Israel is. In other words, we saw the place and talked to people for ourselves. We didn’t rely on others’ impressions. >  > Perhaps someday Ms. Tlaib and Ms. Omar will have another opportunity. >  > ~ >   > Linda Feldmann > Staff writer >  @linda_feldmann >                                           > ANNOUNCEMENT > Have you set up your password? > Please set up a password to get full access and > no ads on CSMonitor.com. > 1. Low interest rates are often a cure. Now they’re also a symptom. >   > Warning signs of recession often spur quick-fix policy solutions to jump-start the economy. But perhaps a look at the endemic circumstances that have brought the world to this point is in order. >  > – Linda > The 30 Sec. Read > Recession alarm bells are ringing around the world. From Europe to Asia and Latin America, signs of economic weakness have emerged or worsened recently. >  > For decades, an inverted yield curve, when shorter-term bonds yield a higher interest rate than long-term ones, has been seen as a likely recession indicator. Perhaps, in this era of ultra-low interest rates, an inversion in the United States this week isn’t the danger signal that it used to be. >  > Still, it’s a fragile time, with some large economies such as Germany and Britain possibly in a recession or near it. One safety valve would be for the U.S. and China to resolve their trade war. Another, beyond mere central bank stimulus efforts, could be infrastructure investment that helps for the long run as well as right now. >  > “I think there are huge distortions in the distribution of income that explain the low interest rates and weak [consumer] demand” globally, says economist Michael Pettis in Beijing. One distortion is high income-inequality worldwide, he says. The second is some nations’ focus on exports, which also leaves consumers with less money to spend. >  > By Mark Trumbull > @MarkTCSM >  > Read 7 min. > ( 1519 words ) >       > 2. Rashida Tlaib, Israel, and what her district wants >   > Members of Congress can be both national and local politicians. Those roles don't always coincide.  >  > – Linda > The 30 Sec. Read > Michigan Democratic Rep. Rashida Tlaib is fast becoming a famous name in national politics. She’s one of the four members of the self-named “squad,” the group of young and progressive Democratic women that also includes Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York. One of the first Muslim Americans elected to Congress, she’s become an outspoken advocate for Palestinian causes. This week Israel, pushed by President Donald Trump, barred her from visiting the country. She declined a subsequent offer to visit her grandmother in the West Bank due to conditions Israel would have imposed on the trip. >  > But will national attention help her win reelection back home? That remains an open question. Michigan’s 13th Congressional District is solidly Democratic – and also majority African American. Representative Tlaib squeaked into office in 2018 in part because four black candidates split the African American vote in the primary. >  > Brenda Jones, president of the Detroit City Council, looms as a possible opponent. Ms. Tlaib barely beat Ms. Jones last time around. But there are indications she’s solidifying her position. One recent poll put Ms. Tlaib’s district favorability rating at almost 70%. >  > “She’s really got to get out here and sell herself and meet the people,” says Kevin Quinn, a diesel mechanic and constituent of Representative Tlaib. >  > By Story Hinckley > @storyhinckley >  > Read 6 min. > ( 1287 words ) >       > THE EXPLAINER              > 3. So many guns, so little data: An economist on US gun violence >   > Al Drago/Reuters >  > There’s a consensus that mass shootings in the U.S. must stop. The question is how. First, says one researcher, start with better data on gun violence. >  > – Linda > The 30 Sec. Read > In 1996, the National Rifle Association convinced Congress to cut funding from a government agency. Up until then, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had dedicated millions of dollars to researching gun violence.  >  > The budget cuts put a “chilling effect” on firearms research, as well as on the science of gun policy, says Rand Corp. economist Rosanna Smart. “It seems kind of crazy that we don’t even know how many guns there are in America,” she says.  >  > Our reporter asked Dr. Smart what’s at stake for society given weak data on gun policy. >  > “I think we lose the ability to have conversations around gun policy that are grounded in science and that are grounded in fact,” she says.  >  > Rand found general agreement among experts that gun policy should reduce deaths – even if they disagreed on how to get there. In the economist’s view, “Providing evidence could potentially change minds.” >  > By Francine Kiefer > Read 4 min. > ( 1000 words ) >       > POINT OF PROGRESS              > What's going right > 4. Watershed moment: How Chesapeake Bay turned its H2O around >   > Sometimes progress comes drip by drip. That’s true in the Chesapeake Bay, where decades of dedication to reducing pollution have helped turn the tide. >  > – Linda > The 30 Sec. Read > For the 18 million people living in the Chesapeake Bay region, clean water is key. But since the 1970s, waste runoff and pollution have contaminated its water, threatening ecosystems and economies.   >  > The watershed’s water quality is now slowly improving, a new report finds. Last year 42% of the bay met its water quality standards –the highest since monitoring began 30 years ago. The gains are vital for healthy aquatic life. Underwater grasses are proliferating. And the bay’s famed blue crabs have doubled over the past year.  >  > The source of success? Besides decades of ongoing cleanup efforts, experts point to a daily pollution limit set in 2010. The regulation charges states within the watershed to reduce what they dump.  >  > Challenges to restoration remain, including climate change. The sheer size of the watershed means progress will be slow, says Rachel Felver of the Chesapeake Bay Program.  >  > “It’s a commitment we all have,” she says.  “We want to know that we can still pull crabs out of the water and eat them.” >  > By David Karas > Read 3 min. > ( 679 words ) >       > ON FILM              > 5. ‘One Child Nation’ lays bare China’s population choices >   > Courtesy of Amazon Studios >  > Nanfu Wang, co-director of “One Child Nation,” “began this film as a way to rediscover her own past,” Monitor film critic Peter Rainer writes. In his five-star review, he called it an “extraordinary documentary” examining the repercussions of China’s stringent family planning policy. “It does far more than that. It will help ensure that the full tragedy of those years is not forgotten.” >  > – Linda > By Peter Rainer > Read 3 min. > ( 625 words ) >       > THE MONITOR'S VIEW              > Saving the academic integrity of student-athletes > The 30 Sec. Read > The label “student-athlete” seems in danger of losing its original purpose as college sports have become multibillion-dollar businesses. Together the top 25 college teams generate $2.5 billion in revenue each year. And while top coaches make millions, athletes at best have a scholarship and a degree to show for their efforts. >  > Scholarships can be seen as a form of payment, of course. But they can be a sham: Many players fail to earn degrees, in part because their days may be filled with athletic training. >  > Sen. Chris Murphy, a Democrat from Connecticut who has been studying the finances of college athletics, holds out hope that critics will influence the NCAA to clean up its house. The courts also could step in and determine that the NCAA is a monopoly in need of regulation. That might open the way for Congress to act – a last resort. >  > Among Senator Murphy’s ideas: Insist colleges restore a real balance between the time athletes spend on sports and academics. Better track athletes’ academic progress toward degrees. And study what happens to them after they leave. >  > By the Monitor's Editorial Board > Read 2 min. > ( 560 words ) >       > A CHRISTIAN SCIENCE PERSPECTIVE              > ( About this feature ) > Resentment healed > When a woman felt resentful toward someone she felt had wronged her, striving to follow Jesus’ command “Love your enemies” led her to see that person in a new light, brought healing to their relationship, and freed her from the burden of holding grudges. >  > By Poonam Likhi > Read 3 min. > ( 650 words ) >       > VIEWFINDER > Asia’s spice rack >   > A dog rests in the heat beside a sack of dried chili peppers in Khari Baoli. It’s more than 100 degrees Fahrenheit and the air around Asia’s largest spice market is so filled with spice dust that workers hauling the heavy sacks cough and sneeze as they push through crowded alleyways. The bustling bazaar is packed and restless, with dogs underfoot and monkeys overhead. Shouting can be heard as wholesale and bulk buyers haggle over everything from chilies and cardamom to nuts and dried fruits. Ann Hermes/Staff >  > View Gallery >  > ( The illustrations in today's Monitor Daily are by Karen Norris. ) >  > A LOOK AHEAD                > Thank you for joining us today. We’ll be back Monday with a beautiful video about a Pakistani American artist who is working to revive the Islamic tradition of decorated nikahnamas, or stylized marriage contracts. Nushmia Khan opened her store this year, and has created illuminated contracts for couples around the world. >  >   > Linda Feldmann > Staff writer >  @linda_feldmann >  >   > The Christian Science Monitor is a trademark of The Christian Science Publishing Society, >  > registered in the United States and in other countries. >  > ISSN: 2572-7060 >  > The Christian Science Monitor >  > 210 Massachusetts Ave, Boston, MA, 02115-3195, United States >  > © 2019 The Christian Science Publishing Society >  > Privacy | Unsubscribe > Update Profile  --  To unsubscribe from this group and stop receiving emails from it, send an email to daily+unsubscribe@csps.com.

column2: accessing bible lesson [JSH-Online #31122]
column3: Subject * accessing bible lesson Message *  Hello,  I'm a little frustrated because I can't access the Bible lesson even though I'm a paid JSH-Online subscriber. With the old, previous format of the page, with the link on (if I remember correctly) the right hand side, I never had a problem opening it. But now when I try I can't get it.  When I go to JSH-O I see that I am logged in. It says (as always) 'Hello, Pamela' or whatever. I usually either listen to the lesson by phone or I read the hard copy, but the other day I wanted to read it online. So I went down to the bottom of the page where all the links are now and clicked on Bible Lesson. I got to the page but it said I had to sign in, even though I WAS already signed in with JSH. So I entered my email address and password anyway. Then I got an error message (multiple times) saying my password was incorrect. This was a little annoying since I know I typed it correctly each time I tried. Finally I gave up and clicked on forgot password--even though I obviously hadn't--and then I created a new password. But that one didn't work either and I just kept getting an error message till I just gave up. I hope I don't have to create a new log-in for the Bible lesson page now, which would mean two sign-ins, which is so inefficient. Upgraded designs are supposed to make things more simple rather than more difficult, aren't they?  This whole problem seems unfortunate considering how well it worked (i.e., how easy it was to access the lesson) previously, when it was on the right margin (or wherever it was; as I said previously, that's where I think I remember it being anyway).  Thanks for any feedback!  Email *   pjdell@earthlink.net Category * Technical Troubleshooting Name    Pamela Dell User Agent Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_12_6) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/12.0 Safari/605.1.15
